PROCTEXT.PARA: The PRESIDENT (Senator the Hon. Kerry Sibraa) took the chair at 10 a.m., and read prayers.

TALK.START.PARA: —Petitions have been lodged for presentation as follows:

PETITION.TITLE: Watsonia Army Barracks, Victoria
PETITION.PARA: To the honourable the President and members of the Senate assembled. The petition of the undersigned respectfully showeth that:

1. The Watsonia Army Barracks contains electronic communication facilities, operated by Australian and American personnel, that gives the United States the ability to pin-point Soviet nuclear submarines, hidden in the Oceans.

2. This would make it possible for U.S. killer-submarines to destroy all Soviet nuclear submarines, while the U.S. nuclear submarines launch their missiles in a `first strike' attack. This makes Watsonia a potential nuclear target. A nuclear attack on Watsonia would have a disastrous effect on Melbourne.
3. The `joint U.S.-Australian' bases in Australia endanger rather than protect us. They also add a new menace to the nuclear arms race, that must be stopped.
Your petitioners most humbly pray that the Senate in Parliament assembled should close the `joint Australian-U.S.' electronic communication facilities in the Watsonia Army Barracks.

PETITION.TITLE: Helsham Inquiry
PETITION.PARA: To the honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned respectfully showeth:

That the Federal Government decision to ban future development in 80% of the Helsham inquiry area and rob Tasmanians of hundreds of jobs in the forest and associated industries is wholly unacceptable.
Your petitioners most humbly pray that the Senate, in Parliament assembled, should ensure that the Federal Government abide by the majority decision of the Helsham inquiry.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Report of the Joint Select Committee on Video Material
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled:
We, the undersigned,

note that a majority of the Joint Select committee on Video Material has strongly opposed the proposition that a new NVE category will contain that material as defined in the current `X' classification.

call upon the Senate to request the Government immediately to implement the recommendation of the majority of the Joint Select Committee on Video Material by introducing substantive legislation to ensure that X rated video material (and its R rated equivalent) is refused classification for the purpose of Commonwealth laws.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Senators Archer (from 183 citizens), Calvert (from 66 citizens) and Jones (from 41 citizens).

PETITION.TITLE: Preservation of the Environment
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled:
The petition of the undersigned respectfully showeth:

But for a High Court decision narrowly favouring the Federal Government, 20,000 years old archaeological cave sites near the Franklin River, Tasmania, would have been destroyed, like a United Kingdom Government unable to stop a Wiltshire authority from clearing Stonehenge for a freeway. Constitutional protection for historical and environmental assets is needed.
Your petitioners therefore most humbly pray that the Senate in Parliament assembled should request the Government to hold a referendum to amend the Constitution so that:

The Federal Government has the bounden constitutional duty, which any citizen may legally require it to perform and a right superior to State and local governments, to set above the commercial advantage of one generation, protect and restore all we hold in trust for the future-
Including relics, sites, features, areas, wildlife, buildings or things of Aboriginal and other historical, cultural, architectural, scientific, aesthetic, ecological or environmental importance and-

To care for the maintenance of the balance of nature, manage land, marine and atmospheric use so as to avoid their degradation and act nationally and internationally in any matter seen as related to these, including-

To prevent military and commercial use of uranium and derivatives, beach and related mining; to preserve Heritage Areas, The Great Barrier Reef Region at least as originally defined in the 1975 Act and extended into Torres Strait.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Senators Jenkins (from 439 citizens) and Jones (from 12 citizens).

PETITION.TITLE: Sporting, Cultural and Community Groups: Sponsorship
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled:
We, the undersigned,
(i) are alarmed that many sporting, cultural and community groups have been made to feel that they can attract sponsorship only from promoters of unhealthy products;
(ii) call for a National Health Promotion Foundation to be established through an increase in tobacco excise of 10 cents per packet; and

(iii) urge that the National Health Promotion Foundation provide national sporting, cultural and community groups with alternative sponsorship funding so that these groups can flourish without the taint of accepting money from tobacco companies and assisting in the promotion of their unhealthy products.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Senators Jenkins (from 100 citizens) and Macklin (from 100 citizens).

PETITION.TITLE: How to Vote Cards
PETITION.PARA: To the honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled.
The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that:

millions of dollars of taxpayers money is spent at each Federal election in Australia in the drafting, production and distribution of How-to-Vote cards which are unnecessary and pollutant and that this waste is not desirable or essential in assisting the electorate to vote informatively for their parliamentarians.
Your petitioners most humbly pray that the Senate in Parliament assembled, should:

urge the Government to introduce legislation which requires that the registered How-to-Vote cards of all political parties and candidates for political office must be placed under glass in every polling booth within obvious sight of all voters, thus making it unnecessary for How-to-Vote cards to be distributed at future federal elections.
and your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Legislation
PETITION.PARA: To the honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled.
The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:

1. That it be recognised the proposed Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission Bill is a public, legal acknowledgement that Australians who are non-aboriginal do not have sovereignty in their own country.

2. That the Australian people are opposed to the idea of a treaty, compact or makarrata between the Australian people who are non-aboriginal and those who are aboriginal, and the Government has no mandate or authority to pursue it.
3. That the proposed legislation and treaty
will damage Australia's position under international law and in any conflict,
will cause distrust and conflict between our aboriginal population (1%) and the non-aboriginal population (99%),
will extend aboriginal land rights, contrary to the wishes of the Australian people,
will not be acceptable to the aboriginal people themselves,
will solve none of the problems of aboriginal people who need housing, health services, education and employment.

That therefore, the Senate reject absolutely the announced proposals for an Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission Bill, and the negotiation of a treaty, compact or makarrata between the Commonwealth and aboriginal people.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Senators Jones (from seven citizens) and Knowles (from 39 citizens).

PETITION.TITLE: Shark Bay Region: World Heritage Listing
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:

That we strongly oppose the proposed World Heritage listing of the Shark Bay Region in Western Australia, either partially or in its entirety, believing that all conservation values of the Shark Bay region will be fully protected under the Shark Bay Region Plan, developed over three years by conservation authorities; and we respectfully request the Parliament and Government to remove the threat of World Heritage listing for Shark Bay by making a firm decision not to proceed with any further consideration of it.
Your petitioners therefore most humbly pray that the honourable senators will oppose the World Heritage listing of either a part or the whole of the Shark Bay Region.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Casino, Australian Capital Territory
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled.
The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
(1) That we are totally opposed to the proposal for the establishment of a gambling casino in Canberra or the Australian Capital Territory.
(2) That a casino in Canberra would detract from the unique character and status of our National Capital.

Your petitioners therefore most humbly request the Senate and the Government of the Commonwealth of Australia to reject any proposal or legislation which would permit the establishment of a casino in the Australian Capital Territory.
And your humble petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Kakadu National Park
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate, the petition of the undersigned shows:
that we oppose any mineral exploration or mining in any part of Kakadu National Park, the Kakadu Conservation Zone, or the Alligator Rivers region.
Your petitioners ask that the Senate in Parliament should:
halt all mineral exploration and mining in the Kakadu Conservation Zone by revoking current leases and licences and by incorporating the zone in Kakadu National Park and;

prevent proposed mining in Kakadu Stages I & II by incorporating the Jabiluka and Koongarra Project in the national park and by proclaiming the whole park under the World Heritage Properties Conservation Act, 1983.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: In-vitro Fertilisation Patients: Medicare Funding
PETITION.PARA: The Honourable, the President and members of the Senate in Parliament.
The petition of the undersigned shows a request for Medicare benefits for in-vitro fertilisation for the medical treatment of infertile couples.

Your petitioners pray that the Senate in Parliament assembled grant Medicare benefits for in-vitro fertilisation, IVF, for the medical treatment of infertile couples. 1 in 10 Australian couples are infertile and unable to conceive and carry a baby to birth. Having a family is one of the most fundamental and rewarding aspects of life and benefits the community as a whole. IVF is an established and proven treatment for infertility. There are existing mechanisms to regulate and control IVF, including the National Health and Medical Research Council and the Reproductive Technology Accreditation Committee. Currently IVF patients pay up to $1,500 per treatment cycle for IVF out of their own pockets. This means that some couples who need IVF to help them establish their own family do not have access. We request that Medicare funding be granted for IVF for the treatment of infertility.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Constitution Alteration Legislation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled; the humble petition of the undersigned citizens respectfully showeth:

that while having some reservations on individual aspects of the Constitutional Alteration (Electors Initiative) 1987 your petitioners wish to express our strong support for the concept of people's democracy implied in that Bill.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Senate in Parliament assembled will:

Refer the abovementioned Bill to an appropriate Parliamentary Committee and will examine the operation of direct democracy procedures overseas with the intention of passing legislation granting such facilities to your petitioners during the Bicentennial year.
Your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Food Irradiation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and the members of the Senate in the House assembled.
The petition of the undersigned respectfully showeth:
That we most strongly oppose the process of `food irradiation' by Cobalt 60, Caesium-137, Caesium-134 or any machine sources.
That we oppose the introduction of regulations that will facilitate the food irradiation process being permitted by State Governments.

Your petitioners humbly pray that the Federal Government ban the importation of any radio-active substances or machinery for the purpose of food irradiation, disallow regulations permitting the irradiation of food in Australia and ban the irradiation of food in this country.
We also call upon the Federal Government to withdraw from the Asian Regional Co-operative Project on Food Irradiation and the International Consultative Group on Food Irradiation.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Pharmaceutical Drugs
PETITION.PARA: To the honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled, the humble petition of the undersigned citizens showeth:

that your petitioners deplore the Federal Government's decision to remove 53 pharmaceutical drugs-including the best available for the treatment of high blood pressure, cancer, epilepsy, high cholesterol and uneven heartbeat-and place them for cost saving reasons only on a special list requiring authority from a Canberra bureaucrat, and

that we believe a patient's doctor is clearly the best judge for medication needed for their particular illness and that it is therefore wrong and unfair to force that doctor to waste valuable time referring a case to a person in Canberra who has no personal knowledge of that case.

Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Senate in Parliament assembled will call on the Government to immediately abandon the proposal and keep its election promise of high quality and universal health care for all Australians.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Senators Calvert (from 255 citizens) and Panizza (from 6,344 citizens).

PETITION.TITLE: Fire Hazard, Northern Tasmania
PETITION.PARA: To the honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled.
The petition of these residents of the Commonwealth of Australia in the Weymouth, Lulworth, Beechford and Pipers River areas of Northern Tasmania respectfully showeth:
That notwithstanding the need for future Army Artillery training, the safety of residents from wildfires resulting from impacting shells during the height of summer must be of paramount importance.

That the need for Artillery training could be met in the safer months of April to November thus making the area much safer from the regular fires of which the near catastrophic wildfire which almost engulfed the township of Lulworth on the 18th February 1988, is the latest.
That a suitable firebreak should be constructed and properly maintained around the impact area of the range as fires will burn uncontrollably at almost all times of the year in this area.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the honourable senators will support all moves to reduce the fire hazard in the aforementioned area.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

TALK.START.PARA: —I give notice that, on the next day of sitting, I shall move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate-

(a) notes the decisive rejection of the 4 referendum proposals by the electors of Australia who recorded a `no' vote of 67.16 per cent for the first proposal, 62.56 per cent for the second proposal, 66.49 per cent for the third proposal and 69.33 per cent for the fourth proposal;
(b) notes that this decisive Australia-wide rejection reflected the record rejection of the proposals in every State of the Commonwealth;

(c) notes that the referendum proposals were brought forward by the Hawke/Keating Government and pushed through the Senate, with the assistance of the Australian Democrats, in terms which were patently misleading and without any genuine attempt to obtain Opposition support for a proposal for a longer term for the Federal Parliament on a basis which would not have threatened the vital role of the Senate in protecting the interests of the people of Australia;
(d) notes that the record failure of the 4 proposals is another example of the incompetence of the Attorney-General, the Hon. Lionel Bowen, who is rapidly proving an embarrassment to the Government;

(e) notes that the cost of promoting and conducting the referendum exceeded $40 million of taxpayers' money at a time when expenditure on the sick and the elderly is being reduced by the Hawke/Keating Government allegedly in the interest of economic management, and
(f) calls on the arrogant and out-of-touch Hawke/Keating Government to give:
(i) a full accounting of the total costs of its now discredited campaign against the Australian Constitution, and

(ii) an undertaking not to bring forward further proposals for constitutional change without full consultation with the Liberal and National Party Opposition which is clearly much more in tune with the views of the Australian people on the necessity to protect the Constitution.

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate-
(a) notes the presence of nuclear armed warships at the Fleet Review in Sydney Harbour this week which must be considered very inappropriate guests for a birthday commemoration;
(b) further notes the continued refusal of the governments of the United States and the United Kingdom to acknowledge that their warships carry nuclear weapons when everyone knows that they do;

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Puplick Sen C.J.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Pharmaceutical Benefits Declaration, as contained in Declaration No. PB 3 of 1988 and made under subsection 85 (2) of the National Health Act 1953, be disallowed.

This is a motion to disallow changes which have been made in the way in which certain pharmaceuticals are provided to the people of Australia. It is yet another example of the extent to which the behaviour of the Hawke-Keating Government is both arrogant and out of touch with the real needs of the people of Australia. It is a decision which has been taken exclusively for crass financial reasons and without any proper medical or scientific justification. It is a decision which may prejudice the health and, indeed, may cost the lives of ordinary Australians.

TALK.START.PARA: —Go, Senator! Nothing like going over the top at the beginning of a debate.

—This is a statement which reduces Senator Crowley to her usual giggling incompetence and simply demonstrates the extent to which she, together with members of the Australian Labor Party, hold in contempt the proper health care standards required for the people of Australia. It is a decision taken--

—I rise on a point of order, Mr Acting Deputy President. I would like the honourable senator to withdraw that remark about my contemptuous holding in regard to the claims he has just attributed to me. I do not hold them in contempt and I ask the senator to withdraw them.

—I rise on a point of order, Mr Acting Deputy President. The standing order to which the honourable senator refers is standing order 418. Nothing Senator Puplick has said in any way contravenes any provision of standing order 418.
—I think that the matter raised by Senator Crowley is really a matter of debate. Senator Crowley may be able to raise it in the debate that will ensue.

—As I said, this decision which has been taken on purely financial grounds is one which needs the attention of the Senate and which should be resolved by passage of this disallowance motion. The issue which is central to this debate is the moves which have been made by the Government to place 53 drugs on a special and restricted method of prescription-namely, the use of the Authority Only list. I seek leave to table a list of the drugs which are involved in this particular pharmaceutical declaration.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —This means that as from 1 August 1988 we are faced with a situation in which a faceless bureaucrat is placed between the doctor and the patient. Doctors will be forced to seek departmental approval before their prescription of more advanced and thus more expensive drugs are filled. The clinical decision making of doctors will be usurped by the decision that cheaper alternative drugs are suitable for certain medical conditions. The advice of specialist medical practitioners may well be ignored by the decision of the departmental bureaucrat. There will be a two-class system of pharmaceutical care, with older products being available through the PBS-the pharmaceutical benefits scheme-to pensioners and the disadvantaged while new drugs will be available to those who can afford to pay where, in fact, they are faced with a negative decision from the bureaucracy. The very pharmaceutical products that provide significant benefits to patients, reduce hospitalisation and patient procedures and improve the quality of life will be restricted by bureaucratic procedures and on the basis of capacity to pay. These changes are totally impractical. They will involve substantial increases in unproductive paperwork for doctors. I shall return to that in a moment.

SPEECH.PARA: It is anticipated that at least 1.6 million authorities in a full year will be required under this system with the potential for bureaucratic bottlenecks and delays being occasioned. In an excellent speech in the House of Representatives on 25 July, my Liberal colleague Mr Halverson, the honourable member for Casey, dealt at some length with the bottlenecks which are likely to occur as a result of this particular decision.

I turn specifically to discuss some of the drugs which are on the list of 53 drugs requiring authority. Of those 53, just seven drugs represent something like 75 per cent of the prescriptions written and 90 per cent of the cost to government. Those drugs are used primarily in the control of high blood pressure, for reducing high cholesterol levels, for regulating uneven heart beat, and for epilepsy. Without attempting to specify the generic names of the drugs concerned, I will simply indicate that these seven are the so-called ACE inhibitors, that is, the angiotensin converting enzyme inhibitors Renitec and Capoten, which are used primarily for high blood pressure, the high cholesterol control drugs Questran and Colestid, the uneven heart beat regulating drugs Cardizem and Tambocor and Epilim, a key drug used to control epilepsy.

I want to concentrate primarily on the use of ACE inhibitors and their value and importance in dealing with what in fact should be an increasingly significant part of the health care arrangements of Australians-namely, preventive health care. The State and Territory health Ministers, in April 1988, announced their intention to attack heart disease and, in particular, to take steps to attack the lifestyle conditions and the conditions which lead to the enormous degree of morbidity and mortality in Australia which is related to heart disease. The report of the task force on cardiovascular disease made to the Better Health Commission estimated that heart disease cost Australia approximately $600m in hospital and medical services and $900m to $1,400m in productivity losses in 1984 alone. If one looks at the report prepared by Paul Gross and Richard Taylor entitled the Total Economic Cost of Disease in Australia and the Contribution of Smoking, High Blood Pressure and Cholesterol, 1985-86, one will see that they estimate that more than 2.5 million years of normal healthy life are lost to Australians because of sickness, disease and premature death related to the three major avoidable factors: smoking, hypertension and high cholesterol. They contribute nearly 25 per cent of that particular loss. These particular drugs to which I am referring in terms of the ACE inhibitors are drugs which are used in the regulation of high cholesterol and in the regulation of patient care related to difficulties in managing stroke and high blood pressure.

I want to go through some of the representations which have been made dealing with the question of ACE inhibitors and the role which they play in preventive health care. A submission made by the Chairman of the High Blood Pressure Council of Australia, Mr P. I. Korner, draws attention to the fact:

That the ACE-inhibitors did not possess some of the undesirable side-effects, particularly on cholesterol and other lipids, that were a feature of many beta-blockers and diuretics, used in the treatment of hypertension.

He goes on therefore to indicate the extent to which it is believed by his Council that these particular drugs, which are certainly more expensive and certainly more up to date in terms of the management of this particular problem, are appropriate drugs to be available on a far more widespread basis, not on a restricted basis which the Government is now proposing.

Dr Robert Hodge, the Director of the National Heart Foundation, has made the point that he believes that the steps taken by the Government will indeed be entirely counterproductive in the management of these particular diseases. The clinical pharmacologist at the Monash Medical School, Professor John McNeil, has estimated that 1.4 million Australians over the age of 30 have cholesterol levels above that which is regarded as desirable and, indeed, that substantial savings could be achieved if only half of them were to be treated with one of the drugs which is currently now being made more difficult to obtain, more difficult to prescribe.

A submission by the Cardiac Society of Australia and New Zealand makes the point that one of the important things about the alternatives currently being used to manage these particular conditions, rather than the use of ACE inhibitors, in fact has been found to have such side effects as to cause people to give up taking the necessary medication. One such side effect can be male impotence. The Society says in its submission that `the high cumulative withdrawal rate of up to 40-45 per cent of patients on active treatment' in terms of using a drug other than the ACE inhibitors is one of the factors which lead it to conclude that there is:
. . . a case for less, rather than more restriction on the use of Ace-inhibitors in the management of hypertension.

They say that this would acknowledge present international opinions and the trends to current use in Australia. However, these are the drugs which the Government is determined to make more difficult and less accessible. Professor John Shaw, Professor of Clinical Pharmacology at the University of Sydney, has questioned the wisdom of this particular Government move and was reported as saying in an article which appeared in the Australian of 15 August:
The decision will make it difficult to implement governmental policy on cholesterol levels and may place some patients unnecessarily at risk of death.

This is the point which I have made. Presumably Senator Cook will tell us that his judgment and the judgment of Dr Blewett are to be preferred to the judgment of a clinical pharmacologist in this particular matter who draws our attention to the fact that this puts some patients unnecessarily at risk of death.

I turn now to the submission by Professor Barry McGrath, Associate Professor of Medicine at Monash University, in which he says that the particular drugs which the Government is now seeking to restrict:
. . . have rapidly gained a dominant role in treating these common conditions because they have significant advantages over other types of drugs.
I turn to an abstract of an article by Malcolm and others in the New Zealand Medical Journal of April 1988 in which it is indicated:
Pooled data from clinical trials show that the incidence of fatal and nonfatal strokes combined is reduced by approximately 39 per cent . . . with antihypertensive treatment . . .

This article states that the saving of this reduction to the New Zealand health budget could be as high as $1.822m. Again, these are the very drugs which this Government is determined to make much more difficult to prescribe.

In terms of comments about the views of eminent persons in the medical community on this matter, I conclude by looking at a letter sent to me by Professor Priscilla Kincaid-Smith, the Professor in the Department of Medicine at the University of Melbourne and Director of Nephrology at Royal Melbourne Hospital. She says in part:
As a consultant, I would only see these patients-
that is, patients who have had side effects from treatment by other drugs-

infrequently when a problem arises and the prescription is provided by the local practitioner. Studies have shown that Authority listing reduces the use of drugs because of the bureaucratic waste of time and effort involved in prescription of drugs restricted in this way.
I understand that the PABC-
the Pharmaceutical Benefits Advisory Committee-

considered an Authority listing for the ACE inhibitors early this year but decided, quite correctly, that such a move was not appropriate. The implementation of an Authority listing now as a government cost-cutting measure is without medical justification. In the long term it will almost certainly cause an increase in cardiovascular mortality and morbidity because of poorer control of blood pressure and poor compliance because of side effects. Authority listing for ACE inhibitors will be a serious blow to all who believe in preventive medicine.

TALK.START.PARA: —Alarmist nonsense.

—I am glad that Senator Peter Cook, this expert from the trade union movement, has put that on the record about Professor Priscilla Kincaid-Smith, one of the most significant medical authorities in this country, a world authority, a person whom this Government has appointed to numerous bodies, including, I think, the Australian Science and Technology Council on occasions and certainly a number of the most significant medical advisory bodies to which this Government can appoint any medical specialist in Australia. He takes the name of one of the most important, one of the most significant medical practitioners in this country, a person of international reputation, and accuses this professor, this eminent physician, of spreading alarmist nonsense.

SPEECH.PARA: There could be nothing more revealing of this Government's attitude than for Senator Cook, with all of his wealth of trade union experience in Western Australia, to set himself up as a superior judge of medical knowledge to one of the most world renowned, eminent physicians practising in Australia. It is absolutely typical of the arrogant, overbearing, incompetent and out of touch approach which Senator Cook, Dr Blewett and all their mates bring to the management of public health in Australia.

Their claims for restricting these drugs are capable of being refuted even on the basis of the so-called economic arguments that they want to put forward. It is a fact that over the eight years from 1977 to 1984 the number of prescriptions for cardiovascular drugs grew at an average of 7.1 per cent per annum. However, during the period from 1985 to 1987, as ACE inhibitors became available on the PBS scheme, this growth slowed dramatically to 2 per cent in 1985 and 1.4 per cent in 1986, and there was a decline of 4 per cent in 1987. So the argument that this is leading to some sort of blow-out in prescriptions and therefore a blow-out in costs is actually refuted by the facts which are available. The numbers of cardiovascular prescriptions and doctors visits have declined since the PBS listing of ACE inhibitors.

I turn now to an example of the way in which the bureaucratic nightmare has affected individual practitioners. I quote some of the cases from a letter which was sent by a specialist physician and cardiologist based at the Royal North Shore Hospital in Sydney. He gives a number of examples of what this new system-these new restrictions-means to him in a practical daily sense, including:

For Mrs A. M. two separate authority prescriptions were provided and a third prescription had to be written for her other regular medications, e.g. Adalat tablets, Zyloprim and Nicotinic Acid. This patient is a vascular cripple and her medications are totally appropriate yet I was called upon to write the patient's name and address and pensioner entitlement number three times. I had to write my own name and address and my contact phone number the same number of times.

The next patient, Mrs A. L., also a resistant hypertensive with multiple drug intolerances, needed two separate authority prescriptions for Questran sachets and Renitec and a third prescription for Aprinox and Trandate.
Then came Mrs R. W. who required an authority prescription for Enalapril, and another regular prescription for Adalat. Her third form was for a renal angiogram which is now needed.

Then came Mrs L. McN. who required an authority prescription for Captopril and another for Tenormin and Minipress. This lady has a litany of previous anti-hypertensive intolerances and has had longstanding hypertension dating back to the bad days of ganglion blockers.
Another patient, Mrs B, required an authority prescription for Plendil.

He goes on to give a whole series of examples of how he has to spend that much more of his time writing out forms for no other purpose than to satisfy the requirements of some bureaucrats, who require him to spend time putting forward an additional amount of paperwork simply to satisfy all of these requirements which the Government has now put upon him.

The Government cannot blame, as it continually does, the medical profession for the blow-out in the costs of the pharmaceutical benefits scheme. There is a whole variety of reasons why there has been a substantial increase in the cost of this scheme, including the fact that increases in costs have been granted to drug manufacturers by the Pharmaceutical Benefits Pricing Bureau. Since July 1986 the Bureau has granted increases totalling $62.7m. The fall in the value of the Australian dollar relative to other major international currencies has contributed to the increased costs of the PBS, as a high proportion of the drugs are imported, and new drugs have been listed as benefits, most of which have higher average prices than the average for existing items. In other words, the attempt of this Government permanently to blame the medical profession, permanently to victimise and vilify doctors, in the way in which Senator Walsh does at every conceivable opportunity, for the cost of the increase in PBS is simply not correct. Since 1975 the cost of pharmaceuticals has significantly reduced, from 13 per cent to 8 per cent of total health care costs.

Australia's per capita expenditure on pharmaceuticals is something like $46.84 a year, compared with $73.43 in New Zealand, $115.50 in the United States of America, $149.40 in Italy and $177.20 in West Germany. The fact is that Australian pharmaceutical drugs are cheap by international standards and the new drugs represent extremely cost effective health care alternatives to hospitalisation and surgery.

Time does not permit me to go at great length into the way in which the statements made by the Finance Minister and other economic Ministers in the Government have deliberately misrepresented the projections of additional costs which may be involved as new drugs come on to the various lists and become available. The extrapolations which Senator Walsh has attempted to put on the public record simply ignore the economic and natural history of the way in which the cost of drugs has traditionally been high for a short period of time and has then significantly fallen away. This facile extrapolation of a single year increase over a projected period of the next three years, which Senator Walsh has used to justify his claims about the cost of the pharmaceutical benefits scheme, is simply not correct. In an article by Professor John Shaw of the Department of Clinical Pharmacology of the University of Sydney, which appeared in the 15 August edition of the Medical Journal of Australia, he says:

Furthermore, the decision to add 53 drugs to the authority list is a poorly-disguised attempt to camouflage the restriction of the angiotensin converting-enzyme inhibitor agents and to forestall a further blow-out in the costs of the Pharmaceutical Benefits Scheme as the new cholesterol-lowering drugs become available.

Presumably Professor Shaw also is an alarmist and the sort of person whose word cannot be taken against the considerable medical expertise of the industrial relations officer from Western Australia who will be following me in this debate! Perhaps under those circumstances he should address his mind to Dr Neal Blewett's press release of 19 November 1985, in which he moved to take off existing lists the drugs which are now to go back on them. Dr Blewett, with a great fanfare, as we usually get from him, said:

Chronically ill patients will be the major beneficiaries of Federal Government moves to free up the availability of prescription drugs supplied under the Pharmaceutical Benefits Scheme . . . The changes will give more freedom to doctors to prescribe as they see fit . . .

The drugs which were taken off the authority only list include captopril, demeclocycline hydrochloride, fucidic acid, penicillamine and tobramycin sulphate, all of which now go back on the list. Dr Blewett took those off the list in November 1985 with a great fanfare about how it would benefit chronically ill patients and allow doctors more freedom to prescribe according to their best medical judgment, and he removed from the specific purpose list under the pharmaceutical benefits scheme three other drugs-azathioprine, chlorambucil and methrotrexate-all of which now go back on the list again. In other words, we have a series of three drugs that went off the specific purpose list onto the generally available list and we have seven drugs that went off authority only onto specific purpose, all of which now come back onto authority only. There is simply no justification for that.

We know what happened in this instance was that a meeting was demanded of the Pharmaceutical Benefits Advisory Committee at short notice and without proper background being provided. The Committee was instructed to examine all those drugs which cost more than $30 and not to decide which should go on the authority only list but to decide which drugs should not now be included on the authority only list. They made certain decisions about things like injectable insulin to help them off the list, but they were put under the hammer to put on the list as many as they could of the drugs available over the $30 mark. Dr Wal Grigor of that Committee was reported in the Sydney Morning Herald of 7 September as saying that the PBAC had been forced to make hasty decisions when the Government asked it to select drugs. He said:

We met in Canberra on the Monday before the May Statement and we did not get any warning before the meeting. . . It was the Committee's view that decisions were reached in some haste and they would all need to be looked at in the future.

Indeed they will, and they should be looked at by this motion being passed and the PBAC going back and doing the sort of job that it ought to do, not under Government pressure but on the basis of the best medical evidence. I come finally to Senator Cook's friend and colleague, Mr Keith Wilson, the Minister for Health in the Government of Western Australia. I presume he is a friend and colleague.

TALK.START.PARA: —Of course he is.
—He put an advertisement in the newspapers on 26 August which says:

SPEECH.PARA: The Commonwealth Government has decided that 53 prescription drugs will require special authority from the Commonwealth Department of Health before they may be prescribed under pharmaceutical benefits regulations. The Western Australian Government is fighting for an urgent review of the drugs on this list. Some of these drugs are crucial to the treatment of diseases such as cancer, heart disease and epilepsy-and there are no satisfactory alternatives. I am convinced that patients are suffering as a result of these changes.
Alarmist propaganda? Alarmist nonsense?

TALK.START.PARA: —He is wrong.

—No, of course he is not. This is a mate. Senator Cook cannot say things like that about mates. All he can say about mates is something quiet and orderly. He can abuse eminent medical practitioners, but he cannot abuse his Party mates in Western Australia. It will be interesting to see how many Western Australian senators cross the floor and sit on our side of the division when this motion is put, on the basis that their own State Minister for Health and Government in Western Australia has not only published this advertisement but has also set up a hot line so that people can phone up and tell everybody. In the advertisement the Minister goes on to say:

SPEECH.PARA: I have already travelled over East-
it sounds like one of the three wise men going to Bethlehem-
to meet the Commonwealth Minister, and to tell him of my total opposition to the aspects of this Federal decision that threaten the health and well-being of Western Australians.

When Senator Cook was asked by Senator Crichton-Browne on 30 August whether he was going to do anything about it, Senator Cook gave one of those rare, simple, straightforward answers: he said no. Under these circumstances one can see the degree of confusion which has been occasioned by the decision for which the Government alone bears responsibility. Philip McIntosh, writing in the Age of 8 September, said of this:

Doctors have objected that many of the drugs included on the authority list-such as Epilem for epilepsy and the anti-cancer drugs-may have no alternatives, or no suitable alternatives for many patients. The blame for this must rest largely with the Government.

We know that it does because of the way in which the PBAC was not allowed to do its job properly; was not allowed to do its job purely on the basis of medical considerations, but was simply told to examine all those pharmaceuticals costing more than $30 to see which of them it could take steps to restrict. In doing so it has picked on a number of drugs, including those which are absolutely central to the management of heart conditions, hypertension and high cholesterol, which this Government has otherwise identified as a high priority in its public health agenda. This move is to sacrifice ordinary Australians on the altar of the Government's economic ideologies and prejudices-the idea of Keating, Walsh, Blewett and Hawke to make disadvantaged Australians pick up yet more of the burden of the economic cost of their mismanagement in order to transfer the benefits to their rich and powerful mates. The sort of philosophy which underlies the whole of the policies of Mr Keating, the honourable member for Manhattan, and this Government needs radical examination. It is an absolute shame and a disgrace that $46m has been wasted on promoting four tawdry referendum questions which were totally rejected by the electors in every State when it is the poor and the sick that have to pay for it.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable senator's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam Acting Deputy President--
—This will be a beauty.

—It will indeed. Senator Knowles should sit in her place, put her seat belt on and wait. We heard from Senator Puplick a speech of sound and fury which in the end signified nothing. Perhaps if it signified anything at all it was an interesting juggling of pronunciations of the chemical names of drugs. The central fallacy in what Senator Puplick has put is that if people miss out on approval for one of these drugs they will have to pay more; they will have to pay the full market price of the drug. That is the central fallacy that he has put. It is not true. If one removes that premise from the long, windy, rhetorical argument that we have heard, the whole thing crumbles like a house of cards.

SPEECH.PARA: What is the case, what will be mentioned by the Government as the case and what is increasingly understood by the community as the case is that if a medical practitioner certifies the drug he prescribes and it is on the list that we seek to add to, that drug will be approved and will be available. If the patient is a pensioner, the drug will be free. If the patient is a low income earner or unemployed he will pay $2.50 for the dispensing of his prescription. If the patient is, like the rest of us, a full wage person, he will pay $11, unless he is a person who suffers chronic illness, in which case after 25 prescriptions have been dispensed the remainder will be free.

The central premise that it will cost more to get the medication a patient wants, even if a medical practitioner believes that that is the appropriate medication, is just not true. That point has to be emphasised as strongly as possible. It was a tawdry effort by Senator Puplick to try to blackguard me and attack the man, not the ball, when I referred to his quote from Professor Priscilla Kincaid-Smith as being alarmist nonsense. That tawdry effort can be answered simply and I answer it now before I go into the text of my speech. What Senator Puplick was quoting Professor Kincaid-Smith as saying was that people will somehow have their treatment restricted or impaired. That is alarmist nonsense. By the way, that does not reflect on Professor Kincaid-Smith's eminence in the field in which she is an expert. I do not in any way seek to judge that. But if she ventures into the field of the impact of this proposal on patients, that is a general field and her eminence in her particular field does not necessarily qualify her to participate in the argument. I am right. On behalf of the Government I do not resile at all from saying that the way in which Senator Puplick presented those quotes was alarmist nonsense.

We have before the Senate a motion for disallowance of a declaration that the Government proposes to introduce. The disallowance motion, if carried, will have a number of serious unintended consequences. It seems to me that Senator Puplick, in framing his disallowance motion, has either by design, accident or sloppiness ventured into a realm in which there are a number of impacts he has not thought through. Given the nub of his speech, it is intended to prevent the 53 drugs from being added to the list. That is what Senator Puplick said in his speech. Four other impacts will then follow. We have added three new drugs to the list. If the disallowance motion were to be carried, those three new drugs would be disbarred from the list. One of them is an important cardiovascular drug, sotalol hydrochloride. There are five drugs which are prescribed on the list in new forms or strengths. If this disallowance motion is carried, they will fall. There are 22 new items which have been deleted from the list simply because they are out of manufacture or because the technical committee has recommended their deletion because of therapeutic concerns. It is appropriate that they come out. The unthinking approach of the Opposition is not to remove them. There are eight alterations to the restrictions on usage of drugs. In the case of one of them, it is a relaxation of the conditions. In the case of some of the others it is a tightening of the conditions. The opinion of the Pharmaceutical Benefits Advisory Committee is that those alterations should be made. There are unintended consequences of mindlessly following this attempt by Senator Puplick to besmirch the Government and put money into the pockets of the big drug companies. For the record, that should be--

TALK.START.PARA: —So it is an attempt to restrict the economics of it?

—I will come to that. In ascending order of stupidity, I want to reveal what Senator Puplick's proposal would do. It is appropriate and proper for a government to be concerned about the cost of prescribed drugs. Some of these drugs cost over $1,000 each. Some of them cost much more than what the technical committee regards as adequate substitutes in some cases. Given the escalating cost of the pharmaceutical benefits scheme, it is appropriate that a government, exercising proper and prudent restraint, look at how those expenses are blowing out. Given that the public purse subsidises the cost of those drugs and the beneficiaries of that subsidy are the major pharmaceutical companies, the major drug companies, it is entirely appropriate that we exercise that sort of fiscal responsibility.

SPEECH.PARA: The disallowance motion Senator Puplick has moved is irresponsible. The way he has argued it is misleading. The political act he is perpetrating by putting forward his disallowance motion is a squalid effort at political manoeuvring, and people who are sick and in need of medication have been preyed upon by the fearmongering campaign Senator Puplick has used in developing this disallowance motion. It is a disgusting example of preying upon people who just want to be left alone to get on with their treatment. To prey upon their fears and anxieties is the most squalid and disgusting thing I have seen in this place for a considerable period, and I might say that I have seen a number of those things.

Let me return to my first point-that the motion is irresponsible. As I said, it is entirely appropriate for a government to question whether escalating costs can in some reasonable way be curbed. I do not in any sense run away from that. We hear from the Opposition, `Cut this cost. Reduce that cost. Cut here, cut there'. Why then do we not hear from the Opposition that we should exercise a bit of fiscal restraint when it comes to putting money into the pockets of large drug companies? In 1983-84 the pharmaceutical benefits scheme cost government $489m. This year it will cost over $1 billion. If it continues at that escalating level, in another two or three years it will cost in excess of $2 billion. That is a cost to taxpayers in this country. It is therefore entirely appropriate, proper and prudent for a government to say, `Is there some way in which these costs can be cushioned or reduced without affecting the entitlement of patients in need to the drugs they require, if that is the opinion of the medical practitioner?'.

TALK.START.PARA: —You could have had $46m extra without your tawdry referendums.
—Why not answer the question? You could have had $46m.

—That is an irrelevant statement and the honourable senator knows it. When we look at the costs and ask ourselves the question, `Is there some prudent and proper way of doing it without in any way restricting the entitlement of people to that medication?', we find that there is. We use a scheme which has operated for 34 years and has already had some 40-odd drugs listed and we include 53 more. How do we get these drugs onto the scheme? We, as a government, do not choose them. The secretariat of the Pharmaceutical Benefits Advisory Committee puts up a list of some 89 drugs. The technical committee then examines those drugs to see whether, in many cases, there are appropriate cheaper alternatives. It then selects 53 and proposes that they go on to the list. Is Senator Puplick saying that the Committee's technical judgment is improper and that there are no appropriate substitutes? Of course he is not, and if he were saying it he would not have the competence to make the allegation.

SPEECH.PARA: Why would a government not be mindful of the fact that the business of pharmaceutical companies is to go around to doctors' surgeries and promote their drugs, saying, `Use our drug. Get a free computer'? In one case a pharmaceutical company trying to sell a drug to stop diarrhoea advertised, `Use our drug. Write as many prescriptions as you can for our drug and get a free trip to Seoul for the Olympic Games'. Why would a government which is paying the cost of those drugs not say, `We ought to look at this problem. We ought to see whether there is a cheaper alternative.'? We ought to provide for doctors an alternative line of argument, of interest, of analysis, of concern, so that the advice they get on the drugs they prescribe is appropriate. We do not in any way resile from the fact that we want to make savings to the public purse, which we estimate will be about $17m this year and $42m in a full year. That will be money that does not go to drug companies. That will be money which could be used for tax cuts, to improve the health system generally, to improve our education and welfare standards, or to improve other expenditures from the public purse. We do not resile from a prudent and proper exercise of that type of restraint.

I turn to the next aspect-the misleading statements which have come out of this campaign, the big lie approach of saying that all the people out there will be ruined and their access restricted. I have dealt with that in my opening remarks to Senator Puplick. There is absolutely no need for people to go around hoarding, stockpiling or panicking because of this measure. If the drugs are necessary they will be authorised by doctors in the appropriate way and will then be dispensed. In an emergency this can be done by telephone to cut out the red tape. There is proper and adequate cover for emergency situations. In terms of the authorisation, even the cost of the postage stamp is provided free of charge by the Commonwealth. I believe that the turnaround time in doctors getting approval is between 24 and 48 hours. It is not an onerous situation. It does involve some extra work by doctors. If the protest is about the fact that doctors have to write between five and 10 words more two or three times a week on average, it is a terribly pathetic sort of protest, and I will deal with it later.

The Government is concerned not only about making the savings, but also about empowering the community to be better consumers of medication, as well as about encouraging doctors and pharmacists to be better able to discharge their responsibilities. As Senator Puplick would know, shortly the Minister will announce a $2m a year campaign, which will be run for the purpose of educating doctors so that when they are pressured in their consulting rooms by drug companies telling them to take their latest product, they are better able to make independent, impartial and objective assessments of the properties of the drugs that are being put to them.

Also, pharmacists, who are great providers of advice solicited by consumers of drugs, will be better able to discharge their responsibilities and to offer advice. Further, the consumers of drugs, the pensioner organisations, the heart groups, and all the other organisations which represent people who consume medication, can be advised more professionally, more fully and more adequately about the appropriate and proper ways of operating within the system, of following through on matters pertaining to medication, as well as doing all the other things necessary to ensure that a treatment cures an illness.

This proposition involves a two-pronged perspective. First, it is necessary to do the immediate things that are necessary to keep costs under control, so that there is more money in the system to spend usefully and intelligently in other ways on health care. Secondly, we want a longer range program of education which ensures that we do not abuse the system, as has occurred in the past. That is an intelligent response on the part of this Government. Any education of the community in drug use and any education of medical professionals and offer of peer group advice to medical professionals is a useful and proper thing. It is an obligation of a government that is concerned about a proper health care system-and that is what we are doing.

I now refer to the third area that I mentioned previously-and by its very nature this is contemptible. People who are ill simply want to be left alone to get on with their treatment. They do not want to hear speeches of the sort made by Senator Puplick this morning, preying on their anxieties and fears, that somehow they will be worse off. I know that it is a stratagem of oppositions to attack governments by inducing the big lie or the big fear campaign. However, let us get the facts right. The central premise is that if doctors prescribe a drug it will be dispensed, whether or not it is on this list. If that is the case, then people will get the medication that they want. Anyone whose fear or anxiety level has been raised due to the sorts of speeches that have been made and the sorts of irresponsible comments that I have seen in the Press can relax, can sit back and pursue their treatment in such a way as to make recovery possible. It is a most base and contemptible manoeuvre to try to use the ill and those in need of medication as some form of political football-as we have seen in this campaign.

I now refer to the issue that has been raised about doctors. It has been said that doctors may be required to do some extra work. Indeed, I have a Press clipping here from the Daily Telegraph of 21 July, in which Dr Shepherd of the Australian Medical Association (AMA) is quoted as saying:

I have seen it happen on enough occasions for it to concern me. The patient will have to wait for the doctor to find time to fill in the form, and if he has 30 or so patients waiting he is not going to sit down straightaway and do it.

We are talking here of a doctor writing on a form, on average, between five and 10 extra words, two or three times a week. That is what we are talking about, but a complaint has been made by the Australian Medical Association that that is too onerous. Indeed, the headline to the article in the Daily Telegraph stated ` ``Lazy'' doctors, skip proper drug scripts'. I am not a doctor basher where doctors conduct themselves appropriately. I am prepared to attack the AMA when it operates on the basis of the sort of comment that Dr Shepherd has made.

I want to make one comparison about the attitude of the AMA on this issue. All wage and salary earners in Australia have had wages fixed by the Australian Conciliation and Arbitration Commission this year and last year in a way in which they are required to enter into negotiations for productivity improvements in order to get wage increases. At this point we see a claim from the AMA to alter the basis on which fees are charged from a time basis to what it describes as a quality charge basis. This matter is still to be determined. It is a matter to which initially the Government responded in a positive way. But doctors want their wages changed, just like every other wage and salary earner in Australia. The doctors, though, do not have any productivity trade-off. All we are saying is that for writing between five and 10 extra words, on average, two or three times a week they can take advantage of this system. That is a reasonable productivity trade-off, by any stretch of the imagination, and involves much less than other wage and salary earners in Australia would make.

In any case, are not doctors-and I believe that they are, because many of them tell me so, and I respect their views-also responsible for the costs of the Australian health system? This is a question not about Medicare but about where we can legitimately save funds for deployment elsewhere in the medical process. Doctors are appropriately concerned about that, and some doctors are prepared to stand up and say so. Indeed, as reported in the Newcastle Herald of 9 August 1988, doctors in the Hunter Medical Association, a doctors group, have said that they reject the call from the AMA for a boycott. So, some doctors are prepared to stand up and resist the blandishments of the AMA in this matter. It is not only those doctors; in a recent press release referring to these matters, the President of the Doctors Reform Society, Dr Judy Edwards, of Western Australia, also supported the Government's position on this matter. Indeed, the press release from the Doctors Reform Society makes interesting copy. It stated:

The National President of the Doctors' Reform Society, Dr Judy Edwards, today condemned doctors who are refusing to adhere to new, simple Government regulations on prescribing certain expensive drugs.
She cited the case in Albany, Western Australia, where a GP is refusing to use the correct form to prescribe Epilim (a drug for epilepsy) for a 4 year old girl.
`This action puts a child at risk, and will cause an unnecessary financial burden on this family' said Dr Edwards.
`The AMA's recommendation that doctors refuse to use the authority prescription forms puts politics before patients' Dr Edwards said.
`Patients should not be used as pawns in political games' she added.
`The Doctors' Reform Society believes that the new Government policy has a sound economic basis.'
`It will encourage doctors to think twice about prescribing expensive drugs when a cheaper alternative may be as effective' Dr Edwards said.
So, some doctors are prepared to come forward and say that responsibility and concern about the ever-escalating costs of drugs should be properly expressed and properly dealt with.

TALK.START.PARA: —You can do something about that whenever you want to.

—Well, we are doing something about it and the honourable senator is obstructing it; perhaps she will cross the floor and vote with us. However, it is not only doctors who have a right to speak on matters medical. People who are the consumers of medical attention, too, have a perfect right to refer to these matters.

SPEECH.PARA: On 3 August, the Australian Pensioners Federation came out strongly in support of what the Government is doing, in a press release headed `Doctors gambling with pensioners' health'. In the interests of protecting Australian pensioners, the press release went on to support the Government, to oppose the AMA's call for a boycott, and to argue that, indeed, in some cases doctors are taking actions privately which are prejudicial to the health of pensioners. Indeed, it has been reported to me that recently a doctor in Newcastle signed the form and asked the patient to go down to Sydney and present it to the Department there. That is not necessary. That is a requirement the doctor has put on the patient which I believe is a quite disgusting requirement. It is a requirement which extends well beyond what is, in these circumstances, appropriate and reasonable and it ought properly to be condemned. That is the sort of silly thing we get when a campaign as mindless as this one is launched, when a campaign as silly as this one is proposed by the AMA and, to its eternal condemnation, supported by the Opposition.

I think it is appropriate for me to put on the record what in fact the procedures are. The fundamental point, which the Opposition is unable to answer, is the premise Senator Puplick got wrong. What has happened is this: the Government, aware of the ever-escalating costs of pharmaceuticals under the pharmaceutical benefits scheme-costs, as I say, at $1 billion this year, rising on a steep ramp over the next three years to $2 billion-considered that in the interests of proper and judicious use of public expenditure there ought to be a review. The secretariat of the Pharmaceutical Benefits Advisory Committee proposed some 89 drugs for review. That Committee, which is made up of nominees of the AMA, pharmacists and a pharmacologist, made a recommendation that in 53 of the proposed 89 cases some patients could be prescribed alternative drugs which were much cheaper. The drugs we are talking about range in cost from over $1,000 each to $30 each. The sorts of substitutes that in some cases are available as alternatives range in cost between $10 and $20. In those circumstances, the appropriate decision was made.

In order to guarantee the access of patients, the Government proposed that a doctor should write on a very simple form that in the particular circumstances of a patient's disease a drug on the list we are proposing is appropriate. If a doctor signs that form and posts it off, at a cost to the Commonwealth and not to himself, within 24 to 48 hours it will be returned approved and will be able to be presented for dispensing. If there is an emergency and it is necessary to deal with things quickly, as sometimes happens, all the doctor has to do is phone through and get approval or, alternatively, ask the patient to take the two cover sheets to the pharmacy, have the prescription dispensed, and obtain approval later. So there will be no delay in the case of emergencies. In the case of routine dispensing there is a minimal delay, which in the circumstances is appropriate. As I have said, between five and 10 extra words have been put on the form. In those circumstances, this sort of disallowance motion should be defeated. The campaign I have talked of is a campaign that should be rejected. The sort of comfort doctors say they want simply because they have to do a little bit of work to save expenditure of millions of dollars from the public purse is contemptible.

I want to turn to a number of other things. Senator Puplick asked me whether the Minister for Health in Western Australia, the Hon. Keith Wilson, is a friend of mine. Of course he is. He and I enjoy the privilege of being serving members of parliament, elected by our constituents, in Labor governments. That does not mean that the Hon. Keith Wilson gets it right every time; nor does it mean that I do. At least in my case I am prepared to admit that I am wrong. On this occasion I am right. It is appropriate for me to say that on this occasion the Western Australian Health Minister is wrong. He made a decision to lend his name to the campaign. He obviously had his reasons for doing so, but that does not alter the fact that he is wrong. I do not accept the things he has said. In fact, I positively reject them.

The second and maybe concluding point I should make is to pose this question: what do these four people-Jim Carlton, James Porter, Michael Baume and Wilson Tuckey-have in common? All of them are former shadow Ministers for health. All of them opposed Dr Neal Blewett, the Minister for Community Services and Health in this Government, who has held that portfolio consistently for the last five years. All of them had to be shifted because none of them was making inroads in terms of health policy in Australia. Do we have a viable Opposition pressing the Government in regard to health policy? No, we do not. Do we have a cohesive set of policies from the Opposition about where it stands on health? No, we do not. Have we had attempts by the Opposition to fashion alternative health policies? Yes, we have. We had one in the last election campaign. As I recall, Senator Michael Baume, who proposed it, could not quite add up. He got all his sums wrong and therefore the health policy fell down.

TALK.START.PARA: —Now he is on the back bench.

—As Senator McKiernan says, he is now on the back bench. He was promoted backwards because he was a failure as an Opposition spokesman. We have had an attempt to get a policy, but the policy recommendations presented at Thredbo were all kicked out.

SPEECH.PARA: What do we have from the Opposition in terms of alternative health policies? We have four faces who tried to oppose Neal Blewett, all of whom had to be shifted. I would not barrack for Peter Shack for very long because he too may soon have to go. We had a failure to get the facts right during the last election campaign. There is still an inability on the part of the Opposition to bring forward, some 18 months or so into this term, a comprehensive health policy that the Australian people can look at and on which they can make a judgment as to which of the two sides of politics are on the right track. Perhaps one of the reasons why the Opposition is finding it so difficult to bring forward an alternative health policy is that it knows that, while people will criticise Medicare, basically Medicare as a health policy is wholeheartedly supported by most Australians. Like all big systems, there are criticisms of how Medicare operates. This Government is sensitive to those criticisms and seeks to modify and improve as we go along. Let me conclude by saying--

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The Minister's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Coulter Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —This morning we are discussing whether 53 drugs on the pharmaceutical benefits scheme (PBS) list should be placed on the general list or the restricted list. The Government is seeking to shift those 53 drugs from the general list to the restricted list and that move has been opposed by the Opposition. We are now debating the motion for disallowance. The Australian Democrats will be supporting the Government, not the Opposition, in regard to the disallowance. We concede that the Government, the Opposition and the Democrats are generally in agreement in regard to the data on which the move is based. That is what makes this subject a rather difficult one.

SPEECH.PARA: I think one should begin by reasserting something Senator Cook has just said. It was distressing for me to hear Senator Puplick again imply something which was not true. I think it bears repeating that these drugs are not being made unavailable. The drugs will still be available although they are being moved from the general list to the restricted list. What is required is that the doctor assert that a particular drug is the most suitable drug for a particular patient. As Senator Cook has indicated, either a telephone call or an extra prescription form will be required for that assertion.

As I understand it, the intention of the Government is to bring to the attention of doctors the fact that there are some drugs on the list which are very expensive and to cause them to think twice before they prescribe a more expensive drug. Clearly, the Government wants doctors to prescribe a cheaper drug if it is available. The costs of medical treatment are rising in every area, not least in the area of pharmaceuticals. I alluded to that yesterday when we discussed the report Australian Medical Education and Workforce into the 21st Century. A number of new treatments, which are extremely expensive, are becoming available. I believe that the time has long since past when, as a community, we should be deciding how much we want to spend on very expensive forms of pharmaceutical treatment such as heart transplants and the IVF program. We need to relate those costs to costs elsewhere in the community. How much more benefit does the community get by making more or cheaper places available in kindergartens compared with how much we spend on these very expensive forms of treatment? That is a question which the Government, the Opposition and people in the community do not seem to be addressing seriously. It must be addressed by both the medical profession and the community at large.

The present costs of the pharmaceutical benefits scheme, as Senator Cook has indicated, are running at roughly $1 billion-$1,000m-a year. Last year the cost rose by 27 per cent. The average increase over recent years has been about 20 per cent per year. If the Government were minded to come up with a core list of drugs, which Professor Shaw has mentioned-Senator Puplick referred in his speech to Professor Shaw-it might cost about $100m a year. The Government might look at that. Recently, as has been indicated, a number of new drugs for the treatment of hypertension-the so-called ACE inhibitors-have become available. It is clear that they have advantages over various earlier treatments but, in general, they are very expensive drugs. A new drug for the lowering of blood cholesterol has appeared recently-the drug cholestyramine.

TALK.START.PARA: —Not recently. They were using it 20 years ago, Senator.

—It is estimated that this will cost $336,000 for each fatal and non-fatal heart attack; that is, if one were to use this as a preventative treatment of raised blood cholesterol in an attempt to put off the possible and eventual development of a heart attack. One should look seriously at that cost, bearing in mind that raised blood cholesterol is substantially a self-inflicted condition, aided and abetted by unrestrained tax deductable advertising promoting whatever is profitable and bad for health.
—What about genetic components?
—Certainly genetic components are involved, but there is a substantial component of self-infliction. I do not want to imply in any sense that I am blaming the victim here.
—It is self-inflicted, but I don't blame you!

—As I have indicated, the victim is also a victim of massive advertising by a number of companies which are supported by the honourable Senator's Party. When I attempted to interfere with that promotion process with respect to tobacco, the honourable senator chose to vote with the Government against attempting to inhibit that form of advertising. We must ask how both public and private funds should be spent to achieve the greatest overall benefit. Somewhere in that equation the very large amounts which are being spent on the treatment of one patient must be weighed against the needs elsewhere in the community; that is, in both the medical and non-medical areas. I believe that the Government is attempting to do that. It is appropriate for the Government to attempt to restrain costs, as Senator Cook has indicated, and I think that everybody is agreed on that. The argument appears to be over whether this is the most appropriate way, in the area of pharmaceuticals, to achieve this cost reduction and whether, if this disallowance motion is unsuccessful, it will be effective.

SPEECH.PARA: The pharmaceutical benefits scheme has grown like Topsy. It has been in existence for some 44 years. In that time the core list of drugs has been added to and other drugs have been abstracted so we now have a hotchpotch list of drugs. The pharmaceutical benefits scheme requires a thorough review. One possible alternative to which I have already alluded is the construction of a core list of essential drugs-something which has been done in other countries-comprising some 150 to 200 drugs, which may cost this country about $100m a year. Of course, that implies that many of these very expensive drugs would be available only if a patient was able to pay or if a safety net was put under patients who were not able to pay. At the moment, the pharmaceutical benefits list contains some 420 drugs. The PBS certainly requires urgent and thorough review. I make the plea now that the Government get on with this, irrespective of whether the disallowance motion is carried.

It is true that the Government simply drew a line at $30 across the list of drugs and said that all drugs above that amount would be reviewed and, if possible, put on a restricted list. Criticism has been made of that, but I would strongly contend that that was the appropriate thing for the Government to do. It would have been quite inappropriate for the Government to have interfered in any way with the professional judgment which should guide a doctor with respect to the prescribing of drugs for his or her patients. In view of the Government's intention to simply limit costs, it was very appropriate that the Government look at costs only and not costs in relation to interference with that professional judgment.

Senator Puplick also indicated that in 1985 some drugs were shifted from the authority list to the general list and that some of those drugs are being shifted back onto the authority list. Evidence shows that, following that shift, the number of prescriptions for those drugs that were shifted onto the general list from the authority list increased. One can draw only two conclusions from this. One must either impugn the professional integrity of doctors and assume that doctors were prescribing drugs which were inappropriate for their patients or, before the shift, were failing to prescribe drugs which were the most appropriate drugs for their patients, or believe that, after the drugs were shifted from the authority list to the general list, doctors were being lax in their prescription of drugs and were prescribing expensive drugs when cheaper drugs which were available on that list would have served the purpose equally well. I would choose to believe that doctors were not being in any way professionally incompetent or lacking in integrity. I would choose to believe that it was simply laxity on the part of doctors and that, when the drugs came onto the general list, the number of prescriptions went up simply because doctors were not being as careful about the costs of their prescribing habits as they were before.

It would follow from that that moving 53 drugs from the general list to the authority list is likely to lead to a reduction in the prescribing of those drugs simply because doctors will become aware of the costs of those drugs-and that is the Government's intention. However, that may not be the case because, as has been indicated, many of these drugs have interesting and peculiar properties which are not shared by some other available drugs. It may be that the prescribing of some of these more expensive drugs may not only not decrease but actually increase for those reasons. So the Government's move may be counterproductive.

One could envisage a situation in which, if the number of prescriptions for these 53 drugs did not decrease, or if it increased, the cost of the Government's initiative would increase the cost of the pharmaceutical benefits scheme rather than decrease it. The same number of or an increased number of prescriptions would be written and, added on to the cost of the prescriptions themselves, one would then have the costs of the bureaucracy which was set up to look after a telephone 24 hours a day seven days a week and to deal with the large amount of paperwork. If that occurs, it will be an even stronger incentive driving the Government to look to better ways of dealing with a thorough review of the pharmaceutical benefits scheme which, as I indicated earlier, I believe needs to be carried out.

One thing that concerns me greatly in this area is the way in which a number of drug companies very heavily promote the use of drugs. In a free enterprise system this is entirely to be expected. The development of new drugs is an expensive operation in terms of research and development, and a company that comes out with a new and effective drug is very keen to recoup development costs as quickly as possible. But it is not fair to say that that market driven mechanism necessarily serves the best interests of patients, because although new drugs may be marginally more effective, they may well be excessively more expensive than older drugs which may be almost as effective.
