The older drugs which are no longer under patent, some of which may be extremely cheap, are not likely to be promoted, whereas the very expensive drugs are indeed likely to be promoted. That will totally distort the perception of the efficacy of these drugs by doctors and the prescribing habits of doctors.

Having been in general practice, I am well aware of the intense pressure under which doctors come from medical retailers, who strongly promote the benefits of their latest drugs but very rarely speak about the costs if the costs are very high, and very rarely speak about the side effects and the dangers associated with drug treatment. I will give several examples, dealing particularly with the ACE inhibitors which are very much a subject of this debate. Several of the drug companies-notably E. R. Squibb and Sons Pty Ltd on the one hand and Merck Sharp and Dohme on the other-have spent very large sums of money promoting ACE inhibitors to doctors.

Squibb, I believe, supplied a computer worth about $1,000 to approximately 1,000 doctors around Australia, provided those doctors put 20 or more patients on that company's brand of ACE inhibitor. Squibb has defended this action by saying that these computers were linked through a modem to a central computer and that through this mechanism doctors were able to enter details of the patients who were put on the ACE inhibitors. Squibb said that information was collated on a central computer and that, through that, it was able to make an assessment of the efficacy of its drug treatment.

This, of course, is an entirely fallacious defence. The proper way of conducting a drug trial is through a process called a double blind trial in which patients are arbitrarily-the arbitrariness is the point at issue-allocated to treatment and non-treatment groups and the results of that treatment are independently assessed by somebody who is quite unaware to which treatment group the patient belonged. To believe that one could carry out a successful, reliable and meaningful trial of a drug by selecting patients on the basis that their doctor was prepared to put 20 or more patients on a particular ACE inhibitor because that doctor would then get a computer worth $1,000 is complete nonsense. The value of any study carried out in this way is seriously to be questioned.

I believe that Merck Sharp and Dohme provided a dinner at Sheraton hotels to doctors all over Australia and that these hotels were connected through a national television hook-up. Doctors were then exposed to information promoting the use of ACE inhibitors. Clearly, the very high costs of promoting drugs to doctors must be borne somewhere. In this case, if the drugs are on the pharmaceutical benefits scheme, costs are borne indirectly by all taxpayers. That is something which needs seriously to be questioned.

A little further down the track, a number of drug treatments shortly to be introduced will be even more expensive. The successful genetic engineering company Genentech has developed a drug called TPA which it has already launched on the American market for the treatment of heart attack victims. Each TPA treatment costs $2,200. In the first four months of registration in the United States of America, Genentech notched up TPA sales to the tune of $93m. Approximately 100,000 Australians suffer heart attacks each year. A quarter of them are unaware that they have had an attack, a quarter drop dead, and the remaining 50,000 could be helped by TPA. It does not require very much mathematics to multiply 50,000 by $2,200 per treatment-and these treatments would go on for some months-and to work out that this cost, if borne under the PBS without some restriction, would be quite intolerable.

At about the same time that TPA became available, the drug streptokinase was also brought into use in the United States. The latter drug costs only $200 per treatment, and it has been shown to drop the mortality rate from heart attacks, if given within four hours of an attack, by as much as 37 per cent. Interestingly, in a massive double blind study carried out in England, it was shown that half an aspirin tablet a day for five weeks following a heart attack reduced the mortality rate by as much as 21 per cent, reduced the incidence of second heart attacks and cut the incidence of strokes by 30 per cent. The point I want to make is quite simply this: Who today is going to promote the use of aspirin compared with the very expensive alternative drugs when the companies concerned have spent vast amounts of money and hundreds of millions of dollars developing these drugs? I venture to suggest that the drug companies will heavily promote the more expensive treatment and that nobody will promote a drug such as aspirin, which is out of patent, very cheap and not particularly profitable to anybody.

It is estimated that Genentech, for instance, invested $220m in the development of TPA, so it has a very strong incentive to continue the promotion of this drug. Interestingly, despite the availability of a cheaper treatment and the lack of any evidence that TPA is better than streptokinase, the prescribing of TPA is outstripping that of streptokinase by 2 : 1 in the United States. So the evidence is clear that this form of promotion can shift prescribing from equally effective but cheaper treatment to much more expensive treatment-roughly 10 times the cost-which is, as I have indicated, no more effective. It is predicted that TPA will become the first $1 billion drug in the United States. Interestingly, already the medicare system in the United States is having serious thoughts about whether the drug TPA should remain on the medicare list.

One other factor which has caused great concern about the promotion by drug companies is the way in which they have sought registration of drugs which have serious side effects and long-term consequences associated with them. In some cases companies have been successful in getting those drugs registered. They have promoted those drugs very heavily and have failed to properly inform doctors of the risks associated with the use of those drugs. In my previous laboratory undertaking I did a large amount of work on a whole class of drugs, the so-called five nitro imidazole drugs of which metronidazole, or the common name flagyl, is an example. This drug was first registered by the drug company G. D. Searle and Co. in the United States in 1953. Evidence which eventually came to light indicated that Searle, suppressed a great deal of evidence in relation to the cancer causing potential of that drug. In fact, investigations were made into the studies which Searle carried out. These indicated that a great amount of the animal experimentation work was simply fabricated. Subsequent inquiries have indicated that the practice is not unusual; it is not an isolated example. It is well established that a number of drugs in class are mutagenic, that is, capable of causing increased abortion rates and birth defects. A number of them have been shown to cause cancer and yet these drugs are still widely promoted on the Australian and overseas markets. The indications of these very damaging long term side effects, if mentioned at all, are mentioned in small print somewhere in a very obscure part of the publicity which these drugs get and which is provided to doctors through the heavy promotion which goes on in doctors' surgeries.

I have written to the Minister for Housing and Aged Care, Mr Staples, on the matter of the rising costs of drug treatment and indicated several alternative ways in which he might address this problem. I believe it would be useful in the little blue book which doctors use for prescription purposes if drugs were listed, as well as in alphabetical order, according to diagnosis so that doctors would have immediately available to them all the alternative treatments with their costs side by side. If cheaper drugs were available they could be more easily identified and prescribed. I also indicated that I thought it would be useful if the cost of a drug were printed on the bottle when the drug was given to the patient. The reason for this is that there is considerable evidence of misuse of drugs at the patient end. Many patients literally have cupboards full of drugs many of which are often wasted. Some find their way into the hands of children from time to time with quite disastrous consequences. Both doctors and patients would thus be made aware of the cost of drugs by the cost of the prescription being visible on the label on the bottle.

I have some concerns with one drug on the list, the drug epilim. Mr Staples has given an undertaking that that particular drug will be looked at. The reasons for that are peculiar to epilim. There are circumstances in which a patient suffering from epilepsy, who has been stabilised on epilim over a long period, allows himself or herself inadvertently to run out of the drug. That person then approaches a doctor who, for whatever reason, refuses to provide this drug on an authority prescription. That patient may then be at risk of having an epileptic seizure which could put that patient's treatment back some time. Although the scenario is an extreme and unlikely one there is a case for putting epilim back on the general list. That suggestion has been made to Mr Staples and I believe it is being looked at.

In summary, we will be voting with the Government on this motion, although I have indicated that the area is a difficult one. It is one in which neither approach is entirely satisfactory. We are seeing rapidly escalating costs of medical treatment, only part of which is in the pharmaceutical area. It is something which must be tackled in a much broader way. The pharmaceutical benefits scheme desperately requires a thorough review. It must be carried out in a public way because we are dealing with a very sensitive area-the area of people's health. As a community we must come to a decision about the level of health care we are prepared to support. I emphasise that because in dealing with pharmaceuticals we are really talking about sickness care rather than health care. What level of health care at what cost should we have as a community? I believe that out of such a review we would discover that a great deal more emphasis would be placed on preventive actions by people. The modification of diet would be a far more cost effective way of controlling cholesterol than by using the drug cholestyramine. I am pleased to see that the Australian Broadcasting Corporation is putting on The Body Show which promotes positive health through exercise and the cutting down of salt in our diet. I am disturbed to taste the large amount of salt in the food in the parliamentary canteen. I think we should be doing something about that. All these things would be a lot more cost effective than attempting to treat people after they become ill. Given that, and recognising that this move by the Government may not be effective, nonetheless we will be supporting the Government's motion.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Patterson Sen K.C.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —In this debate we are discussing the Government's decision to add 53 drugs to the list of drugs which require written authority from the relevant State manager of the Commonwealth Department of Community Services and Health before they can be dispensed with the attached Government subsidies. In 1985 the Minister for Health, Dr Blewett, announced a number of significant changes to current prescribing restrictions. He said:

SPEECH.PARA: The changes will give more freedom to doctors to prescribe as they see fit.

Seventeen drugs were taken off the authority only list and reclassified as specific purpose drugs. Dr Blewett said that this was a much needed change which would modify the complexity of the approval system and also reduce delays in prescribing which could sometimes adversely affect patients. Six drugs restricted as specified purpose were to have the current restriction removed. Dr Blewett said that the six would be re-listed as unrestricted items, with a saving in administrative time for both doctors and pharmacists. The Minister went on to say that the changes would be of benefit to everybody concerned-patients, doctors and pharmacists-and were in line with the Government's general move towards deregulation.

Senator Puplick has pointed out that a number of those drugs that went off the list in 1985 have now reappeared on the hit list in 1988. Why? What has led the Government to this turnaround? There was a cost blow-out in 1986-87 when the Government's contributions to the pharmaceutical benefits scheme increased from $596.6m in 1985-86 to $714.5m. This is not attributable to an increase in the number of prescriptions because in that time the number of prescriptions has decreased from 119.8 million to 102.8 million. As doctors will know-and as many of us who have had experience in the health field will know-the aetiology of a disease is not always unifactorial. It is often multifactorial. The aetiology of the spiralling cost of pharmaceutical benefits services is not unifactorial as the Government would have us believe. It is telling us that it is basically the fault of the doctors, blinded by the glossy advertising, failing to think twice before they prescribe costly drugs. As with many diseases the causes of the spiralling costs are multifactorial.

The increased costs of the reduced number of prescriptions in 1986-87 as compared with 1985-86 are due to a number of factors. Not all of these have been discussed in the debate today. In 1986-87 there was an increase in the price of drugs. There was the adverse movement in the exchange rate. We know only too well how that affected not only drug costs but also many other costs. There was the listing of new and more expensive drugs. It has been pointed out to many of us that the pattern of usage of these drugs increases after their introduction and then plateaus out. That has been the history of the use of new drugs for a very long time. There have been changes in prescribing habits so that new expensive drugs replace older ones. I have not seen anywhere in the economies of health an evaluation of the value of these newer drugs as to whether they are more cost-effective in the long run, whether they have fewer side effects and whether, in fact, the reduced number of medications that patients have to take means that we reduce the number of adverse drug interactions and whether we increase patient compliance. Nowhere has the Government argued or told us that the more expensive drugs are, in fact, not cost-beneficial.

There are also long term causes of the increase in the cost of pharmaceutical benefits services. I refer to the issues and problems associated with the patent life of drugs. Also, as Senator Coulter pointed out, there is the problem of patient compliance. A report by the Health Economics and Technology Assessment Corporation indicated that a significant proportion of the cost of pharmaceutical benefits services results from wastage by people not complying accurately with the instructions for the drugs prescribed for them. This may be a problem of public health education. It may also be a problem of how pharmacists distribute drugs. There has been an improvement in recent years because pharmacists now instruct patients much more clearly on the use of their drugs. It also may be that medical education is required to ensure that patients are more adequately told about how they should take the drugs. In typical haste, the Government has used a bandaid approach. Mr Staples, in announcing the new pharmaceutical arrangements, said:
We are simply prompting doctors to think twice before prescribing expensive drugs where there are possible cheaper alternatives.

He said that the Government took full account of the advice of the Pharmaceutical Benefits Advisory Committee. This advice that the Government sought from the Pharmaceutical Benefits Advisory Committee has been criticised on a number of counts. The basis for the inclusion of drugs on the authority list, which was the identification of drugs which cost more than a certain amount per month, did not include an assessment of the efficacy or the cost-effectiveness of the drugs. Also it has been claimed that the decision was made with undue haste. I do not want to rely on the press but in the Age of 8 September Philip McIntosh said in regard to the placing of the 53 drugs on the list:

The blame for this must rest largely with the Government. Shortly before the May economic statement, the Health Minister, Dr Blewett, called an extraordinary meeting of the Pharmaceutical Benefits Advisory Committee in Canberra. Without prior briefing, the nine members of the Committee were met by Dr Blewett and the Finance Minister, Senator Walsh, and were told that the Government had decided to put all PBS drugs costing more than $30 on the Authority list.

The Committee was asked to advise if there were any drugs that should be excluded because they did not have a cheaper alternative at least for some patients. In the next few hours the Committee had to apply this test to all 53 drugs. Some of the members now concede that they made mistakes. However, the Committee did not include representatives of every medical specialty, including oncology, and it did not have time to seek wider expert opinion.

How true that is I do not know but it makes one wonder how much consultation went on in deciding which of these drugs would go on the hit list. This is a typical Labor knee-jerk response to spiralling pharmaceutical benefits service costs.

None of the groups protesting about the drugs is saying that costs should not be contained. Nor is the coalition saying that costs should not be contained. What is being questioned is the Government's preferred treatment of the disease of spiralling PBS costs-the preferred treatment of getting doctors to think twice. What happens if, having thought twice, doctors decide to prescribe the more efficacious drugs on the authority list? If there is no change in doctors' prescribing behaviour, what will be the outcome? There will be a typical Labor Government outcome of increased bureaucratic interference, increased intrusion into patient-doctor relationships and increased administrative costs. Nowhere has the Government costed the economics of its actions. What will be the relative cost of processing each authority to prescribe application versus the average cost of the issue of drugs on the Government hit list?

The community, the coalition and the health professions will need to be convinced that the economies are such that they warrant the current action. Some people have estimated that on average it will cost $100 to process each authority to prescribe application compared with an average of $50 per issue of the drugs on the hit list. How many more pharmacists and clerical support staff will be required to process the increased number of authorities? Some have estimated these to be in the realm of 1 1/2 million additional authorities this year. We do not need a quick-fix, bandaid approach. What is needed is a major overhaul of the pharmaceutical benefits scheme. Currently, we have a one step forward, two steps backward approach. In 1985 some drugs were taken off the authority list. In 1988 some of those drugs were placed back on the authority list.

The whole pharmaceutical industry should be reconsidered. The Pharmacy Guild of Australia is quite concerned about the decision to grant an increase in the number of prescriptions available on the basis of one consultation and one visit to a pharmacist. The Government has retracted on some of that. Doctors argued that there would be insufficient monitoring of patients' condition and that there was a likelihood of problems associated with the prescription of, for example, eyedrops when patients could get two drugs dispensed on the one script instead of one. It was argued that both drugs could be opened, thus being subjected to bacterial infection, and also that patients were at risk of toxicity in being provided with both these drugs. The Government has responded to the concern expressed by the medical profession. Some of these drugs which can be prescribed two for the price of one have been taken off the list. Again, it is a typical example of this Government's rushing in to try to solve the immediate economic problem without addressing the long term implications.

In supporting this disallowance motion I ask the Government to apply the appropriate treatment rather than applying bandaids to the pharmaceutical benefits scheme. How Senator Coulter can vote with the Government on this when he admits that what is really needed is an overhaul of this system, I do not know. What I am asking for is a total review and a major reform of the pharmaceutical benefits scheme. Ways must be found to contain the cost of drugs, but this short term, quick-fix approach is not necessarily the answer.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —(New South Wales) (12.33)-The Senate is being asked to disallow a Government instrument altering the prescribing status of 53 drugs. The disallowance motion is important. If the Senate were to disallow the instrument, the status quo ante would apply. The Government would then have to go back and re-examine how it wished to achieve its goals. The motion before the Senate addresses a central question of the role of government in subsidising drug treatment in Australia and how governments can control costs. They are legitimate questions. I have no argument with a government that says that it wishes to control costs or thinks it is important to control the cost of drug therapy. However, in this motion we highlight how the present Labor Government has lost its way on this matter; in fact, how it has fallen into the hands of its accountants on an important matter of health, to the possible detriment of the health of Australians.

SPEECH.PARA: The issue before the Senate is whether the Government acted properly or appropriately in restricting the availability of 53 expensive pharmaceuticals so that they became available only on authority. As other speakers in this debate have said, some of them were drugs that were removed from the authority list just three years ago. The Government is not seeking to make the drugs unavailable. Neither are we asserting that that is the case. It is just to make them more difficult to prescribe as pharmaceutical benefits.

For years I wrote authorities for drugs available on authority only. As a practising doctor I did it day in and day out. I understand what is involved in writing these authorities. I do not need to be lectured, as Senator Cook was doing, on what is involved in that. It is no great imposition. I was able to get the drugs and I knew the emergency procedures if the drugs were needed urgently. However, the fact remains that it did provide extra trouble and extra difficulty in my practice. Of course, I am a doctor. I was a doctor in practice and I am proud to be a doctor. I am also proud to say that I am a member of the Australian Medical Association, which has come under some attack today. But the objective of government is to save costs by having fewer of the 53 drugs prescribed. That is the stated goal of government and if it wants fewer of the drugs prescribed we are entitled to ask: How will fewer of them be prescribed and will this be good for Australians?

About 10 years ago my brother died of cancer, and before he died he was treated with drugs, with chemotherapy. This chemotherapy was very unpleasant. No-one in his right mind would receive it unless he was suffering an illness such as he was suffering. His hair fell out, he was ill, his blood count was affected, but those drugs probably gave him a remission and some useful life. Is anyone suggesting that those anti-cancer drugs, whose use is so unpleasant for the people who receive them, are being prescribed inappropriately or in an idiosyncratic manner? All those drugs are on the list and will now be available by authority only. There are legitimate questions to ask of this Government. Why, in pursuit of a goal with which we do not disagree, has it chosen this particular method with which we do disagree? If the Government can show that it has acted fairly, effectively, efficiently and properly, it is fair enough that the motion for disallowance be defeated. But unless there is a view that the Government has acted correctly, sympathetically, efficiently, effectively and fairly, the motion for disallowance should be supported.

Almost everything about this exercise has been mismanaged by the Government, I suspect because of instructions given through the Department of Finance. It has been mismanaged not least because the Government started from wrong premises. It used a blunt and non-specific approach typical of the Department of Finance. It asked wrong questions and it reached a foolish solution.

Let us start by looking at some of the premises from which the Government approached this matter. They are in brief: projected increases in the costs of the pharmaceutical benefits scheme (PBS) are caused, to some degree at least, by inappropriate prescribing or by bad prescribing of certain drugs. That is the starting point. If the Government cannot make that case and make it watertight and absolute, it falls before it gets to the first hurdle.

The Government's case then asserts that expensive drugs are being used where cheaper drugs would do the job. That has been asserted in those words, as I will mention later, and the Government's case rests on the fact that much of this prescribing is due to fads and fashion rather than to medical need or indication. I do not think I have put the Government's starting premises in any way that is not fair or accurate. But each of those premises is wrong and is certainly not proven or demonstrated.

Let us look for a moment at the rising costs of the pharmaceutical benefits scheme. We all know that part of the increase in the costs of subsidised drugs in Australia relates directly to the ageing population of Australia. I say to my colleague, Senator Coulter, himself I think medically trained, that if he is correct and if one goes down the path of lifestyle change and preventive medicine-he is not suggesting people thereby become immortal-one lives only to develop serious illnesses at a later age. In the long run the use of drugs is not going to diminish, it will be the use of drugs for different conditions at an older age, and many of the preventable conditions which cause premature mortality or morbidity will not occur. So we are not against lifestyle approaches, but that is not what this question is about.

The ageing of the Australian population, which in fact is due to lifestyle change, which is due to a whole range of environmental improvements, in fact brings about its own call upon the pharmaceutical benefits scheme of this country because old people are sicker. As Australians live longer they will manifest more illness requiring more drug therapy, and that in fact contributes to the cost of the PBS. It is not good enough for the Government to say, `We are worried about the costs of the PBS, therefore we have to cut it back'. It has to be related to the need to be met and to whether that need is being met, and I will make that point later. About half the people in Australia with elevated blood pressure are receiving no treatment at the present time. In fact if the Government wants to improve health in this country there are many people who possibly should start some drug treatment. The Government should understand that an increased use of drugs may represent major advances in medical care in this country and is not something to be criticised.

We come back to the ageing population of Australia. We know that old people are sicker, we know that they need treatment, we know that they will need greater subsidy and we know that that on its own explains some of the inevitable increase in the costs of the pharmaceutical benefits scheme. We also know that it will continue to represent part of the rising costs while ever the PBS exists in its present form. But this is only part of the reason for the rising costs which seem to have alarmed the Government. It is also true that the average cost of each prescription is rising, and this is what has concerned the accountants in the Government, the bookkeepers, the people from the Department of Finance who could not really care what social effects they produce, provided they can balance the books for government.

It is a fact that new and better drugs, superior to their predecessors and with fewer side effects, continue to appear for the benefit of patients. I have not heard that acknowledged today by the Government, but that is a fact central to modern drug therapy. If those new drugs are prescribed appropriately and properly patients will benefit, morbidity will decrease and mortality will fall. So perhaps we should be encouraging the use of some of these new drugs if the social outcomes they can produce are ones that we should be pursuing. That they are being prescribed is not of itself evidence of inappropriate or reckless use. Yet honourable senators will know that the Minister for Housing and Aged Care, Mr Staples, put out a press release that, because certain drugs had gone from one per cent to 1.43 per cent of all prescriptions, that in some way was some evidence of inappropriate use of those substances. It is nothing of the kind. It merely says that more of the drugs are being used. Whether they are being used inappropriately is an entirely separate matter requiring its own proof and its own demonstration.

Let us examine the mean and distorted views of some of the Ministers on the nature of the problem. In a speech to a business luncheon in Geelong on 7 July, the Minister for Finance, Senator Walsh, said that some of the increased costs of the PBS average drug prices could be attributed to new drugs which are medically superior. I ask honourable senators to remember that. But he went on to claim that much of the increased cost was due to doctors prescribing expensive drugs, and I quote the words that appeared in the medical press release, `which have new names but are no more effective than existing generic products'. If that is the crux of the case on which the Government rests, where is the evidence, where is any evidence, where is some evidence that the Minister is correct in what he is saying, that prescribing is idiosyncratic or inappropriate or that new drugs, the ones to which he was referring, are no more effective than existing generic products? It is for the Government to support its case with evidence. There is ample evidence to the contrary, and I will attempt to bring some of that evidence out when the debate resumes a little later.
Debate interrupted.
Sitting suspended from 12.45 to 2 p.m.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Prime Minister. Is the Minister aware that there was a drop in the money market rates yesterday after the Caucus chairman told the media that the Prime Minister had expressed a hope that rates would fall `a little bit'? Is the Minister further aware that the Prime Minister's office later denied that Mr Hawke had said any such thing? Given the Minister's own comments yesterday that conditions were in place under which interest rates were expected to fall, a similar view to that put by the Acting Treasurer in the House of Representatives, and in the light of Mr Keating's reported remarks from Berlin that there is a better ambience for interest rates, can the Minister help clarify these somewhat confused messages by giving the Senate some indication of where he thinks rates might go in the foreseeable future? I stress that I am not asking the Minister to come up with any particular figure, but in light of the concern among Australian home buyers, which has increased following the Commonwealth Bank's decision to lift its deposit rates, can the Leader tell the Senate whether it is likely that mortgage rates will rise before Christmas?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the last part of the question is of course no, consistent with everything I have previously said. In regard to the first part of the question let me say that I did see a press report of a reported statement by the Prime Minister-reported at second or third hand, as I understand it-which was subsequently denied, as Senator Chaney pointed out.
—It was your Caucus spokesman who said it. He must have got it wrong.

—I understand that. It is quite possible that the Caucus spokesman did get it wrong. These things sometimes happen in politics. I certainly saw the statement of denial of any comment about interest rates by the Prime Minister, which followed the rumour to which I just referred. Yesterday, in answer to a question about longer term projections in relation to interest rates, I referred-in answer to a somewhat confused question which referred to exchange rates rather than interest rates in the beginning-to the circumstances which might be described in the Treasurer's phrase `a better ambience for interest rates'. That reference that I was making was to the Budget Speech of this year, which at page 47 referred to the ongoing policy environment in which interest rates will be considered by those responsible for fixing them. I do not need to quote that in full. It is part of a section in which the Treasurer refers to inflation as being the main concern of the Government, but it also refers to the environments for interest rates.

ANSWER.PARA: I repeat that which I said yesterday. The Government believes that in the medium to long term there is a better environment for interest rates. However, I must say that that question will be affected by external factors as well as internal factors. I make the point that all major countries are currently concerned about renewed inflationary pressure, and interest rates have in fact risen in several major countries. As far as the Government is concerned, it was said in the Budget context that monetary policy must continue to be set with an eye to achieving a suitable balance between the impact on the exchange rate and competitiveness, and the need to contain cost pressures which also damage competitiveness. The last part of the question related particularly to housing interest rates and I suppose that arose from some tribal loyalty to Senator Chaney's Victorian colleagues, which few Liberal politicians in Victoria have.

TALK.START.PARA: —Probably a few home owners throughout Australia are interested.

—Yes, I concede that. I am asked to comment as to whether rates may go up. Again, I cannot confirm or deny that. I am not going to make any predictions about that. As Senator Chaney knows, there is a certain section of housing interest rates which remains fixed. Apart from that, the interest rate question in respect of housing is very much a matter which the market will attend to. I must make the point that recent figures suggest that a lot of the pressure has gone out of the housing market in the last month or so.

—Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. The Minister has confirmed and explained and given justification for his comments yesterday that conditions were in place under which interest rates were expected to fall. When he got to housing interest rates he became rather more uncertain. I ask the Minister: Is he saying that, with respect to housing interest rates, conditions are in place under which interest rates are expected to fall or is there very considerable doubt about that and may interest rates in fact rise, given that the Commonwealth Bank, for example, has decided to lift its deposit rates?

—Senator Chaney knows that the question of housing interest rates is not unrelated to other interest rates and I would have thought it was implicit in what I said that the environment which we believe is there for medium to long term improvement in interest rates will affect housing rates as well as other rates. It is very difficult to comment or in any way make predictions, even if one wants to or is prepared to, in relation to minor fluctuations up and down in housing interest rates. I am not going to do that.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Resources. It relates to the application by Huon Forest Products Pty Ltd for an export woodchip licence for its proposed mill at Whale Point on the Huon River south of Hobart. Is it true that the Huon River would need to be deepened and widened to accommodate the large woodchip ships which would need access to the Whale Point area? If so, what research has been done to assess the environmental damage that would occur as a result of this action? What would be the environmental effects on the Huon River's ecosystem from the discharge of ballast containing foreign organisms from vessels? Given that recently Atlantic salmon farms have been established in the area at vast expense, what effect would ballast water, oil and rubbish from woodchip ships have on the vital need of these farms for a clean, stable tidal flow of fresh water? As the current Liberal Tasmanian Government has a poor record in environmental matters, will the Minister assure the Senate that all environmental concerns associated with this mill proposal will be thoroughly examined prior to any consideration of an application for an export woodchip licence for Huon Forest Products?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank Senator Devereux for his question. There is no doubt that the issue of Tasmanian forests is a matter that all Tasmanian senators-indeed, all senators and members in this Parliament-should be concerned about. The question is in several parts. Let me approach an answer by saying first of all that I have a deep concern in sorting through the issues associated with the granting of a woodchip licence for Huon Forest Products and all the environmental issues that the honourable senator has raised.

ANSWER.PARA: As recently as the 13th of this month I spent a day in the Huon Valley. That day I had an opportunity to consult with representatives of Australian Paper Manufacturers Ltd, which operates a pulp mill in the vicinity of the Huon Valley, and with Huon Forest Products itself-the consortium that is proposing the development referred to in the question-on their views and expectations of how that development could be carried on. I took the opportunity as well to speak to representatives of the Esperance and Huonville municipalities and obtained from the elected local government representatives a view-I might say, couched in fairly pithy terms-as to their attitude to the development of the mill. In the course of that day I also spent some time with the Huon support group and discussed its concerns. I discussed the concerns of a local sawmiller with the representatives of east coast log hauliers, who have some worries about the impact such a development might have on their industry, with the Tasmanian Woodcraft Guild and, later the next morning, with the Tasmanian Trades and Labor Council.

TALK.START.PARA: —You had a full day.

—I had a very full day, that is true. I should also point out to the Senate that I have previously discussed the matter with the Tasmanian Premier, Mr Gray, and the Tasmanian Minister for Forests, Ray Groom. That was a fairly exhaustive round of consultations but I did it because the Commonwealth is concerned to discharge fully its obligations on a sensitive and controversial matter such as this.

ANSWER.PARA: As Senator Devereux would know, we have endorsed in principle the go-ahead for the Huon Forest Products development, subject to, in my portfolio, two major considerations. The first is that there is sufficient resource in the catchment area this development would serve to enable it to proceed. As Senator Devereux would know, Australian Paper Manufacturers has a mill there, and the Commonwealth and the State of Tasmania are close to concluding their consideration of the Helsham report and, hopefully, reaching an agreement on it. There is a major mill development in the north of the State by Associated Pulp and Paper Mills Ltd. Thus the resource impacts of a new development have to be properly weighted. We are working with the State at Commonwealth level to make an assessment of whether the wood supply is sufficient to enable such a project to proceed. The second consideration is that there be adequate and full community consultation. That is why I engaged in that exhaustive round of consultations. I do not rule off the page and say that they are now complete. If any Tasmanians or interest groups in Tasmania wish to put further views to me about those developments they should feel free to do so and I would welcome them.

Senator Devereux's question was about the environmental impacts of such a development. I do not take it unto my responsibility-indeed, it is explicitly not my responsibility-to make those decisions. Senator Richardson, my colleague, is best equipped to do that. I take advice from him on those matters and am guided by his judgments. I am mindful of the fact that Senator Richardson has said that he will not become involved in the issue of the wood resource for the mill and whether that is adequate to meet the demands of this project. With respect to the environmental issues about siting, location and all the other aspects of that development, he has said that he will be guided by the Tasmanian Government's environmental checks, which I understand are well advanced, subject to several considerations he has about the way in which those checks are carried out.

At this point I am unable to answer specifically the particular questions Senator Devereux has raised. When I obtain advice from the Tasmanian Government and from Senator Richardson about the environmental assessments they are undertaking, I will be better equipped to reply in detail.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Minister representing the Treasurer. I refer the Minister to the answer he gave to my question yesterday, when he refused to confirm the Treasurer's Budget forecast of a $9.5 billion balance of payments deficit for the current financial year. In the light of this morning's release of the August-and revised July-balance of payments figures showing a total deficit of over $2.9 billion for those two months, will the Minister now agree that the Treasurer's balance of payments forecast is history? Will the Minister also acknowledge that the balance of payments blow-out has happened before there was any appreciable softening in our export commodity prices such as has appeared over recent weeks? Without asking the Minister to speculate upon the future of interest rates-unlike his colleague the Acting Treasurer yesterday in the other place-will he now also acknowledge that the need to finance in 1988-89 a much higher balance of payments deficit than originally contemplated is bound to mean higher domestic interest rates in order to attract the necessary capital from overseas to do so? Finally, given these developments, will the Minister convey to his colleague the Treasurer the view that his own economic management performance would not seem to be an appropriate basis from which to be delivering patronising lectures on that topic to such countries as the United States and the Federal Republic of Germany, as he has been doing recently?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —My first comment is that that question was undoubtedly written by Senator Stone himself and not by some Murdoch ghost. For a start, I cannot think off the top of my head of any Murdoch journalist, with one exception, who would know enough to put together a question like that. But that is not the telling factor. The telling factor is that it is so similar to the questions Senator Stone asked so many times in September and October of last year. It certainly has a sense of deja vu about it. We have heard it all before. From I think Budget night onwards Senator Stone was forecasting a blow-out in the current account deficit forecast for the last financial year. His prophecies of gloom were intensified with the stock market crash. In the end, all of Senator Stone's worst fears turned out to be groundless. He has a long history of being a Jeremiah. Having said all that, the current account deficit figure for August is a little higher than most people would have expected.
—How much higher?

—This morning I heard, for what it is worth, that anonymous people in the money market in Sydney expected a maximum figure of $1.3 billion and it was a bit more than that. I do not know how good their judgment is.

ANSWER.PARA: Let me make a few other points. First, there is a well established seasonal pattern in the current account deficit; that is, in the first half of the financial year it is higher than in the second half. The figure for August was higher than many people would have expected. However, the figure for July was revised downwards, as was the figure for the last financial year in the most recent Australian Bureau of Statistics bulletin. Secondly, in addition to the seasonality factor, it is not unprecedented-indeed, it is not unusual-to have two consecutive months where a current account figure is abnormally high for the financial year in which that occurs. If I remember correctly, the months of September and October of last year were such months. The fact that there were two consecutive months where the current account deficit was substantially above either the trend or the monthly average for the whole financial year set Senator Stone off and running last year with exactly the same sort of question he has now asked.

He asserted that I refused to confirm the Budget forecast for the financial year current account deficit. That is not true. I did not refuse to confirm it. Any forecast or estimate is of course just that-a forecast or an estimate. Nobody can be certain that it is dead right, too low or too high. One can be certain only that it will not be precisely right. One cannot with any confidence or responsibility, however, assert anything else. On the basis of two months' figures, it would be premature to make a judgment that there was any significant error in that forecast. For all of those reasons, the other questions Senator Stone asked, based on the false assumptions and assertions in his question, are not relevant.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask a supplementary question, Mr President. Cutting through all the verbiage of the Minister's response, and getting to the heart of the matter, the Minister seems to be saying that he is not prepared to confirm the present forecast of the balance of payments-but he is not prepared to deny it, either. Is the Minister therefore saying that he thinks the forecast remains a good forecast? In the light of the fact that we have already achieved-if that is the right word-a $2.9 billion deficit in the first two months of the year, should not the Minister at least open his mind to the possibility that the balance of payments might in fact blow out to a deficit appreciably higher than the $9.5 billion as laid down in the Budget Papers?

—With every Budget forecast there is always the possibility that it can be wrong. Of course that possibility always exists. Indeed, most of last year's Budget forecasts were wrong. Some inaccuracies in estimating or forecasting were cancelled out by other errors or inaccuracies made in estimating.
—We don't doctor them up like those opposite do.

—Exactly, Senator Ray. What we do not do and what we have never done is cook the Budget figures, the way Opposition members used to do when they were in government. One remembers the rubbery figures, the crook figures that were written into a Budget. This was when Senator Stone was either the Secretary or the Deputy Secretary to the Treasury, and so he would know all about it. They were crook figures written into a Fraser Government Budget because there was to be an election in a couple of months' time, and those opposite decided not to tell the people the truth, just as the discredited former Treasurer decided not to tell the people the truth at the end of February 1983, when Senator Stone sent him a letter saying that the forecast Budget deficit was going to blow out wildly for the 1982-83 financial year and that the prospective Budget deficit for the next financial year was not $5 billion-which was the figure that the discredited former Treasurer was feeding to the public-but about $10 billion. Mr Howard decided then that he would not let the public in on that, either. We make honest estimates in Budget figures, and we always have since we have been in government.
—But wrong.

—Of course; they are nearly always wrong. Senator Stone knows enough to know that it can be no other way, that one cannot estimate with a greater degree of precision. I see no reason for criticising the forecast for the current account deficit, for gross domestic product growth, employment growth, inflation, or indeed expenditure items, which are much more predictable than those other broader aggregates. Even the estimates for expenditure items sometimes involve a significant degree of error in them. Indeed, for every year that we have been in government, bar one, the Budget estimate of expenditure has been significantly higher than the actual Budget outcome.
—Seven minutes-come on.

—Well, Senator Stone has asked a supplementary question. Of course, no sensible person would guarantee that any Budget forecast was correct. I repeat: on the basis of two months' figures, there is no reason to change the expectations about the current account outcome for this financial year-when there are so many precedents in the past where the figures for two consecutive months have been highly misleading, both as to the underlying trends and as to the monthly average for the entire financial year.

—I address my question to the Minister representing the Minister for Defence. On a recent visit to the Northern Territory, the shadow Minister for Defence, the honourable member for McPherson-and may he never return to the Northern Territory-stated on behalf of the Opposition that he was opposed to the re-location of the Sixteenth Cavalry Regiment in the Northern Territory. That provoked his colleague the Deputy Chief Minister of the Northern Territory to make the statement that he was one of the reasons why the Federal Opposition will stay in opposition-and hear, hear! Can the Minister advise the Senate what the Government's intention is with the re-location of the Sixteenth Cavalry Regiment to the Northern Territory?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: IMMIGRATION, LOCAL GOVERNMENT AND ETHNIC AFFAIRS

TALK.START.PARA: —I was a little surprised when I heard reports of the statement made by Mr White when he was in the Northern Territory. The Government has given the highest priority to providing defence for all of Australia and for all Australians. To this end, we have decided to move major units of all elements of the Australian Defence Force to Australia's north and west. An essential element of this program is our decision to move Cavalry Regiment to Darwin. The implementation of that decision is now well under way. When that is achieved, in the early 1990s, we plan to follow with an entire brigade. These decisions reflect our determination to develop a Defence Force which is trained, equipped and located to defend Australia. This can be done only by locating our forces where they would most likely have to fight-in the north. I find it somewhat surprising that the honourable member for McPherson has opposed that strategy. I am not surprised that his colleagues in the Northern Territory reacted in the way that they did.

—On a point of order, Mr President: Senator Collins asked about the Sixteenth Cavalry Regiment. The Minister is referring to 2 Cavalry Regiment. I do not think the Minister's answer is relevant to the question, and I suggest that the Minister not be allowed to continue to answer the question.
—Order! There is no point of order.

—It is good to see the cavalry come to the rescue of the Indians, Mr President! In conclusion, I say that what Mr White's views reflect is the failure of Opposition members to know where it is going with defence. I acknowledge that their heart is probably in the right place and that in fact their intentions are good; but they lack two essential qualities in this regard. First, they lack a strategy. Secondly, they are not able to detail what they would do in the defence area, given the other requirements placed on them by their policy to cut government expenditure. However, with defence, which is one of the biggest Budget items, they struggle on to say how they will maintain investment in the defence area. However, this is not particularly new and it does not apply just in the defence area. I think-and I would have to agree with Senator Collins-that, in the recent re-shuffle of the Opposition front bench, the honourable member for McPherson was a very lucky person to survive.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade. I refer the Minister to the recent speech made by General Secretary Gorbachev in which he offered to close the Soviet base at Cam Ranh Bay if the United States closed its major Philippines bases, and he pledged further the continuation of a Soviet freeze on the deployment of naval nuclear weapons in the Asia-Pacific region. I ask the Minister: What is the Government's view of the Soviet proposition? Does it believe that the Soviet freeze is genuine? If so, does it mean that the Soviet SS-N-21 sea-launched nuclear cruise missile is not being deployed? Will the Government seek a commensurate act of restraint from the United States if it does believe that the freeze is genuine, namely, to halt the current deployment of the Tomahawk sea-launched cruise missile? Finally, will the Government endorse the likely United States line of refusing to trade its Philippines bases for Cam Ranh Bay?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —While largely devoted to domestic concerns, Mr Gorbachev's speech in Krasnoyarsk on 16 September, to which Senator Macklin has referred, did contain quite a wide range of proposals, as the honourable senator says, concerning security and arms control in the Asia-Pacific region. It must be said that the proposals, despite their different and enthusiastic manner of presentation, are largely a re-working of Mr Gorbachev's speech in Vladivostok a couple of years ago, portraying, as that speech and the most recent one do, the Soviet Union as a constructive power in the region and seeking to reduce the United States presence and influence.

ANSWER.PARA: We welcome constructive Soviet involvement in the region and we are studying the speech closely. I will perhaps be able to give a more detailed response to some of Senator Macklin's questions when this process is further down the track. However, our preliminary assessment is that there are few new elements in the proposals and, to the extent that there are new elements which have attracted public attention, and in particular the offer to close Cam Ranh Bay in return for closure of American facilities in the Philippines, such proposals, and the Philippines one in particular, have a large element of unacceptable asymmetry in them, and, as such, could not be accepted at face value. Generally speaking, we will continue to judge the Soviet Union on the basis of actions rather than words. That is not to say that there are not some constructive things in the speech that are worthy of close study-and the speech is getting it.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —I draw the attention of the Minister for Justice to an article in the Australian Institute of Criminology newsletter Trends and Issues No. 9 of December last year by Dr Paul Wilson and Stephen Nugent on the research and policy implications of sexually explicit and violent media material. I draw the Minister's attention to the reference in that paper to the United States Attorney-General's Commission on Pornography, which found harmful effects of video pornography of the type found in X-rated material in this country. I draw attention to the following statement by Dr Wilson in that document:

QUESTION.PARA: It is important to note that there have been suggestions of alleged political bias in the formation and determination of the Meese Commission. Nobile and Nadler believe that the Commission's verdict was a forgone conclusion due to its leading terms of reference and its conservative membership.

Is it a fact that Philip Nobile is the Editorial Director of Penthouse Forum in the United States of America and that Eric Nadler is its senior editorial director? Is it not strange in an academic article such as this from the Institute of Criminology that reliance should be had on the chief propagandists for the video pornography industry in the United States to undermine the findings of the United States Commission? Will the Minister draw the attention of the Institute of Criminology to this apparent lapse on the part of Dr Wilson and Mr Nugent?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have had my attention drawn to the publication in the Trends and Issues series which dealt with the matters that Senator Harradine has outlined. It is a fact that the author of that short paper on sexually explicit and violent video material, research and policy implications, mentioned Nobile and Nadler. As I understand it, the citation method used in that Trends and Issues paper was in accordance with normal practice. It is not normal practice in academic publications to cite the political or personal characteristics or allegiance of authors. The fact is that the citation which was used in that Trends and Issues paper was, as I say, in accordance with normal academic processes.

ANSWER.PARA: I do not think Dr Wilson or his co-author can be criticised from a professional point of view for the methodology that was used. On the other hand, I think it would have been perhaps more useful if the authors had cited other commentators on the Meese Commission report, of whom there were many, who themselves pointed out the methodological and other weaknesses of that report. For example, virtually the whole of the American Bar Foundation research journal Fall 1987 No. 4 is devoted to a critique of the Meese Commission with some very senior and respected commentators contributing articles to that issue. In other words, I do not believe that the citation practice adopted in this Trends and Issues publication departed from normal and accepted practice. As I say, it could well have been that more trenchant and more authoritative commentators could have been found to balance the conclusions of the Meese Commission which, as I recall, were outlined in the Trends and Issues report.

TALK.START.PARA: —I direct my question to the Minister representing the Minister for Administrative Services. I refer the Minister to the present land sale fiasco in Bundaberg, where a former rifle range of 216 hectares and 7,000 square metres of land within the proposed strategic plan of Bundaberg was sold only two months ago for $270,000 to the Bundaberg Small Bore Rifle Club and then resold within 24 hours to Eskrose Pty Ltd for the sum of $390,000? Is the Minister aware that because this land is due to be gazetted industrial its value has been estimated at close to $4m? In view of the fact that Senator Robert Ray wrote to the honourable member for Hinkler, Mr Courtice, and informed him that this land had been valued by the Australian Valuation Office, can the Minister explain to the Senate why he allowed government assets worth an estimated $4m to be sold for $270,000, involving a loss to taxpayers of more than $3.5m? Will the Minister table the valuation made by the Australian Valuation Office? Also, will he initiate an inquiry into the circumstances surrounding this sale?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: IMMIGRATION, LOCAL GOVERNMENT AND ETHNIC AFFAIRS

TALK.START.PARA: —I am not sure that I will be able to answer in sufficient detail all aspects of Senator Boswell's question.
—You asked for a valuation.

—I know that the honourable senator is a bit excited and that this is his first question as a member of the shadow Ministry. I am really trying to assist. What I am saying to Senator Boswell is that this is a fairly complex question and I will have to seek further information on some parts of it.

ANSWER.PARA: Information that I have available to me now suggests that the Bundaberg rifle range became surplus to Commonwealth requirements in 1983. Consistent with a then standing Government policy, the rifle clubs in occupation were offered first option to purchase the property at Commonwealth valuation. Financial and legal difficulties delayed the proceedings for some years. The most recent valuation, made in late 1987, was based on advice from the local council on the likely future zoning that would apply to the property and on other market evidence relevant to the disposal of the property. The Bundaberg Small Bore Rifle Club accepted the offer and settlement occurred on 11 July this year. I am advised that the club immediately sold the property to another buyer at a profit. I understand that the intention of the club is to relocate to a cheaper property.

These events are of considerable concern to me, especially because the Commonwealth set out to assist the rifle club to continue shooting at the property. In this regard, I am advised that under Queensland law it is not possible to place covenants on land at the time of sale to restrict the way land is used by future owners. I interpose to say that I think Senator Boswell understands the reasons why that exists in Queensland. The Department of the Minister for Administrative Services has prepared a report on this matter. Mr West is considering this report to determine whether further administrative action should be taken on this issue. As to the honourable senator's request for tabling this and that, I will pass it on to the Minister for Administrative Services and seek an early response.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. The Minister is quoted in today's Bundaberg News Mail as saying that he sought a valuation from the Australian Valuation Office. Could he confirm that as Acting Minister he personally sought the valuation from the Australian Valuation Office? Will he confirm that he did in actual fact ask for that valuation?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: IMMIGRATION, LOCAL GOVERNMENT AND ETHNIC AFFAIRS

TALK.START.PARA: —I have not had the pleasure of reading the Bundaberg newspaper yet so I can neither confirm nor deny what is in the newspaper. Again, I will seek some further information on that and get back to the honourable senator.

—Is the Minister representing the Minister for Defence aware of the accident in Cairns on 5 September involving the nuclear-armed guided missile destroyer, USS Berkeley, and the Australian vessel, Coralita, which received about $100,000 worth of damage as a result of the collision, which the United States Navy has to date refused to acknowledge? Given that the dive boat charter company, Barrier Reef Cruises, is now facing collapse as a result of the damage done, the boat having been laid up for three weeks and a further five weeks of repairs being needed, I ask the Minister: Who is responsible for compensation to the owner of the vessel? In light of the fact that the Department of Defence has denied responsibility and neither the Prime Minister nor the Leader of the Opposition has replied to a letter from the company director, and knowing that if he sought compensation from the United States Government the case would have to be heard under American law, which could take up to three years, I ask: What steps will the Government take to prevent Barrier Reef Cruises going to the wall? I further ask why the Minister for Defence made such a ridiculous assertion on the 7.30 Report on Monday night as that there will be no accidents involving warships that carry nuclear weapons, when one such accident, although not directly affecting the nuclear weapons, has occurred so recently in an Australian port.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: IMMIGRATION, LOCAL GOVERNMENT AND ETHNIC AFFAIRS

TALK.START.PARA: —I am aware of an incident in Cairns on 5 September in which the USS Berkeley came into contact with the Coralita while berthing. Consistent with normal practice, responsibility for compensation for damage caused lies with the party responsible. As this claim arose out of navigation of a vessel, arrangements under the Status of Forces Agreement with the United States, whereby the Australian Government may settle claims on behalf of the United States Government, are not applicable. I understand that both the owner of the vessel and his insurer have been in contact with the United States authorities about the claim and I am advised that the United States authorities are currently awaiting material in support of the claim. I understand that when this material is available the United States authorities will be prepared to negotiate about the settlement of the claim, consistent with the usual principles.

ANSWER.PARA: In answering this question, I make no assumption as to some of the material contained in Senator Vallentine's question to the effect that the vessel was a nuclear-armed destroyer. Consistent with usual practice, the United States authorities will neither confirm nor deny that the USS Berkeley carries nuclear weapons. There will be no need to litigate the compensation claim if a negotiated settlement can be arranged. The Prime Minister's office will be replying shortly to a communication from the owner of the Coralita.
In answer to the last part of the question, let me clarify what the Minister said on the 7.30 Report-not what Senator Vallentine claims he said. He said:
There will be no accidents, none; no accidents that involve a discharge of nuclear weapons or a problem with the reactors.

That is what the Minister said according to the transcript of the 7.30 Report. Maybe Senator Vallentine blinked and missed that part, but I would have thought that that part was entirely clear. It is preposterous to suggest that no nuclear-powered or nuclear-armed ship-I am neither confirming nor denying, as I have no knowledge in this case and, if I did, I would not say anything on it-is ever involved in an accident per se. However, Minister Beazley's remarks on the 7.30 Report were very precise and clear and I think Senator Vallentine should have understood that.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Justice. I refer to evidence given by Mr Greenwood, the Director of the Special Investigations Unit, to the Senate standing committee investigating some aspects of the War Crimes Amendment Bill which is scheduled for early debate in the Senate this session. Mr Greenwood's evidence indicated that at the time, which I think was early this year-probably January-he had more than 200 active files under consideration by this unit on, presumably, alleged war criminals in Australia. I ask the Minister: What is the present number of active files held by Mr Greenwood's office, and has the Government received any estimate of the number of prosecutions which are likely to be launched if the legislation is passed?

—I will make inquiries of the Special Investigations Unit headed by Mr Greenwood as to the present number of active files. Senator Durack asked, in the second part of his question, whether the Government has received any estimates of the number of prosecutions. I do not believe that any estimate has been forwarded to the Attorney-General or the Director of Public Prosecutions (DPP). I will make inquiries; but, as I understand it, the number of prosecutions that might be launched would be a matter for the DPP.
—Have any files been forwarded?
—I do not know.
—Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. Will the Minister obtain the information for the Senate before the Bill is debated?

—As to the first question, I will certainly be able to achieve that. As to the second, I do not want to leave the Senate with any assumption that all I have to do is find out the numbers. I do not know that any such estimate has been forwarded to the Government.

—Has the Minister for Finance seen a newspaper report that photocopies were tabled recently in the Queensland Parliament showing that Queensland Department of Health cheques were made out in favour of three National Party branches in Queensland? Can the Minister advise whether Federal funds are made available to the Queensland Government for use in that State's Health Department? If so, is the Queensland Government's auditor required to certify to the Commonwealth that the funds have been used in the manner for which they were intended? If funds supplied by the Commonwealth are directed by the Queensland Government to National Party branches, would the Commonwealth be able to take any action to recover those funds from the Queensland Government?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have seen a copy of a news report in the Courier-Mail late last month which reported that cheques drawn from the Queensland Health Department accounts were made out to the Townsville branch of the National Party for $100 and $25; to the Mansfield National Party branch for $30; and to the Queensland Health Minister's own National Party branch of Greenslopes for $39.
—The shadow Minister for regional development is not even here.

—What a pity. `Regional development' is a euphemism for pork- barrelling, I presume; so it is a double pity that he is not here. Apparently, these payments were made as either donations or entrance charges for a number of National Party dinners and other functions for which Mrs Harvey, the Queensland Minister for Health, was asked to put her hand into her pocket and pay, but she put her hand in the taxpayers' pocket instead. There are many precedents, of course--
—On a point of order, Mr President: that statement is unparliamentary. It reflects on a member of another parliament and should be withdrawn.
—I ask the Minister to withdraw the statement.
—Very well. If Senator Chaney finds it offensive, I withdraw it. Nevertheless, the fact remains that Mrs Harvey drew cheques on the taxpayers for social functions.

—Mr President, I rise on a further point of order. My further point of order is that it is not for the Minister to categorise the basis of my objection. My objection is that his statement is in breach of Standing Orders. Also, I ask him to withdraw his comment about me. I find that objectionable.
—I did not make a comment about you. You must be thin skinned.
—You did, about the basis on which I took the point of order. I made it quite clear to the President that--
—Order! I ask the Minister to withdraw.

—I withdraw. Mrs Harvey made out cheques to the National Party to cover her entrance fees to Queensland National Party functions and the cheques were drawn on taxpayers. That was not the first time the Queensland Government got National Party money mixed up with Government money.

ANSWER.PARA: Senator Colston is quite correct: very substantial Federal funds are made available to the Queensland Government for the purpose of delivering health services and it certainly is not intended that those funds should finish up in assorted branches of the Queensland National Party. However, financial assistance grants to the States into which, under the present arrangements, most Commonwealth health payments are rolled wind up in Consolidated Revenue, along with the Queensland Government's own revenues. In that situation, it is not possible to unscramble the funds and to assert with absolute certainty that the cheques that Mrs Harvey made out, drawn on the Queensland Government's account, were ultimately funded by Queensland taxpayers or by Commonwealth taxpayers. One thing we are quite certain about is that some taxpayers paid, unknowingly and without consent, Mrs Harvey's entrance fees to various National Party functions in Queensland.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Transport and Communications. Why is the Government planning to waste several million dollars on temporary improvements at Brisbane's international airport terminal while promising a new facility in five years time, when private developers are prepared to build a terminal and hotel which could be operational within two years? Is the Minister aware that Brisbane cannot wait five years for a new terminal, considering that in June 1991 the city will be hosting the Lions Clubs International convention and, according to statistics provided by previous host cities, the six airport gates currently available at our existing international terminal could not possibly pro- cess the 45,000 delegates expected to arrive at and depart from Brisbane Airport? In 1987, for example, Taipei International Airport, with 22 gates, had great difficulty in coping with 35,000 delegates. Can something be done to ensure that a new terminal is constructed and operational by June 1991?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The timing and financing of the development of facilities at Brisbane Airport is a matter for the Federal Airports Corporation (FAC) rather than the Government. It has made an independent commercial judgment about these matters, and we pretty well have to accept that at face value. My brief tells me that an investigation has now been completed by the FAC into the requirements for maintaining the existing international terminal for a planned period, as Senator Bjelke-Petersen says, of up to five years and that the Board has now approved the expenditure of $4.8m for these works to be undertaken.

ANSWER.PARA: I have to say that my own inclination was to investigate the possible use of the centre of the new domestic terminal for international purposes. That, as we all know, is a splendid edifice, arguably splendid enough to take us into about the twenty-second century, quite apart from the immediate needs for the period ahead. I am told in this brief, however, much to my disappointment, that the consideration that has been given to the possible use of the centre of the new domestic terminal suggests that it would be financially prohibitive to utilise that centre span and to make the appropriate further alterations to it. Moreover, I am told, the area will be required in 1990 to accommodate new entrants in the domestic market.

TALK.START.PARA: —Ha, ha! You have been conned again.
—That may be so. Certainly, I am not surprised that there is a prohibitive expense involved--
—We have an outbreak of optimism in the Senate.

—I am sure that there will be new entrants in the market. I have no doubt about that, but I would have thought that there was enough space around the other existing fingers of the Brisbane terminal to accommodate about 43 new entrants for another 75 years. But since, mercifully, I have no further responsibility for such matters, my own judgments, for what they are worth, do not count for a row of beans. I am told, finally, that the Corporation is looking at alternatives for a new development and will be consulting with all interested parties. So I say to the honourable senator that one never knows one's luck.

—Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. In light of the answer given by the Minister, for which I thank him very much, I wonder whether the Government, in thinking of other alternatives, has looked at the suggestion that I put forward in my question about private developers being prepared to build a terminal and hotel which could be operational within two years.

—As I said in the last sentence of my reply, I am told that the FAC is looking at alternatives for a new development. It will certainly be consulting with all interested parties, no doubt including potential private sector tenderers.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Resources. I refer him to an article in today's Business Age, which I will hand to him, headed `Esso-BHP to spend $85m developing two new Bass oilfields'. There is a map next to that headed `Tapping new fields', showing the two fields, Dolphin and Perch, which are situated, it seems, off the Victorian coast near Sale. I ask: What significance does the Government attach to that development in terms of both its resources and its economic strategies?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank Senator Cooney for giving me a copy of the Business Age of today's date. That is a newspaper I have not read, but I am aware of the announcement by Esso-BHP--
—I want it back.

—I will give it back later, if I may. I might need it for this answer. I am aware of Esso-BHP's announcement of the total expenditure of $550m on the development of the Dolphin and Perch fields for further oil production in what we call the Gippsland Basin but which is commonly known as Bass Strait. This $550m development will create about 600 new jobs, most of which will be located in the Sale or Barry Beach area in Victoria and will thus be a tremendous boost to industries in that area from a geographical and economical point of view.

ANSWER.PARA: I think it is a mark of confidence by Esso-BHP in both the Commonwealth and the Victorian governments that it has chosen this week to announce the go-ahead for such a massive development as this. It is a mark of confidence in the Commonwealth in that one of the controversial issues in the area of oil production in Australia is whether we have our tax regime right. It would suggest that we have, and, indeed, the reduction in corporate taxation announced by the Treasurer recently may have been the spur to have encouraged Esso-BHP to move as confidently as it has in this area. It is also significant, given that at present the benchmark crudes are trading in a band of between $12.50 a barrel and $14.50 a barrel, with pundits suggesting that they might fall to even $10 a barrel. West Texas intermediate, Brent and Kuwait light, the three benchmarks, are in that band at the moment. Thus with the end of the Iran-Iraq war and the forecast being that oil prices will fall even further, for the Australian Esso-BHP venture to proceed to announce such a major development is a quite significant development. In fact, I had the opportunity of talking to Dr Al-Chalabi, who is the Deputy Secretary General of the Organisation of Petroleum Exporting Countries, when he was in Australia just the other day.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I raise a point of order. This is very interesting, but it is not really relevant to anything much. Could I ask the Minister to restrain the length of his answer in the interest of getting a few questions asked during this Question Time? The Minister is debating the question, Mr President.

—There is no point of order. I point out that there have been a number of long questions, a number of long answers and a number of supplementary questions. That is the reason a very small number of questions is being asked today. I ask the Minister to keep that in mind.
