—I will indeed, Mr President. The question was: What significance do we attach to the announcement of this development. I was just annotating its significance, but I will bring my answer to a conclusion fairly rapidly. The Perch and Dolphin reserves are estimated at 19 million barrels of crude each and, as Senator Cooney has indicated, it will cost about $85m to develop those fields. The partners, Esso-BHP, are also going to conduct further exploration-I think another five wells are to be drilled in the Bass Strait area in the next year-so the exploration side of their agenda as well as the production side is up.

ANSWER.PARA: It is important, too, that the Government, during the period of stewardship of this portfolio by Senator Evans, negotiated a package of excise concessions with Esso-BHP in this area. That has proved to be an incentive for further development and, since the first 30 million barrels of crude produced from these fields in each case will not be taxed by excise, that has proved to be a successful incentive for that type of development. Overall, it is clear that we have the tax mix right and that the economic and political stability offered by Victoria is appropriate for a development of this sort.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: COMMONWEALTH SCIENTIFIC AND INDUSTRIAL RESEARCH ORGANISATION: RESEARCH CUTBACKS

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Science, Customs and Small Business. I draw his attention to an article in yesterday's Australian newspaper which stated that Dr Trevor Scott, the head of the Animal Production Unit of the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation (CSIRO), has been forced to resign because, as he says, he can `no longer manage and implement policies which are leading to a systematic destruction of the animal production research effort in CSIRO'. Given that Dr Scott is acknowledged as a leading research scientist and that, as head of the unit for the past 14 years, he has demonstrated an unquestioned loyalty to the aims and aspirations of CSIRO, does the Minister not agree that Dr Scott's resignation is a severe blow for Australia's $14 billion livestock industry? What justification can the Minister give for the cutbacks his Government has made to research and particularly to the CSIRO? Does the Minister accept that his Government's appointment of a former Labor Premier, Neville Wran, to the position of Chairman of CSIRO has been neither wise nor appropriate?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I might deal with the last part of the question first. Mr Wran has been a very dedicated and committed Chairman of CSIRO and I believe he has worked very hard at that task. I certainly regard the appointment as appropriate.
—Like Minister Jones-widely acclaimed but not very effective. That is the same sort of pattern.

—If I might say so, I do not think it is the same sort of pattern. The question is about Mr Wran, not about Mr Jones. If Senator Chaney wishes to ask me a question about Mr Jones I will be happy to try to answer it. But let us get it clear. One regrets the resignation of any distinguished scientist from a position of importance. The article in the Australian claims that Dr Scott is standing down from his position because of Budget cuts. He has been head of the division for the past 14 years. His current term as chief of the division was to conclude in February 1989. Dr Scott indicated several months ago, prior to the Budget, that he did not wish to be offered appointment for a further term. His position has been advertised internationally since he indicated that. It is a bit of a long bow in the circumstances to draw the conclusion, as some other conclusions have been drawn, that Dr Scott retired as a result of the Government's Budget strategy in respect of CSIRO finances.
—Nonsense, the CSIRO is in complete disarray.

—I come back to the point of Senator Brownhill's question which suggests that Dr Scott retired because of the Budget. I am telling honourable senators-if this is an unpalatable fact I suggest that Senator MacGibbon try to swallow it-that Dr Scott gave notice several months ago that he did not wish to be reappointed.
—Next year.

—As from February 1989. That was when his appointment concluded and he did not wish to be offered appointment for a further term. His position was consequently advertised internationally. That is the important fact.

ANSWER.PARA: I want to say something briefly about the question of the CSIRO budget because it has been made relevant in Senator Brownhill's question. What the Government has done in respect of the CSIRO budget is to agree to maintain in real terms the appropriation funding levels for CSIRO for three years. It is the first time that has happened to CSIRO for quite a long time, if ever before. The purpose of that is to assist forward planning in CSIRO and to facilitate the planned expansion of identified priority research areas. At the same time the Government has set a target for CSIRO to achieve 30 per cent of its funding from external sources. I would not have thought anyone from the Opposition would have any objection to that, listening as I have over several years to the desultory questions one is asked about science policy. The Opposition knows the figures. It was in government when the disastrous figures for research and development funding in this country were known internationally, when private sector research and development in this country dropped to the lowest levels in the Organisation for Economic Cooperation and Development table. Opposition senators were the people in government when all that happened. They ought to know all that. The fact of the matter is that in terms of a strategy for CSIRO there is real term funding for three years to assist it in forward planning. There is a target set for it to earn 30 per cent of its earnings from external sources and it will be able to retain that money.

TALK.START.PARA: —You will cut it again.
—No, we will not. I said there was a guaranteed funding from the Government. The honourable senator should have a look at it in two or three years time.
—No, I will have a look at it now.
—You are pretty good at looking for income on the side, or you thought you were.

—Senator Walsh is right. This is intended as an incentive for CSIRO to foster even greater interaction with industry. In the course of the Budget we also approved a major capital redevelopment project at North Ryde. This year's appropriation is $334m from the Federal Government, which is a pretty big slab of Commonwealth revenue to pay to an organisation as important as CSIRO. There has been a lot of confusion in people's minds about this issue which is often fuelled, as it were, by dubious questions and dubious comments of the kind which I do not blame Senator Brownhill for. It is sometimes fuelled by that sort of misinformation about CSIRO matters.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Brownhill Sen D.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask a supplementary question, Mr President. I ask the Minister whether he disagrees with the statement in the Australian newspaper which was attributed to Dr Scott and which read:

QUESTION.PARA: ``This continued reduction in funds made available from the Government for the strategic or longer-term research and development for the animal industries is one of the main reasons why I have decided to step down as chief of this division in early 1989,'' he told The Australian yesterday.

I ask the Minister whether that is correct. In answering the last part of the question does the Minister not have any regard to the fact that Mr Wran had forbidden all departmental heads of CSIRO from public comment on the Budget effects on the CSIRO?

TALK.START.PARA: —Let me say first of all that I did not say that what Senator Brownhill just suggested Dr Scott said was incorrect. I said it is incorrect to relate his comment to that Budget, if it was made, as I believe, prior to the 1988 Budget. It is quite incorrect to relate it to that Budget as Senator Brownhill did in his opening question.
—He had to resign to say it.

—Senator Bishop has the facts muddled as usual. Let me make it quite clear that Senator Brownhill sought to relate this to the Budget funding of CSIRO. I am sorry but one cannot do that. If Dr Scott made a statement subsequently that he was leaving earlier than his foreshadowed February retirement date he may well have said it was because he was aggrieved by Budget funding but he did not originally establish that intention with the CSIRO. In so far as the question of the Chairman of CSIRO attempting to gag CSIRO staff is concerned, I have seen no such indication from the Chairman of CSIRO. I have seen a copy of a letter from the Chairman of CSIRO to a divisional head saying that he hoped this would not continue to be a matter of public comment. That is a vastly different thing from--
—He was gagged.

—Senator MacGibbon, who is usually an expert on defence matters, has now become an expert on the English language. That is a vastly different thing from the use of the word `gag', which he used in his silly interjection.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —As honourable senators will be aware, the Thirty-fourth Commonwealth Parliamentary Conference was held in Canberra from 18 to 25 September. During the conference, which was attended by some 300 delegates from national and state legislatures from 43 Commonwealth countries, a number of agenda items of interest to all Commonwealth parliamentarians were discussed. During the plenary sessions the topics included: international peace and security, with special reference to SouthernAfrica; improving international trade, especially in agricultural products; superpower disarmament; and environmental protection. Panel discussions included drug problems; parliamentary committees in the control and scrutiny of government expenditure; establishing a parliamentary branch of Amnesty International; education mobility in the Commonwealth; combating acquired immune deficiency syndrome; and the impact of a declining world economy on women and youth.

INTERJECT.PARA: All sessions were marked by high quality contributions and keen debate. The Commonwealth Secretary-General made a major speech to the conference and the Prime Minister and the Minister for Trade Negotiations hosted dinners for the conference participants. The conference, which was attended by a number of Prime Ministers, Chief Ministers, Presiding Officers and senior Ministers, was a great success for Australia and this Parliament in particular. A number of trade opportunities were explored, and there was a considerable exchange of ideas between parliamentarians in both the formal sessions and the informal activities.

An unusual feature of this conference was that the delegates arrived in Australia through a number of different entry points where the State and Territory branches provided pre-conference programs for all delegates. The Small Countries Conference and the Executive Committee meeting were hosted in Hobart by the Tasmanian Branch. On behalf of the Commonwealth Branch of the Commonwealth Parliamentary Association, I want to thank all State and Territory branches for the hospitality which was extended to delegates prior to the conference in Canberra.

The Commonwealth of Australia delegation was led by the Hon. Ben Humphreys, MP, and it contributed greatly to the conference proceedings. As Joint President of the Commonwealth Branch, I want to thank all members of the delegation for their contribution to all conference activities during the week.

This conference would not have been the success it was without the dedicated work of many people who work for the Parliament. This includes the conference secretariat led by Kieran Schneemann and the numerous individuals who provided assistance to the delegates and the conference in general. The group of people I wish to single out for special tribute are the members of the Parliamentary Catering Service and the property section of the Joint House Department. The quality of the meals and the level of service provided by these people throughout the entire week was outstanding. Many delegates from senior member countries of the Commonwealth remarked on this feature of the conference and commented that such service on this scale could not have been provided in their own parliaments. I take this opportunity to thank each and every member of the staff of the Parliament from all departments who made a contribution to the success of the Commonwealth Parliamentary Conference.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Teague Sen B.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the statement.

I concur fully with Mr President's statement. I believe that Australia can be justly proud of the conduct of the recent Commonwealth Parliamentary Association (CPA) Conference. You, Mr President, as President of the CPA and the conference, represented all parliamentarians in Australia in a magnificent way. I commend you for the contribution you have made to this Parliament through that CPA conference.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I endorse the remarks that you have made relating to the Commonwealth Parliamentary Association meeting and I endorse your remarks thanking those people who made the conference such a success. Mr President, I think that you missed one person in your remarks-that is, yourself. You were the chairman of the conference. It was evident that you conducted that conference with efficiency, allowing the debate to range over a wide area of subjects which were of interest to the delegates. I notice that there were only three slight queries about your rulings-one of which inevitably came from an Indian delegate, and two of which came from unnamed persons on the Australian delegation. However, the warmth with which you were greeted at the end of the session showed how much the delegates from the various countries appreciated your chairmanship. Mr President, you were not, of course, on the delegation as you are the President of the International Secretariat, so, as a member of the Australian delegation, I wish also to congratulate and thank the secretary of our delegation, Mark McRae from the House of Representatives, and his colleagues from the House of Representatives and the Senate who were involved substantially in the success of this conference.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Reid Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —At the risk of perhaps repeating some remarks already made, I should like to endorse those remarks. As chairman of the conference, Mr President, you have brought great credit to this Parliament, not just at the conference in the last week or so but throughout your term as President of the Commonwealth Parliamentary Association. You have set a standard for others to live up to. Your handling of that large conference, of some 300 people from 40 countries and many parliaments, was skilful and dignified.

SPEECH.PARA: I also refer to Mrs Sibraa, who, with the staff involved, ran the spouses program. From talking to spouses during the week of the conference, I noted that there was not one who was not delighted with the program offered.

That the conference was in Canberra, the national capital, was pleasing to me because there are so many things here that we wanted to show the overseas delegates. They certainly saw the sights and features of the national capital, which they enjoyed. I noticed that many of them were exhausted on occasions. Perhaps the highlight of it was Dr Heptulla's comment that the delegates had not only shaken hands with a kangaroo but had seen `sheeps being undressed'. I think that that, in a sense, brought it all home to us.

One could not refer to the conference without commenting on Mr Kieran Schneemann and the role he played in working with you, Mr President, to ensure that the conference was put on with the style it was. Also, for those of us who were in the delegation led by the Hon. Ben Humphreys, Mark McRae made sure that we were catered for and looked after as a delegation should be. The liaison officers from the various departments of the Parliament, all wearing their brown Akubras, not only added style to the function but were at all times ready to assist delegates. The number of delegates who wanted to change their airline bookings in the last few days put tremendous pressure on all the people involved in the organisation of the conference.

Of course, there will be the chance to comment on the substance of the debates when the report is presented. However, those people who are running this building-who are still quite new to it-really deserve our very warm thanks and gratitude for the way the functions went off. The speed with which they had to turn the Great Hall from a meeting room into a hall for dinner and then back again into a meeting place for the next morning was remarkable. The dining room staff and those people in the kitchens who were preparing the food are to be congratulated. The food was of an extremely high standard, as were the functions generally. Those people deserve our thanks. To put on a function of that size at any time certainly takes considerable talent; to do it in a very new building such as this, even more so.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Coates Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I associate myself with the remarks of other members of the Commonwealth Parliamentary Association delegation. As one who participated last week, I would not like it to be thought that there was no-one from the Government benches in the Senate present at that conference; there was. I particularly associate myself with the remarks congratulating you, Mr President, on your patient conduct of the conference and to congratulate Kieran Schneemann on his years of organisation leading up to an event which did Australia proud.

SPEECH.PARA: As far as the contribution of Australians to the conference debate goes, I draw particular attention to my House of Representatives colleague Mr Tickner for his contribution in leading off the debate on the disarmament question. Secondly, I draw attention to the participation of all those delegates who we know are associated with the Amnesty International group in this Parliament in the very important panel session in that area-a session which had the potential to create severe tension because some of the countries felt sensitive about the matter being discussed. As I understand it, the discussion was very successful. I think that all those delegates who were involved in that session and who made contributions to other panel debates and the plenary session debates deserve our congratulations.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Discussion of Matter of Public Importance

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —I have received a letter from Senator Alston proposing that a matter of public importance be submitted to the Senate for discussion, namely:

INTERJECT.PARA: The serious burden to the national economy imposed by the extraordinarily high levels of public debt in Victoria, the onerous burden of Victorian State taxes and charges and the gross mismanagement of the Victorian economy as exemplified by the $2.1 billion unfunded liabilities of Workcare, the horrendous losses approaching $1 billion per annum of the State transport system and the hundreds of millions of dollars put at risk by the bungled investment policies of the Victorian Economic Development Corporation.
I call upon those senators who approve of the proposed discussion to rise in their places.
More than the number of senators required by the Standing Orders having risen in their places-

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Alston Sen R.K.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —Victorians will go to the polls on 1 October and I do not think I need to say that it is going to be a very important day for the future of that State. Of course, voters could be excused for not knowing that there is to be an election on that day because in recent weeks the Victorian Government has assiduously cultivated forms of entertainment other than politics. If people are not watching the Olympic Games on television night and day, they have been attending the grand final, some perhaps with more enjoyment than others, or going to the royal show. What we have had over the last few weeks in Victoria is a calculated attempt to distract voters from the real issues. It is the sort of strategy that most of us are familiar with because almost $50m was spent in similar vein fairly recently, and of course that proved that the Federal Government was too clever by half. I have no doubt that the same result will befall the Victorian Government on 1 October.
—What did they spend the money on?

—It spent $6m on running a fruitless Constitutional Commission and the balance on sending us to the ballot boxes on a referendum. Quite clearly, the same strategy is being used here. I do not know whether Senator Button has been giving cogent advice to his old friend and colleague Premier John Cain, but I venture to say that even Malcolm Blight will not be able to save John Cain on 1 October. I wonder whether John Cain and John Button have much in common any more.

SPEECH.PARA: If we look at the way the State of Victoria is run, it is quite clear that this is the last of those State governments that believe in spending money as though it was going out of style, in taking on board about 10,000 public servants in the first two years of government and raising public debt spending to a new art form. I want to go through some of what I think are the quite frightening statistics that demonstrate beyond doubt that mismanagement in Victoria has reached such a stage that the voters will have no choice other than to reject massively the Cain Government. It is more than six years since the Australian Labor Party came to power in March 1982. At that time voters were promised all sorts of new goodies. We were told it was going to be a new era of modern economic management, that all the latest and most sophisticated financial techniques such as program budgeting would be introduced and that this would somehow deliver Victoria into a new era of prosperity and efficiency. Of course the opposite has occurred. All of this new financial jargon has become simply a matter of beads and mirrors. It has served no real purpose at all,as the Government has imposed no disciplines or restraints. As a result we have had this massive overspending that now causes such great travail in Victoria. After six years I think we are entitled to look at the Victorian Government's record.

Perhaps the most devastating indictment appeared in last Saturday morning's Australian. It stated that Moody's Investor Services Inc., the international credit rating agency, was reported as having done a very close analysis on Victoria's debt position and it came to a number of damning conclusions. One could summarise them by saying that Victoria is now beyond doubt bearing the heaviest debt burden of all the States. But the report also found that Victoria has the highest gross State debt; the second highest ratio of gross debt to gross State product and the lowest ratio of liquid assets to debt; the highest net debt per capita of all the mainland States, the highest interest bill and the highest debt service ratio measured as the ratio of total net interest paid to total revenue. No one could do much more than that if he wants to single out one government as being much worse than all the rest. The end result is that of every dollar now paid in State taxation 22c goes to pay the interest on that debt, compared to 15c in 1982, the last year when the Liberal Party was in Government in that State. A lot has happened for the worse in that time. It is quite clear, according to Moody's, that Victoria's debt service ratio is higher than that of any state and for no good reason.

It is rather pathetic to look at the explanations offered by the Victorian Treasurer, Mr Jolly. His first justification was that we should not look at the level of debt but rather take it as a proportion of gross domestic product. Moodys did not accept that approach and I think it is just a feeble attempt to distract attention from all the other indices which clearly point to debt being out of control. The Victorian Treasurer also said this:
The reason for the high figure for Victoria is the relatively capital-intensive nature of the public sector.

If that is just a frank admission that somehow Victoria is overburdened in its public sector, I will take it at face value, but he does not seem to accept that there is anything wrong with that. He simply states the fact and then says that somehow that explains why Victoria is in such a parlous state. I think it is clear that there are many ways in which that debt burden now bears on all Victorians. As a result we find that, in order to cope with these levels of debt and the interest required to service it, Budget expenditure has increased at an average annual rate of 3 per cent in real terms and that Victorian per capita expenditure has increased from $1,508 in 1981-82 to $2,832 in 1988-89, an increase of 14 per cent in real terms. The Budget deficit has virtually trebled under the Cain Government.

There are a massive number of statistics which demonstrate beyond doubt that there are reasons why the State Government in Victoria does not really believe in fiscal responsibility and in proper economic management. About 65 per cent of State Budget outlays are in labour costs or labour related costs. Public sector employment in Victoria has grown at treble the rate of other States. I do not want to go into detail of that; suffice it to say that it is not accidental, it is quite deliberate. It is founded in the belief that somehow the more public servants there are, the more people there are to hand out the goodies-the more people there are to service the media unit, to pump out disinformation, to pork-barrel as much as possible and to ensure that people are grateful for big government. Well, it certainly has not worked out that way.

Victoria's net State debt has more than doubled in seven years. In real terms it has increased by 27 per cent and it will go on and on increasing if the Victorian Government is given another opportunity. Its profligate spending program and debt servicing costs have driven State taxes and charges to record levels. State taxation has more than doubled in the seven years of the Cain Labor Government, increasing by 41.4 per cent in real terms. Victorians now pay more in State taxes per head of population than the residents of any other State.

When it comes to public utilities there are hidden taxes on items such as gas, water, electricity and other statutory authority services which have increased from $111m in 1981-82 to $607m in 1988-89. Need I go on? The level of State taxes and charges is a scandal in Victoria. But of course there are a number of other scandals. State public transport is a classic example. While the Liberal Party has recognised that 90 per cent of Victorians travel by car, that the road system is greatly in need of repair and expansion, that we need new freeways and ring roads, the Labor Government in this election campaign has pledged to spend not one cent more on private transport needs but instead to boost dramatically the public transport system, which has been declining year in year out and which currently costs almost $1 billion a year net. That is the loss that is incurred. It therefore has committed itself simply to perpetuating that situation. It will not accept any of the sensible suggestions that have been made about the introduction of automatic ticket machines. It is a captive and a hostage of the union movement in Victoria. A classic example of that is that there is, as we all know, a fair rate of attrition in all areas of the Public Service, certainly in public utilities, but when it came to dealing with the railways the Government meekly suggested that over a 15-year period 1,400 jobs might be lost, and the trade union movement and the Australian Railways Union in particular said they would not wear that. They could not agree to the shedding of 1,400 jobs. They asked for talks and the Government immediately said it was prepared to discuss the matter further. It is clear that if the unions will not wear something this Government does not have the gumption to withstand that pressure. It has a blind, ideological obsession with public transport, even though it is clear beyond doubt that Victorians vote with their cars. They are not prepared to leave home and travel by public transport, not knowing whether that same public transport will be available that evening. The Victorian Government will not accept consumer preference. As a result it is going to spend more and more money in areas in which the population of Victoria has clearly demonstrated it does not want money spent. Let me give a couple of classic quotations. They are withering testimonials from the chief ideologue of Victoria, Mr Cain. This what he said about public transport in 1986, which is more than four years after he came to government. He said:

The Government has tried to bring these work practices up to date and to provide a better system. Considerable progress has been made. Victoria is now heading towards having the best public transport system. Honourable members should ask anyone who uses public transport whether he or she is satisfied that public transport is better now that it was before. Constituents will know the system is better.

In other words, he was not prepared to say the system is good. He was not prepared to vouch for any significant improvements. He was simply saying it is better than it was. After all the money that has been pumped in, after all the funny money deals of selling railways to the Australian Government and then buying them back on secret leasing arrangements, it is not surprising that we have got more modern rolling stock and that one could say the system is better than it was before. But even the Premier did not argue that the system is good, that somehow it is performing or that the expenditure is justified. What he said later in that year was almost laughable. He said:
The performance by the Minister, Tom Roper, and by the Government is the best proof of the popularity of our public transport system.

Of course, Mr Roper subsequently got the chop and I do not think anyone would pretend for a moment that there is any popularity attaching to the public transport system in Victoria. They are the sorts of glowing testimonials that the Premier gives. I certainly would not want a character reference if that is his state of mind. It is quite clear that the problems of the public transport system in Victoria are of titanic proportions and it is certainly sinking faster than the Titanic did. The Labor Government is not prepared to take the measures that are required or to cut back in the areas where funds do not need to be spent in order to spend them in areas where they manifestly are needed, such as on ring roads and freeways.

The ultimate ideological commitment is WorkCare. As anyone who has worked in the area of personal injuries would know, even the Leader of the Government and Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce (Senator Button), there are very many problems with almost any system that one introduces, but perhaps the worst way that one could go is to try to put an artificial price cap on premiums for five years without trying to improve the expenditure costs in the system. That is precisely what the Government did. It was a cynical attempt to pretend that somehow it could wish away the massive burden of that system. The first thing the Victorian Government did was to drive all private insurers out of the market, which ensured that there was a monopoly running the system, with no incentive for efficiency. In the first 22 months of operation WorkCare lost $1,706m.

TALK.START.PARA: —How much? A billion?

—$1.7 billion. The sorts of things that we all took for granted as sensible means of keeping down levels of fraud, such as allowing the use of films in court, were banned. Employers were required to pay moneys for the first seven months irrespective, as long as the worker claimed to be injured. On it went. Rehabilitation was introduced as some sort of global saviour, when anyone who had studied the system knew that rehabilitation was an empty charade; there had been pilot projects, which simply had not worked. Now we have reached the point where it was announced last week that the unfunded liabilities of WorkCare exceed $2 billion. The consulting actuary retained by WorkCare itself has reported that, even with the changes proposed to be made by the Government, the system will be bare of assets by 1992. In other words, it is in a state of absolute crisis. It is a system that the Government will not acknowledge is in need of fundamental repair. Indeed, it is quite clear that the system cannot continue in anything like its present form. Unless competition is reintroduced into the system, it will go on and on being milked.

SPEECH.PARA: I do not have any doubt that everyone in Victoria knows what a scandal it is and knows how easy it is to get money from the system and how little work results from all of these so-called changes. I come now to perhaps one of the most scandalous examples of economic mismanagement in the State of Victoria. It relates to the Victorian Economic Development Corporation (VEDC). As the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce would well know, the principal reason why this election was called early was to save the scalp of the Deputy Premier.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thought it was because the Olympic Games were on.

—That is all part of the timing. It was very fortuitous, of course. But the desperation, the need to call an urgent election, was driven very much by the fact that Mr Fordham was twisting in the wind. He had engaged in all sorts of unnecessary interventions. The Deputy Premier of Victoria, on one view of the matter, was in breach of his statutory obligations and the Government was not prepared to expose him to any more parliamentary cross-examination. That was why it decided that 1 October was the most propitious date, because of all these other distractions. But let us not be distracted for a moment from the pitiful record of the VEDC. What it has done in about six areas is to provide the funds to get into joint ventures for which there is absolutely no economic justification. A classic example, and the one that will bring Mr Fordham down, is Wallace International Ltd. I have a copy of the prospectus here. It says on the outside:

SPEECH.PARA: The assets of this new company to be floated are of an intangible nature. For this and other reasons appearing in the prospectus, investment in shares offered pursuant to this prospectus are to be considered speculative.

If one then looks at the financial statements, which it says have not been audited for any period, one finds that there has been an operating loss every year since 1983 and if it had not been for government grants and the sale of distribution licence rights, the company would have been in the red from the date of its inception. If one excluded advances to related companies and the so-called intellectual property scientific knowledge, the assets of the company would have barely exceeded $600m. On the strength of that the Government, aided and abetted by Mr Fordham, lent $1m, secured by a factory which had not even been purchased, and by a life assurance and disability policy over the founder of the company. When that money was finally repaid, another $10m was advanced to the company.

Mr Fordham then insisted that the company should seek to recover its funds and that the VEDC should be repaid some of the moneys that the company had been lent. In fact, when the prospectus was issued there was litigation already under way against the company, which was not mentioned at all in the prospectus but was clearly known to Mr Fordham. Nonetheless, what the Minister did was to authorise the VEDC to sub-underwrite half of the $25m float of that company. The Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce, who is at the table, should know it well, because my information is that not only did Wallace International get its hand into the Victorian Government till for $12.5m by way of sub-underwriting, but it also got an export market development grant on the basis of false and misleading information. Projected sales of products which it submitted in support of the application were found to be wildly in excess of its actual achievement. The VEDC Board was not notified of Mr Fordham's approval of the authorisation of the sub-underwriting agreement until 3 1/2 months after Mr Fordham had made the decision. The full Board was asked to endorse the deal retrospectively and to pay the money owing. Only a few hours after the board had ratified the original agreement and three days before the VEDC paid for the shares it was obliged to buy, as a sub-underwriter, a copy of the share register listing the VEDC as Wallace International's second biggest shareholder.

The Government intervened quite improperly. Again it is impossible to understand why, other than that it had some sort of notion that it could pick winners; that somehow there was a role for government to be played in this area. There is nothing smart about Wallace International; there is nothing unique about its business. It is just another little outfit that the Government wanted to help. Although I do not have time to dwell on the detail, there are half a dozen other examples of companies that have gone to the wall, that have resulted in very many millions of dollars still remaining owing to the creditors, and the creditors are ultimately the taxpayers of Victoria. They are the ones who will voice their displeasure in no uncertain terms on 1 October and they will demonstrate why Australian taxpayers are suffering at the hands of the Victorian Government's incompetence.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BUTTON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce)

TALK.START.PARA: —There has been a touch of hyperbole and exaggeration in what Senator Alston has had to say about the Victorian Government today. I can understand that he, as a Victorian senator, has certain preselection considerations to look after and certain tribal loyalties, as I put it earlier, which he has to carry out. It is a sad fact that not many people in the Victorian Liberal Party, even in the parliamentary party, have the same sort of tribal loyalties to the leader.

SPEECH.PARA: I was in a hairdresser's last week-that is a very interesting piece of information for the Senate-and the barber said to me, `You know, the last politician I had in here was a member of the State Liberal parliamentary Party. I told him, ``You've got to get rid of that Jeff Kennett''. Do you know what he said to me? He said, ``We're working on it as hard as we can''.' That is the sort of tribal loyalty that exists to the Leader of the Liberal Party in Victoria. Senator Alston, as he is from Victoria, has to go through this ritual in the Senate in order to try to help his desperate Victorian colleagues. It reminds me of Henry IV, Part I, when the Welsh leader, Glendower, said, `I can summon spirits from the vasty deep', and Hotspur said, `Yes, yes but will they come?'. Senator Alston is trying to summon spirits from the vasty deep, but of course the question is: will they come?

On 2 October the Victorian people will be confronted with a choice between the existing Government in Victoria and a disunited, divided, lacklustre group of people who have been sitting on the Opposition benches for years and have no profile at all in the minds of the Victorian people other than as buffoons. In pursuit of helping his Victorian colleagues, Senator Alston is up to old Liberal Party tricks-getting things wrong, mucking things up, not doing his homework. Today he made a big point about an article in Saturday's Weekend Australian about the debts of the Victorian Government. He failed to refer to a correction in yesterday's Australian.

TALK.START.PARA: —By Jolly.

—No, not by Jolly; by the Australian-a very important correction in yesterday's Australian. In the weekend newspaper an article purported to describe Victorian State debt. It was wrong in a number of respects, but Senator Alston came in here relying on it. Yesterday a very coy correction reported the correct position. That is, if one looks at gross debt as a percentage of gross State product of Victoria, Victoria had the second lowest debt burden of the four States measured using this ratio. This measure is the real test of indebtedness because it shows whether one can repay a debt.
—Says Jolly.

—No, it has nothing to do with the Treasurer of Victoria, it has to do with the Australian. That measure shows whether one has the income to repay a debt. No one questions Victoria's capacity in this regard. The international credit rating agency, Moody's, to which Senator Alston again referred, has awarded Victoria, and has continued to award Victoria, the highest--
—Are you pretending that Moody's somehow did not recite eight different indicators where Victoria was in trouble?

—Senator Alston is excited because he is wrong and he is upset. He set out to help his Victorian colleagues and, as usual, he has mucked it up. It is Hobson's choice whether one would want the Victorian representatives in the Senate or the Victorian representatives in the State Parliament. In terms of competence in getting their facts right, they are all of the same colour. That is why, no doubt, Senator Alston supports them. He feels a warm glow of mutual ignorance. Senator Alston keeps on trying to interject because he does not like the facts. Moody's has consistently awarded Victoria the highest credit rating that any State can achieve. The reason for that is that Victoria's debt is coming down and is now just over half the debt to gross domestic product (GDP) ratio that honourable senators opposite had in the so-called golden days of dear old Henry Bolte, when Victoria was described as the jewel in the Liberal crown.
—Are you pretending this report does not exist?

—It is all right for Senator Alston to brandish documents and try to interrupt what I am saying because it is very unpalatable to him. The fact is that the ratio is half that which existed in the golden days of Henry Bolte, when Victoria was the jewel in the crown of the Liberal Party. That is how good honourable senators opposite were in government. There is, of course, significant capacity for people such as Senator Alston to make mischief with those sorts of comparisons. The Opposition's performance here today shows it in its true colours.

SPEECH.PARA: I want to refer to a few facts about Victoria which Senator Alston ought to listen to. After 27 years of Liberal rule in Victoria, economic growth in that State is as good as it has ever been. When John Cain came to power in Victoria there was one crane on the Melbourne city skyline. Today building activity in the central business district of Melbourne is at an all time high.

TALK.START.PARA: —And relatively the lowest of any State in Australia.
—Senator Short will get his opportunity. He is a sacked ex-spokesman on finance for the Liberal Party. He will have the opportunity to get his figures right when he speaks.
—You cannot be a sacked ex unless you are tautologous.

—Perhaps I am tautologous, but I wanted to make the point doubly clear that it was Senator Short who was speaking. Growth in real private business investment since the Cain Government came to power has been 46 per cent compared with 25 per cent for the rest of the country. Total exports for Victoria have risen by 75 per cent in real terms since 1982-83. For 63 consecutive months Victoria has recorded the lowest unemployment rate of any State.
—Tell us about employment growth-the lowest in Australia.

—I am moving on to that. Wait. More than 286,000 new jobs have been created in Victoria since April 1983. Victoria's share of national business investment is expected to be 29.9 per cent in 1988-89-more than eight points higher than the figure of six years ago. I am disappointed that Senator Alston has failed to recognise the achievements of the Victorian Government. They have not been overlooked by the Victorian public. Victorians know that in the last six years the State's economic growth has been 1 1/3 times that of the rest of Australia. There is always resort to phoney numbers to attack the Government's record.

SPEECH.PARA: Mr Kennett has claimed that Victoria is the highest taxing of the Australian States. He supports that by putting together a whole lot of charges, such as those for veterinary licences, which have gone up. On the basis of examples such as that, he says that Victorian taxes have gone up more than taxes anywhere else. That is an example of what is called, in economic debate, user pays. Does the Liberal Party believe in user pays? I thought it did. Honourable senators opposite are always bleating about user pays. That is what the Victorian Government has done in relation to professional charges. Jeff Kennett then says, `This is an increase in taxes'. For goodness sake, do honourable senators opposite not know the difference? I understand that Jeff Kennett might not, but honourable senators opposite ought to. They at least have the opportunity to listen to views of people such as myself and are able to get an advantage in that way.

These figures on tax have been vastly misrepresented. According to the Australian Statistician, Victoria's per capita taxation in 1987-88 was $971. That is well below the figure for New South Wales of $1,009. Apart from that sort of nonsense, the Opposition's numbers are ludicrous. It ignores the principle of fiscal equalisation enshrined in the federal system which ensures that the less populous States appear to have the lowest per capita taxes. A more consistent measure of the share of a State's product being taken by the Government is the statistics published in the Federal Budget Papers. They give State own source revenue as a percentage of gross State product. So taking away the jargon, these figures show how much of the State economy each State government takes for its own purposes. The most up to date version of those numbers shows that Victoria's State Government own source revenue is the fourth highest of any State. However, if State revenue per head is taken into account, Victoria does one better. On that measure, it is the fifth highest of the six States. The State that has been administered for the longest time by the Liberal Party, Tasmania, has the highest per capita revenue collections of all States. The Cain Government has also shown up well in keeping revenue collections to a minimum. I think that one can justifiably make the claim that, under the present Government, Victoria is a low tax State-perhaps the second lowest tax State. During the period from 1982-83 to 1987-88, the time that the present Victorian Government has been in office, Victoria was the lowest of the six States in relation to tax.

On the question of taxes and charges, let me make the point that the government charges component of the Melbourne consumer price index (CPI)-a Commonwealth statistic, Senator Alston-has increased by only 44.2 per cent since March 1982, compared to 59.4 per cent for Australia as a whole. This year, the Victorian Government is committed to ensuring that Victorian families face no overall increases in costs in relation to a basket of government services, including electricity, gas, Melbourne and Metropolitan Board of Works rates, motor vehicle registration fees, as well as urban public transport charges. I make the same point about increases in electricity, gas and Board of Works charges this year-they are well below the forecast inflation rate and compare most favourably with New South Wales, where those costs have increased by 9.1 and 8 per cent respectively.

One could go on making these comparisons in terms of figures, and so on. It is very easy to talk about figures in hypothetical terms, but the real measure is whether or not the runs are on the board. The real question concerns the choice between a lacklustre Opposition, led by a buffoon and supported by an inaccurate senator, and a government which has exercised great economic responsibility and which has done some other very important things in terms of laying the basis for a sound economy in Australia for years to come.

Senator Alston touched on the matter of WorkCare, and I want to say just one thing about that. It is true that the Victorian Government saw fit, and I believe responsibly so, to make some changes to the WorkCare arrangements. I think it is very much to its credit that it has done so. The real question is: what is the choice in Victoria? What does the Liberal Party in Victoria offer as an alternative to WorkCare? What will it do? Mr Kennett does not know. Does Senator Alston know of an alternative to WorkCare?

TALK.START.PARA: —It is not hard to work out.

—Well, I guess the honourable senator ought to get on the telephone to Jeff Kennett and tell him. People in Victoria have only three days to work it out, and so Senator Alston had better get down there and tell them-because they are not about working it out on the back of a chequebook or something like that. They want to know what the alternative government stands for. That is the only point I want to make about WorkCare.

SPEECH.PARA: I also want to make a point about the Victorian Economic Development Corporation (VEDC). It has provided $580m in loans to over 1,600 Victorian companies. I do not shrink for a moment from the fact that in a program like that, from time to time, misjudgments and failures will occur.

TALK.START.PARA: —There certainly have been.
—Senator Alston has found one; that is all he referred to in his speech.
—I didn't have time; there are heaps of them.

—The honourable senator did not have time, he says. However, some 1,600 Victorian companies have benefited from Victorian Economic Development Corporation assistance of one kind or another. Some 40,000 new jobs have been created for Victorians, many in the manufacturing and agricultural sectors. The bottom line is that, when the VEDC makes a loan to a company, it tries to arrange appropriate securities. I do not want to go into the details of the--
—I'll bet you don't.

—No, I do not want to go into the criticism that the honourable senator has made about Wallace International and the VEDC loan. We could debate that endlessly. But that is not the point about the VEDC program. The point about that program is that it has assisted 1,600 companies and it has helped in the creation of 40,000 new jobs. As I say, one does not retreat from the fact that from time to time a body like that will make mistakes. As regards the public transport system, other senators on this side of the House will refer to that matter.

SPEECH.PARA: This whole matter began with an ill- informed analysis based on an incorrect newspaper report by Senator Alston-the loyal senator from Victoria. He is loyal to Jeff Kennett as not many Victorian parliamentarians are. He is as loyal to Jeff Kennett as the National President of the Liberal Party is not. At least Senator Alston has a preselection-and he has to look after it. The honourable senator launched his whole criticism on the basis of an incorrect report that he has inadequately analysed. That is the sort of standard that we expect from the Liberal Party Opposition, both here and in Victoria-and we have rightly come to expect it because that is the standard that has applied for the past six years.

The real choice that Victorians are faced with is whether they want an honest government, a very honest government committed to good management, which looks ahead and which will build new industries, as it has done, better than any other State--

TALK.START.PARA: —Like Alcoa. Do you support joint ventures there?

—Yes, like Alcoa. It is looking to the future. This choice is to be made by what I believe to be an intelligent electorate, and in that circumstance I have no doubt about what the choice will be. The basis of it all, of course, is the question of good economic management. I do not call in aid many third party referees. Senator Alston called none in aid. However, let me quote one source-and I refer to comments that were made by Mr Bob Ansett, a distinguished businessman, committed to private sector enterprise and committed to deregulation. On 8 September, Mr Ansett had this to say:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . the thing that matters to me is strong economic management-
and elsewhere he makes the point that all the other issues flow from that, that law and order and all those things follow from that-
and so I guess I would have to be persuaded that the coalition is going to be able to more efficiently manage the State than the Government-as yet I haven't been convinced of that . . .

I have seen nothing to suggest that Mr Ansett has changed his mind or to suggest that intelligent voters in Victoria will not be totally persuaded by that central issue in regard to the Victorian State election. Mr Ansett refers, of course, to the coalition: Mr Kennett cannot even make up his mind whether he is going to lead a coalition or lead the Liberal Party alone-if he were successful in this election. He cannot even make up his mind about that issue, three days before an election. If it was a coalition, it would be disastrous for the Liberal Party.

TALK.START.PARA: —Don't worry. It won't be. Your fears can be put to rest.

—Well, we have Senator Alston's views about that-as we have those of the President of the Liberal Party, Mr Elliott, and all the others. Everywhere one looks in the Liberal Party there is a different view about whether there would be a coalition or not, and now we have flushed out Senator Alston's views. I am sure it will be very reassuring for everyone in Victoria that Senator Alston is of that view.

SPEECH.PARA: This attempt that has been made by the Opposition is a specious one, based on bad figures and bad material, to influence the choice of the Victorian people. I have great confidence in them, and I have no doubt that the Victorian Government will be re-elected, because it is a very good State government. I do not think there is any threat to the Victorian Government from Senator Alston.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The Minister's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Powell Sen J.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —Earlier today I had some discussions with a group of fine young Australians who are attending a seminar in Canberra. Members of this group from all States have achieved prominence under the Queen Elizabeth Silver Jubilee Trust. This morning they spent a few moments in this House and in the other place. They said to me that they were quite amazed to hear Federal parliamentarians going on about the Victorian elections. Indeed, they expressed not just amazement but some considerable disapproval, which I would echo.

SPEECH.PARA: It seems to me to be a considerable misuse of this place, which we often see, that a considerable amount of time has been spent this afternoon discussing the Victorian election-time which could be used for substantive debate on major issues and for dealing with the enormous backlog of legislation introduced last session and during other sessions of this Parliament. However, what we are seeing this afternoon is an all too common practice. We have become accustomed to irrelevant grandstanding, especially before elections, by-elections, referenda and so on.

The Australian Democrats feel that it would be much more relevant to the Senate's responsibilities if we took the first line of the matter of public importance proposed by Senator Alston and discussed the burdens on our national economy, especially in relation to national debt. We might then get some real debate on the major issues, which of course only the Democrats seem to want to address. I refer to issues such as the fact that our gross foreign debt-that is, the amount that various governments, public enterprises and the private sector have borrowed overseas-rose from $6 billion in 1975 to $67 billion in 1985 and $115 billion at the end of the last financial year. Much of this debt is short term. In fact, the Bank of International Settlements believes that around 40 per cent of lending to Australia by foreign banks has a maturity of less than one year.

Since Treasurer Keating made his `banana republic' statement in April 1986, economic policy in general and fiscal policy in particular in Australia have been designed to gain the approval of international bankers. Obviously these foreign banks would not continue to lend to Australia if they believed that our economy would not be able to earn or borrow the foreign currency to repay them. To keep the banks lending to us, the Government pursues an economic strategy that maintains the bankers' confidence. Bankers would like to see Australia increasing its foreign currency earnings through increased exports. If that happened, we could stop borrowing to pay for our past borrowings. The Government has not been able to achieve a substantial increase in exports or a reduction in imports. Instead, it has attempted to placate the bankers by reducing expenditure in areas such as welfare, reducing wages, deregulating the financial system and producing bigger Budget surpluses. Therefore, average and low income Australians bear the brunt of reducing our foreign debt.

However, if we analyse the composition of our foreign debt, we could see an alternative course of action. Currently, 54 per cent of our foreign debt is due to private sector borrowing. Daryl Dixon has argued that Alan Bond alone, through his companies, has incurred at least 10 per cent of Australia's private foreign debt. On the day of the Federal Budget, the Bond Corporation announced a record profit of $355m, on which $4m is due as income tax. Foreign borrowing is one way in which the largest private companies can reduce their tax liabilities to as little as the one per cent that the Bond Corporation will pay this year. I am talking about the practice of Australian companies borrowing overseas and then claiming the cost of borrowing as a tax deduction by the use of negative gearing. This Government has shown no inclination at all to stop that; nor has the Opposition. We do not hear Opposition senators screaming about that.

Only the Australian Democrats seem to want to make these points on the real issues of foreign debt. We have pointed out that a great deal of our foreign debt is tax driven and has little to do with generating new investment or production. As I say, both the Government and the Opposition seem comfortable in this environment. We are now seeing further accumulation with deregulation and the encouragement of foreign investment, mainly through the purchase of Australian property and businesses. In fact, we are looking at the potential replacement of our foreign debt problem with a foreign ownership problem, a problem which if it is not considered, will have to be faced by future governments and by future generations of Australians. They are the major issues of the Australian economy and our indebtedness which the Democrats believe we should be addressing in this place.

The matter of public importance we are debating concerns the issue of Victoria's debt. That, of course, raises a question. During the Victorian election campaign Senator Stone has claimed that that debt was at a level of $23 billion. Senator Stone in his interesting visit raised the spectre of a coalition government, which of course has been raised by other august people in the Liberal and National parties, not the least being the President of the Liberal Party of Australia, Mr Elliott. It raises the spectre of uncertainty in the event of the loss of the election by the current Australian Labor Party (ALP) Government under Mr Cain. Who would be in the Cabinet in that event? Which portfolios would be held by which members of parliament? Which policies would be in place-those of the Victorian National Party or those of the Victorian Liberal Party? What sort of compromise would be reached? Those questions are of great concern to many Victorians. For instance, strong claims are being made for the Conservation, Forests and Lands portfolio by the National Party, which has a policy very much at odds with the policy forged by Marie Tehan, who has responsibility for that portfolio in the Liberal Party. It is a policy with which environmentalists are considerably more comfortable, as opposed to the National Party policy, which is the usual slash and burn policy we are accustomed to from the conservative side of politics. The question of which policy would hold sway is very much in the minds of Victorians.

This morning's Age contains the National Party and Australian Democrats policies for women. I am quite sure that Victorians would be very concerned that in the event of a coalition government being elected the Deputy Premier would be Peter Ross-Edwards. I must say that he is a nice man and a long time acquaintance of mine; but in terms of policy for women, the article in the Age commences by saying:
Peter Ross-Edwards basically believes that a woman's place is in the home rather than in the House.
The article also says:
. . . children, in his eyes, are an undeniable and unavoidable impediment to their political success.

As a mother of four I take considerable exception to that comment. I am sure that many other Victorian women would do likewise. The article points out that Mr Ross-Edwards was persuaded to employ a sole male parent at one point. He was quite astonished that this remarkable fellow made arrangements, organised backups and indeed `overcame that burden he was carrying'. I say to my female colleagues who are in the chamber that that sole male parent was not the only person in employment anywhere in Australia to overcome that inevitable burden.

Other issues were raised in that article. Interestingly enough, Mr Ross-Edwards takes great umbrage at the interviewer associating him and the National Party with the Country Women's Association. The article quotes him as saying:
Don't try and give us the image of just the CWA.

Frankly, I would be happy to have the image of the CWA, which is made up of a very hard-working group of people with a very broad range of policies and actions in the community. Mr Ross-Edwards is also quoted as saying:

Smart women can have it both ways . . . `They get a lot of privileges and advantages in life and they've all the rights of men, given to them very graciously by their fellow employees and by their husbands and friends'.
I think Victorian women at least, and many fair minded men, would be very concerned at those kinds of policies being pursued by a coalition government in Victoria.

Since I am quoting from this morning's article in the Age on women's policies, I shall quote the opening lines of the report of the Australian Democrats policy for women, as articulated by Dr Di Bretherton. The report says that the policy reads like a collaboration between Germaine Greer, Gloria Steinhem and Dale Spender. Having had some input to that policy, I find that a rather complimentary analysis of the tone of the women's policy of the Australian Democrats.

Senator Stone came to Victoria and talked about the debt which is the subject of Senator Alston's matter of public importance. This, of course, raises the question of what is or is not a debt and what the debt might be. I understand that this morning Mr Kennett warned on the radio that a Liberal government may well have to increase taxes because a hidden State debt may exist. Obviously, the Victorian Liberal Party has in mind using the Greiner discovery of a hidden debt to justify a large percentage of potential tax increases that we can expect if the ALP should fall on 1 October.

As has been clearly pointed out by the Victorian Treasurer, Mr Jolly-I would suggest that he is in a position to know the facts-the election promises of the Liberals and Nationals have crashed through the billion dollar barrier; yet it is those same co- alition parties that are running around warning about a $23 billion debt figure. I am sure that right now the Victorian Auditor is sitting around scratching his head wondering where all that is hidden. The answer is that the debt on the scale being proclaimed by the coalition will come into being only if it comes into government. It is very easy to promise a billion dollars, but it is much easier-as Mr Greiner discovered-to increase taxes to meet a debt brought into being to meet election promises. The bottom line is that the most effective planned economy in the country is that of Victoria.

I refer briefly to an article by Kenneth Davidson which was published as far back as last April in which he made a point which Senator Button made about relative taxes and charges and referred to the way in which the Victorian Government has brought management under control through the Department of Management and Budget. Indeed, Kenneth Davidson called the setting up of Cabinet committees to set economic priorities, the consensus within government on the targets of government and the full understanding of people throughout the Government to the goal, which has resulted in high levels of employment and growth-not to mention the cranes in the Melbourne city area-an administrative revolution.

The Victorian Economic Development Corporation (VEDC) was mentioned in Senator Alston's matter of public importance. It is important to note that the end result of the Liberal Party having found some chinks in the armour will be an unfortunate one, given that those businesses which are successfully involved with the VEDC have now had doubt cast on their names. With such a corporation there will be risks; they are inevitable. It is a shame that those companies which are successful, having been assisted by the VEDC, should now be called into question.

I think that Victorians will reject the sorts of things that Senator Alston has said. They will not do so lightly. I do not suggest for a moment that the Cain Government is perfect. If I did I would not be involved as an Australian Democrat in the election campaign in Victoria. Transport, which was raised by Senator Alston, is a good example of where-apart from the fact that open warfare on the industrial relations scene would be the result of a Liberal government-there is no innovation to the extent that there ought to be on behalf of the Labor Government. It adopts the attitude `steady as she goes', which is not good enough. I think that Victorians will be looking for alternatives. They will find them, in their search for a fair go, in the alternatives offered by the Australian Democrats in this election campaign. We offer a broad range of economic policies which promote long term indicative planning, a cost effective, non-intrusive supportive role of government and the economic development of Victoria. In this election campaign those are the sorts of alternatives which will be looked to by Victorians who will reject the rhetoric of Senator Alston and his colleagues and who will not say to the Cain Government, `You have done a perfect job', but rather, `We want to pass a message on that there can be another way'.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable senator's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Short Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Cain Labor Government in Victoria has brought that State to the point of financial bankruptcy. The level of government debt has reached unprecedented levels. Taxes and charges have risen to their highest levels in Victoria's history. Public bodies have had their assets stripped from them and the proceeds of those asset sales have been squandered on profligate spending. The Victorian Public Service has been bloated by an employment increase three times that of other States. The deliberate pursuit of hard core socialist policies, coupled with quite criminal economic mismanagement, has resulted in outstanding liabilities totalling $2.9 billion under the Government's no-fault workers compensation scheme called WorkCare. It has led to the public transport system losing $3m every day of the year. It has put at risk hundreds of millions of taxpayers' dollars through the operations of the Victorian Economic Development Corporation and, more recently, the Victorian Equity Trust.

SPEECH.PARA: Fear of having some of these matters debated in the Victorian Parliament was the overriding reason why Premier Cain called this totally premature State election. Indeed, so concerned was he that he did not even allow the Parliament to sit to pass the State Budget-a Budget which he said he would stand by but which he has already made obsolete before it has even been passed, by the disclosure of $750m of additional spending commitments made during the election campaign; commitments undertaken in a desperate, panic-driven attempt to bribe voters to support Labor on Saturday. In doing so, Mr Cain has further compounded the fiscal irresponsibility for which he and his Government are now notorious. No Australian State in living memory has been on the brink of financial bankruptcy as a result of economic mismanagement as is Victoria in September 1988.

My colleagues in today's debate have already detailed, and will do so after me, some of the relevant statistics. I propose to repeat some of them because they bear repeating time and time again before it is too late, but I will concentrate my remarks on perhaps the greatest single disaster of them all-namely, the Government's socialist system of WorkCare. First I turn to the overall statistics. Far and away the major legacy of the economic vandalism of the Cain Government is an enormous level of public debt. That debt is now $23.64 billion. In more understandable terms, that figure represents a debt of $5,519 for every man, woman and child in Victoria. The debt is now more than double what it was when the Cain Government came to office. This year alone the Government expects the debt to increase by an additional $1.6 billion.

This huge increase in Victoria's debt has not happened by accident. It has been the result of a deliberate policy of pump priming by the Cain Government. This pump priming policy is highly interventionist; it is archaic; it is hugely expensive; and it is contrary to the policies now being pursued by virtually every government in the world. The debt has been incurred to fund non-productive expenditure, despite the fact that record levels of interest rates have made the borrowings even more costly. There is no doubt, as I think Senator Alston mentioned, that interest rates will rise again as soon as the Victorian election and the Oxley by-election the following week are out of the way.

The result of this huge debt increase is to produce a debt servicing crisis in Victoria. The interest commitment alone, as shown in the 1988 Budget Papers, is $1.3 billion. Since the Cain Government came to office in 1982 the interest bill has increased, on average, by 13 per cent every year. This year it will increase by a further 13 1/3 per cent. Even that figure is derived after a deliberate fiddling of the accounts by the Government. The Government is now borrowing and selling off assets to enable it to meet its interest commitments on previous borrowings. The State Auditor-General reported, as far back as 1985-86-more than two years ago-that $254m of capital funds, mainly borrowings and asset sale proceeds, had been used for recurrent purposes and predominantly to pay interest.

Debt servicing costs are now the most serious financial problem for Victoria's major statutory authorities. These authorities have been forced to increase their debt at an alarming rate. Often the debt has come in the form of foreign borrowings. This has imposed grave exchange rate risks on the statutory authorities. Indeed, last year the statutory authorities, and therefore the Victorian taxpayers and consumers of gas, electricity, water, sewerage and other essential services, lost $700m through exchange rate losses alone. They also lost $1,000m on the stock market through statutory authorities being forced by the Government to invest in high risk share portfolios, including, in particular, in the nine months leading up to the stock market crash of October 1987.

Interest repayment commitments are now equivalent to well over 50 per cent of the total revenue of the State Electricity Commission of Victoria and the Melbourne and Metropolitan Board of Works. This is the result of a deliberate policy by the Cain Government. It is a policy motivated by the goal of using Victoria's statutory authorities as sources of revenue and sources of hidden taxation. This year alone such hidden taxes will total more than $600m-a fivefold increase since the Cain Government came to office. This year alone they are budgeted to rise by a further 13 1/2 per cent. These taxes are being ripped out of the statutory authorities and therefore out of the pockets of Victorian taxpayers and consumers, despite the fact that the authorities have consistently performed worse than in other States because of the incompetence of the Cain Government. In 1986 the combined losses of Victoria's public trading enterprises totalled $1,419m. Last year that total was just less than $1,000m.

As part of this economic vandalism, this criminal economic incompetence, assets worth many billions of dollars have been sold and the funds used to fuel the Government's continuing financial profligacy. The cost has been quite horrendous. For example, the Government sold $600m worth of railway rolling stock to foreign buyers. Then it leased back the rolling stock, and the lease costs totalled $1,200m over only a five-year period. To make the situation even worse, not one cent of that $600m was used to reduce Victoria's outstanding debt.

The Cain Government has also been party to some sale and lease-back deals that can only be described as shonky in the extreme. The most notable is perhaps the Austrian train scam, although it is by no means unique. Late in 1987, Victorian Treasurer Jolly sold rolling stock to an Austrian bank for $200m. On the very same day he bought the rolling stock back for $200m. The stock was therefore regarded as having been exported to Victoria, even though it never left our tracks. As a result, some European investor gained a very substantial tax advantage and $6.5m of the European tax avoidance proceeds was passed to the Victorian Government. I ask you, Mr Acting Deputy President: who would be prepared to do business with this Labor Government in Victoria?

Time prevents me from detailing more such sordid sagas, as I want now to turn to the matter of Victoria's notorious WorkCare scheme-a no fault workers compensation system introduced by the Cain Government in 1985. WorkCare is a financial disaster of the greatest magnitude. After its first two years of operations, unfunded liabilities totalled $1.76 billion. During the just completed third year, 1987-88, unfunded liabilities rose by a further $430m-a further increase of 25 per cent-to the level of $2.136 billion. That figure is equal to $16,000 for each of Victoria's registered employers and represents $500 for every Victorian.

The facts about WorkCare are these: WorkCare now owes $2,900m on claims it has received or expects to receive. It has only $774m in funds to pay for those claims and its cash surplus is only $50m. This means that WorkCare requires $3 in addition to every $1 that it currently has available simply to meet its obligations. When WorkCare was established in 1985 the Cain Government said that it would be fully self-funding over a 10-year period. The Government also gave a commitment that the average levy rate of 2.4 per cent of payroll to be paid by all employers would remain as a fixed maximum levy for the first five years. While employers are still paying this average 2.4 per cent levy, the true cost of this scheme is closer to 5 per cent of the payroll. While the full effect of the shortfall will take a number of years to develop completely, the first substantial impact could be as early as the current financial year, when WorkCare may run short of the money required to meet its claims payments. On current trends, WorkCare will continue to lose approximately $700m each year. A recent independent review of WorkCare which has come into my possession says:

If the Government maintains its commitment to both a 2.4% maximum average levy rate for the first 5 years and full funding over 10 years, and makes no further changes to the system, we estimate that the average levy rate for the second five years will be 7.1% of payroll.

WorkCare has not yet produced its annual report for 1987-88. However, I have a copy of parts of the third draft of the report. The draft claims that there has been an improvement in the scheme's financial position in 1987-88 but says that, despite this:
. . . it cannot be concluded that the scheme is now on target to achieve its primary financial objective of full funding at 2.4% of remuneration over its first 10 years of operation.

That would have to be the understatement of the year. Apart from these statistics, which paint a clear picture of financial disaster, there is also a very unhealthy smell surrounding the operations of WorkCare. This applies to its ethics, its integrity and its lack of managerial competence. It is of the very essence of any acceptable compensation scheme that the various parties to the scheme be completely at arm's length and independent of one another. Apart from the ethics involved and the need to ensure that there are not conflicts of interest, the secrecy provisions of the WorkCare legislation are such as to require arm's length operations as well.

It is therefore a matter of considerable concern that the company which is probably the leading agency in Victoria acting on behalf of the Accident Compensation Commission, namely Mercantile Mutual Insurance (Australia) Ltd, appears to have a financial interest in an investigation company named Probe Investigations Pty Ltd. Material in my possession indicates that, at least until very recently, Probe has been carrying out the vast majority of investigations for Mercantile Mutual. Indeed, in certain areas, namely, Bendigo and Shepparton, I am advised that Probe carries out all the investigations for Mercantile Mutual.

In addition, Mercantile Mutual has an associate company, Corporate Safety and Health Services Pty Ltd, to which it makes direct referrals. It is difficult to avoid the conclusion that Mercantile Mutual is referring people to Corporate Safety and Health Services on the basis of information gained by virtue of being a WorkCare agency. This is a matter that requires urgent investigation. I am amazed that the Accident Compensation Commission has not conducted such an investigation as yet. On the face of it, interlinked operations of this nature appear to involve major conflicts of interest. They raise major questions of ethics and business morality and they also involve questions of legality under the existing WorkCare legislation.

There are many other things that I wanted to say about WorkCare, but time has prevented me.
