Let me give just one example of the extraordinary lack of financial controls existing in WorkCare at the moment. I have in my possession a copy of a cheque dated 29 August 1988 paid by WorkCare to a doctor for services rendered. Fortunately, he is an honest doctor, so he returned the cheque. I say `fortunately' because that cheque was written out for an amount of $290,788. How on earth could such a mistake occur? It could not have occurred if basic financial procedures were being followed. The Cain Government has brought the State of Victoria to the brink of financial disaster.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable senator's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cooney Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Short has given a sweeping survey of the present workers compensation system. No doubt he wants to return to the one which introduced the need for reform. He wants to take the Metal Trades Industry Association back to the sorts of premiums which I am about to quote. I will quote what the Metal Trades Industry Association had to say about the old scheme, about the sorts of premiums that were charged under the scheme that no doubt Senator Alston and Senator Short want to go back to. A table put out by the Association shows that the premium in 1982-83 was $260,000. The annual wages for that year were $2,200,000. In the following year, under the scheme that Senator Alston wants us to go back to and that Senator Short wants in this form, the premium for company A was $1,130,000. The annual wage bill was $1,850,000. The premium increase was 334 per cent. Senator Short said that 2.4 per cent was not the real figure, it was something more like 4 or 5 per cent. Let us say that it was. We say that the maximum premium paid by any employer is 2.4 per cent; that is what it is now. This is the sort of scheme that Senator Alston and Senator Short have advocated we will return to. Breweries in Victoria under the old scheme that we have been asked to return to paid 24.51 per cent of their wages bill in premiums. They pay almost 25 per cent of their wages bill in premiums. Engineering industries pay 19.47 per cent; meatworks, 37.66 per cent; pastoralists, 15.72 per cent; farm and agriculture, just over 11 per cent; and sawmills and planing mills, 28.36 per cent. This WorkCare scheme has introduced a fall in premiums from those horrible levels-I will tell honourable senators why they are horrible in a minute-down to 2.4 per cent. No doubt the Opposition is speaking for Jeff Kennett and if he wins on Saturday-as always, that is a possibility-the Opposition wants us to go back to the situation where a terrible and crippling cost is placed on Victorian industry. We say 2.4 per cent. I do not know what Senator Cook has heard. Mr Elliott runs a brewery and it wants to charge him 24.5 per cent as distinct from what this Government is charging-2.4 per cent. It wants to charge the meatworks 37.6 per cent, compared with our 2.4 per cent.
—Where are these figures from?

—These are figures provided by the Insurance Council of Australia and the Accident Compensation Corporation of New Zealand. We give the New Zealand figures to compare with what was being charged in Victoria. Since Senator Short has raised that matter I say that, while we were charging breweries 24.5 per cent, New Zealand was charging 1.45 per cent, and so on. Yet here we have the Opposition-speaking on behalf of Jeff Kennett I presume-wanting to go back to a situation where there will be such ruinous impositions placed on Victorian industry which will take it back to the days when the Liberals were in power. Does the Opposition want to hear about the great record? This is private business investment under the previous Liberal Government. Each year private business investment increases by a certain amount. It is measured in percentages. In the 10 years before the Cain Government came to power the percentage increase each year-that is, the extra amount that was put into private investment in Victoria-was 0.3 per cent compared with 2.1 per cent for the rest of Australia. The Cain Government came into power-that is, the supposed socialist hordes-and the figure goes up each year to the projected estimate this year of 12.8 per cent compared with the projected estimate for the rest of Australia of 4.7 per cent. Here we have it. It was 0.3 per cent under the Liberals, of whom Jeff Kennett is an eminent member. I am talking about private investment, not the public sector. Part of the reason for that increase is the sensible approach that this Government has taken to workers compensation.

SPEECH.PARA: The other point I want to talk about concerning workers compensation, which has been roundly criticised today, is that this was a package-I will come to the package-which we had to get through the Victorian Parliament at a time when fortuitous circumstances were such that we had power in the upper House. It only occurred for a short period. We would not have got this reform through if the Liberals and the National Party had been in power. They would have resisted the package which was won and that was workers compensation, the payment of money. Secondly, it included safety legislation to make sure that workers in the factories were not ground down and made victims of unfenced machinery, slippery floors or over-heavy loads imposed upon them-those accidents which impose so terribly not only on the economic well-being of the State but on the social well-being of the people who live there. That great safety reform would have been resisted. The fewer accidents we have the less compensation we will have.

That great safety reform was got through at a time when the Liberals were not in a position to effectively resist it. At the same time, there was a move towards rehabilitation. This is the criticism of the scheme which the Opposition makes. No doubt, arising from that criticism there will be a lessening of the safety provisions, of the rehabilitation that has been brought in with this WorkCare program as a proper package to help not only the economic situation of the State or the industry which flourishes there-I have shown how it flourishes-but the continuing need to make sure that workers do not become victims of unsafe work practices. Apparently from what we can gather here today, the Opposition intends, speaking on behalf of Jeff Kennett and the Victorian Liberals, not only to throw aside that exciting reduction in premiums but also to lessen the safety provisions and the rehabilitation schemes.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is bankrupting the State.
—Senator Short says that we bankrupted the State. He no doubt gets those words from the--
—Who was the architect of the WorkCare scheme?

—Senator Short should just listen to this. He is taking his headlines from the Australian. I am indebted to Senator Maguire who pointed this article out to me. The headline in the Weekend Australian says, `Victorian debt burden nation's worst'. It is a very bold headline in the Weekend Australian and it is there for all the world to see. It is followed up in Monday's Australian with the headline `States must account for debt profligacy'. It takes every State except New South Wales to task. In this very indignant editorial of Monday, 26 September 1988, it takes to task the Victorian Government. On page 2 of the Australian on Tuesday, buried well down where it cannot be noticed-I thank Senator Maguire for pointing this out to me-appears the headline `Victorian debt correction'. The article states:

SPEECH.PARA: An article in The Weekend Australian which used several different measures of the debt burdens of the States made a mistake in reporting one of Victoria's ratios-that of gross debt as a percentage of gross State product. The correct position, that Victoria had the second lowest debt burden-
the second lowest, not the highest-
of the four States measured using this ratio, was shown in a table on page 8 of the same issue.

It made a very weak-willed effort to correct this statement. Senator Alston and Senator Short saw this article and said, `This gives us great scope for running a matter of public importance on Wednesday to help our good friend in the State, Jeff Kennett. We will run it. We will use the Australian'. Of course, they read the Weekend Australian. They read Monday's Australian. I think that we have to extend sympathy to them because it is not their fault but the fault of the Australian for showing this correction in such a poor place. Those honourable senators forgot the correction. They shot themselves in the foot. They brought on this matter of public importance without reading Tuesday's Australian. It is most unfortunate. The material they have got no doubt is all from the Australian. Unfortunately they did not read it all. I say for the third time that I am indebted to Senator Maguire for pointing this out.

The other thing I am indebted to Senator Maguire for pointing out, yet again, is that in regard to employment-not a thing that concerns Jeff Kennett but of concern for those of us who have some sort of compassion for our fellows in society-Victoria has had the lowest unemployment rate in Australia for 63 months. Therefore, people have a better chance of getting a job in Victoria than elsewhere. Honourable senators opposite then turned, with some sort of desperate futility, to the Victorian Economic Development Corporation. The reality is that the great success story of that development corporation can be illustrated to have occurred under the Minister Robert Fordham. Honourable senators opposite have talked about Wallace International Ltd, the pharmaceutical company. I will come back to that company. However, what about Australian NC. Automation Pty Ltd at Bayswater in Victoria? That company employs approximately 75 to 80 persons. I refer also to Little Desert Tours in Nhill, the Colonial Motor Inn at Halls Gap, Monsbent Pty Ltd at Benalla-which is Australia's latest and most modern chipboard factory. Companies in the country, as well as in the city, are being supported. I refer also to Hickory Fashions Pty Ltd at Burwood. They are all success stories.

The reality of the situation concerning the Wallace pharmaceutical company, which honourable senators opposite have clawed so desperately to in their remarks, is that the role of the Minister in that has been everything that could be expected of an honourable and dedicated Minister. Not only is he dedicated, may I say, to proper administration-there is no doubt about that-but also he is dedicated to keeping Victoria the foremost economic State in the Commonwealth. He deserves great praise for what he has done. He has been part of that great economic success which is Victoria and which I illustrate again by referring to figures I have already cited for private business investment. May I say in passing also that in looking at country Victoria there has been a 75 per cent increase in exports from Victoria. Farming product in Victoria last year was worth $4.4 billion. That production has doubled over five years.

The other thing honourable senators opposite have spoken about is Victorian transport. Victorian transport matters presently are part of the portfolio of one of Victoria's and, indeed, Australia's, most outstanding Ministers, Mr Kennan. He has a policy which has led to all sorts of things. For example, he has extended the Preston tram service to Bundoora. He has extended bus services and has given travel concessions. He has a plan for the future to make public transport better and more comfortable. Rolling stock has been replaced. Everybody agrees that things are going well. On the other hand, the Liberal Party policy is to start by sacking 7,000 people.

TALK.START.PARA: —How many?

—Seven thousand. That is only in the transport industry. I ask honourable senators whether they know what industrial relations have been like in Victoria under Labor? There has been a reduction of 80 per cent in industrial disputes since Labor came to power. In the building industry there has been a reduction of 88 per cent. Next Saturday, if unfortunately the Liberals win government, Victoria will be returned to the era when there was 0.3 per cent private investment, strikes were the order of the day and there was nothing but conflict and conflagration. People gave that away. Not only did private enterprise--
—Order! The honourable senator's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hamer Sen D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Senate is debating a matter of public importance in the following terms:

SPEECH.PARA: The serious burden to the national economy imposed by the extraordinarily high levels of public debt in Victoria, the onerous burden of Victorian State taxes and charges and the gross mismanagement of the Victorian economy as exemplified by the $2.1 billion unfunded liabilities of WorkCare, the horrendous losses approaching $1 billion per annum of the State transport system and the hundreds of millions of dollars put at risk by the bungled investment policies of the Victorian Economic Development Corporation.

It is a feature of Labor governments that they borrow recklessly to pay for current waste and leave it to future generations to pay their debts. This is happening with the Federal Government where Australia's gross overseas debt is more than $100,000m, making us the third most indebted country in the world. Interest payments alone on this massive debt are taking about one-third of our export income. We will go into overseas debt by a further $10 billion this year under the gross mismanagement of the Hawke Labor Government. This interest burden which we have to meet will increase still further.

Worse still, the Hawke Labor Government, although it talks a great deal about its economic skills, in fact has taken no effective step to correct the problems of our economy. Our inflation rate is still more than double that of our trading competitors. If our productivity is rising at all-for four successive years it did not rise at all-it is rising much more slowly than that of our competitors. Our interest rates are much higher than those of our competitors. Almost certainly they are being held down artificially and very unscrupulously by the Federal Government until the Victorian State election and the Oxley by-election are over, at which time they will jump again. It is a most disturbing picture, the full impact of which has not yet come home to the Australian public. However, it does explain why Mr Keating, a couple of years ago, was runner-up for the title of World's Worst Treasurer.

The same situation is occurring in Victoria. The statement we are discussing sets out some of the ways in which Victoria's resources are being recklessly wasted. In order to finance its wasteful expenditure, for instance, the Cain Labor Government has sold off $600m worth of rail transport rolling stock. It spent this money recklessly, as I said, and will leave future generations with having to lease the equipment back. Look at the figures. The Government sold rolling stock for $600m. It will spend $1,200m over the next five years leasing it back. It is both a reckless waste and gross financial mismanagement.

Some of the other things the Cain Labor Government has done in Victoria have involved sales of other assets, such as land reserved for freeways. It has sold assets worth more than $1,000m. What did the Government do with the money it raised? It did not use the money to reduce the State's indebtedness. The Government used it for current expenditure. In particular, it had to spend the money on paying the interest on the debts it had already incurred. If we wish to build freeways in the future, the Victorian taxpayers will have to buy back that land that the State Government so recklessly sold.

Let us look at some other expenditures and examples of economic mismanagement. There has been quite a lot of talk about WorkCare. Let us look at some simple figures. WorkCare lost $1.7 billion in the first 22 months of operation. Even with the changes proposed by the Cain Government it will have no assets at all by 1992. Government superannuation schemes have unfunded, vested liabilities of $6,000m. The new compulsory third party insurance scheme lost $100m in its first six months of operation. During the current campaign the Cain Labor Government has made $750m worth of promises which were not funded in the Budget. These are just examples of disastrous financial mismanagement by the Cain Labor Government.

The Government admits that the net State debt in Victoria is now $24,000m and it has more than doubled in the six years since Labor came to power. The present debt in Victoria is the equivalent of $5,519 for every man, woman and child in Victoria, and that is what the Government admits. The only area in which the Cain Labor Government has been creative has been in creative accounting. Most observers think the State debt is very substantially more than the figures admitted by the Labor Government. And, of course, interest payments on this debt have to be met. By whom? By the Victorian taxpayers, of course.

State taxation has more than doubled in the seven years that the Cain Labor Government has been in office; it has actually gone up by 139 per cent. If honourable senators opposite think that is misleading because of inflation, State taxation has increased in real terms in the seven years of the Cain Labor Government by 41.4 per cent. Victorians now pay more in State taxes per head of population than the residents of any other State. One of the worst aspects of the Cain Labor Government's administration is where the money has been going. It has primarily been going into jobs for the boys, into increased public sector employment. Between March 1984 and March 1988-the latest figures available-the increases in government employment in Victoria were three times the national average. That is where the State taxes are going. They are going into jobs for the boys.

Another of the worst aspects of the mismanagement of the Cain Labor Government's administration has been public transport. Despite billions of dollars having been poured into the public transport system, it suffers continuously from industrial disruption. Management is in turmoil, the trains in Melbourne are dirty and often unsafe, the service is unreliable and patronage levels are static or declining. I give just two statistics: over the five years to 1985-86 revenue from Victoria's rail system in real terms fell by 13 per cent, but expenditure grew by 47 per cent. So revenue has gone down and expenditure has gone up or, to put it another way, Victoria's level of cost recovery-the user pays principle which the Leader of the Government in the Senate, Senator Button, was very keen on when he spoke a few minutes ago-fell from 52 per cent in 1980-81, when the Liberal Government was in power, to 30 per cent in 1985-86.

TALK.START.PARA: —So you would put up transport fees, would you?

—I want a more efficient transport system so that we do not have to put up the fares. We have a thoroughly inefficient feather-bedded system. One of the worst aspects has been this: the transport system loses more than $1,000m a year through bad work practices and gross feather-bedding-aspects which the Cain Labor Government is not prepared to tackle. It governs not in the interests of Victorian travellers but at the direction of militant unions. An efficient transport system is essential to a State's economic performance. If a transport system is inefficient and expensive, costs rise throughout the economy, industries become less competitive and employment drops. The idea that employment can be created by feather-bedding in a key area like transport is economic lunacy.

SPEECH.PARA: Let us look at a couple of examples of feather-bedding or restrictive practices on our Melbourne city trains. Everyone knows that the guards, sitting at the rear of the train, are contributing nothing and have been contributing nothing for years. Yet the Government is not prepared to get rid of them. When it was suggested that there might be a window in the guard's compartment so that the guard could at least see what was going on in the carriage, the idea was rejected on the grounds that that would interfere with the privacy of the guard. Why will the Government not get rid of the guards? Everyone knows that they are not needed. The unions will not let it. I think ours will be the last significant rail system in the world to introduce automatic ticket vending machines on railway stations. Why have we been so slow in Victoria? Because the unions would not let them be installed, of course, and the Government was too weak to do anything about it.

The feather-bedding and overmanning, of course, cost money-money that could be either saved or diverted to more useful purposes, such as increased security on the trains or increased security at the stations. One of the reasons why train travel is not more popular-I have pointed out that we have declining patronage and that revenue and cost recovery are going down-is a fear of violence while on the trains or a fear of arriving late at night at a poorly lit and deserted railway station. Personally-I emphasise that this is a personal view-I would like to see the suburban rail system changed so that wherever possible railway stations are leased out to an all-night shopping system such as Seven-Eleven Food Stores, which is very keen to have sites where there is both parking and a flow of people. If that could be provided people would not worry so much about arriving at the station, as they would arrive at a well lit shopping centre.

Then there is the question of reliability. Every time there is a rail strike, potential passengers are lost forever because they are not prepared to risk being stranded again. We must declare public transport an essential service to overcome the absurd situation of passenger rail services in Melbourne being constantly disturbed by strikes and bans-at least 18 times in the last 18 months. The Government has even directed the stopping of public announcements that particular trains are cancelled, because there are too many of them. We simply cannot allow the people of Victoria to be held to ransom by people employed by the public to provide a service, and a sensible government would negotiate no-strike provisions with public sector unions for all or part of their awards. The Victorian public should not have to tolerate the type of industrial thuggery to which it has been subjected because of the climate of lawlessness which the Cain Government has created with its industrial relations policy over the last six years.

It is not only trains that the Cain Government runs so inefficiently. The Victorian Government's own reports show that private operators can run buses of equivalent standards for 30 to 50 per cent less than the government buses; yet the Government, for doctrinaire reasons, will not get out of the area in which it performs extremely badly. It has been assessed that if overmanning and inefficiency were eliminated from the metropolitan transport system $110m could be saved in the first year and $300m in the fourth year. This would be done chiefly by getting rid of feather-bedded positions in public transport.

While pouring money down the drain in the Government's inefficient rail, tram and bus services, roads have been very seriously neglected. The Cain Government has not had one major new road initiative. Grants for essential roadworks have been severely cut in real terms. Many rural councils are tearing up paved surfaces to return them to gravel and urban arterial roads are desperately clogged, as I am sure many people in Melbourne will now be experiencing. The hang-up of Mr Cain in particular about freeways is notorious. It even reached the absurdity that a road to link two freeways was deliberately designed with traffic lights so that the Government could say that it was not building freeways, they were just arterial roads.

The whole performance of the Cain Labor Government in transport has been deplorable. It has been badly directed and recklessly wasteful. An entirely new approach is needed. In fact, what is needed is an entirely new government which will really serve the interests of all Victorians, not just those of a few anti-freeway fanatics and militant unions.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Zakharov Sen A.O.

TALK.START.PARA: —This matter of public importance refers to the alleged mismanagement of the Victorian economy and the alleged effect on the national economy, in itself a tenuous claim even if we forget-as the Opposition both here and in my own State of Victoria would like us to forget-that the bulk of the nation's foreign debt is private sector debt. The debate is not really about the economy but is an attempt to snow the Victorian electorate with pseudo-economics and pseudo-accounting, as we have heard today. This attempt is seen as necessary because most Victorians are aware that they are better off, economically and socially, as a result of six years of the Cain Labor Government than they were in the long years of Liberal or coalition rule, in spite of the changed economic circumstances in the world.

SPEECH.PARA: The Victorian Liberal Party and the Victorian National Party-which, of course, are not in coalition and never will be if Jeff Kennett has his way-are raising spectres of economic mismanagement very often based on statistics which are selected so as not to represent the true position, as Senator Button and Senator Cooney have already pointed out. Those parties are raising these spectres or red herrings in order to hide the fact that Victorians of all ages and from all sections of the community have been doing very well under a Labor government and most voters are old enough to be able to make a comparison with what prevailed under previous conservative governments, and goodness knows, we have had enough of those in Victoria. They were in office at a time when the world economy was in a much healthier state than it is in now.

I want to tell the Senate about some of the ways in which the Cain Labor Government has assisted Victoria to become the State with the lowest unemployment rate in Australia, a high international credit rating, the healthiest rural economy in Australia, a very healthy secondary industry sector and a quality of life which is second to none. I shall deal first with some facts which relate directly to the reason for Victoria's healthy economy and its effects on ordinary people, workers and consumers; then I shall come to some of the ways in which the quality of life of Victorians has improved in the years since 1982. Honourable senators have already heard from Senator Button and Senator Cooney the facts about the economy, and I would just like to add a few pieces of evidence to what they said. Under the Cain Labor Government the Corporate Affairs Office has concentrated its resources on investigations. An investigations and insolvency task force has been established within the Corporate Affairs Office. This is very important because an ethical economy is as important as a strong economy.

The confiscation of profits legislation has been introduced to allow courts to confiscate or freeze the ill-gotten gains of prisoners. The Crimes (Computers) Act ensures that various computer and credit card frauds are now covered by the criminal law in our State. The maximum penalties for secret commission and bribery offences have been increased from two years to 10 years. That is something that the Queensland Government might benefit from looking at. A close liaison has been established between the Corporate Affairs Office and the Victoria Police to fight company fraud. Persons repeatedly associated with company failures are now prohibited from taking part in the management of companies and their names are listed at the Corporate Affairs Office as a warning to others.

Victoria has a very healthy rural economy and is expanding its rural exports, including finding new markets for such things as fresh grapes in the European winter. The Cain Labor Government is maximising the contribution of agriculture to the Victorian economy, making agriculture more efficient and more sustainable. The gross value of rural production in Victoria is now a record $4.4 billion, double what it was five years ago. Forty per cent of Victoria's export earnings comes from agricultural commodities.

Victoria is also tackling the problem of land degradation in a very realistic way. The Cain Government has been at the forefront of tackling salinity and that strategy recognises that salinity is not a problem which can be solved by governments alone. There must be a joint effort involving many sectors of the community. In the last four years some $60m has been spent and over the next five years $100m will be spent in fighting salinity in Victoria, which of course has implications for the other States in the Murray Basin.

Housing and construction is a very important part of the Victorian economy. Over the past six years an additional 16,700 units have been added to the stock of public housing. This represents an increase of 45 per cent over the period, a major improvement by any reckoning. This activity in public housing construction is only part of the story. Building in the private sector is also in a very healthy condition. A glance at the cranes on the skyline of Melbourne reveals evidence of that. But the private housing sector is also very healthy and will be assisted further by the recently announced stamp duty concessions for first home buyers. All first home buyers who are eligible for the Commonwealth first home owners scheme, who have dependent children and who purchase a house costing up to $100,000, will benefit by receiving a full exemption from stamp duty on the property transfer and on the associated mortgage duty. The maximum benefit will be about $2,500. This initiative, of course, has social as well as economic benefits, because it will provide financial support to eligible families at a critical time and assist families to move from rental accommodation to home ownership-something I thought that the Opposition would be very keen to see.

Consumer legislation is very important to a healthy economy which does not exploit consumers. Throughout the Government's last term a series of Acts was passed to protect consumers. Some examples of these are the Credit Act which ensures that consumers do not suffer from excessive interest rate increases or inappropriate documentation. Under the Act credit providers will have to behave in an ethical way or they will not be licensed to provide further credit. The Fair Trading Act provides protection from unfair and deceptive business practices. It protects against misleading advertising and unethical conduct by traders. The Housing Guarantee Act provides a guarantee for all new homes and renovations carried out by approved builders. Anyone in this place or elsewhere who has experienced building or renovating a house will know just how important that is.

The Cain Labor Government in Victoria is also making sure that the unemployment rate continues to fall and that a supply of skilled labour is assured for the future. One way of doing this is through the creation of additional training positions. In February 1985 the Victorian Premier promised 5,000 additional training places in Victoria at the end of his Government's second term in office, as part of the Youth Guarantee. In fact, more than 12,000 new positions were created in Victoria from March 1985 to June 1988. This Youth Guarantee commitment is very important to the young people concerned and to their families and as a source of future skilled labour. In 1985 there were less than 37,000 training positions. Today there are 50,000. As a former student counsellor, very much concerned in careers counselling and helping young people to find jobs, I know just how important that is.

I shall now give a few facts about transport. At the outset I should say that, unlike some Opposition Victorian senators who displayed obvious ignorance about public transport in Victoria, I am a frequent traveller on public transport. As I live close to the city I tend to use public transport rather than drive if I am travelling within the inner city area. Honourable senators will remember that transport is one of the areas mentioned in this matter of public importance. But it is totally unrealistic and biased to talk about the cost of transport without mentioning the benefits to the traveller and also to the community in safety, through fewer motor accidents, in reduced atmospheric pollution, and in reduced social costs and savings in servicing private vehicle transport. These are some of the benefits which Victoria has gained under the Cain Labor Government. More people now use public transport.

The figures that were given by Senator Hamer were distorted by the fact that the time that he dealt with included two years of conservative rule. He started with figures which were far too early to talk about what the Cain Labor Government has done. This greater use of public transport reflects better service, higher safety levels and more comfortable travel. The previous conservative Government had in fact reduced services. On the line on which I lived there were no Sunday services. The stations were unstaffed after 8 o'clock at night, so women in particular and children did not use trains. Since the last year of conservative administration there has been a 14 per cent increase in patronage on metropolitan transport. In the same period there has been a 57 per cent growth in V-Line patronage, that is, transport outside the metropolitan area. More people are now using a better system, and I have personal knowledge of that.

Concessional travel has been extended by the present Government to supporting parent beneficiaries, to widows of World War I veterans, and to sickness and special beneficiaries. Concessions for students and the unemployed have also been improved. The service has been improved by restoring services to some lines which had been closed by the previous Government, by the upgrading of vehicles of all sorts, by extending services in the outer metropolitan area, and by increasing efficiency. Ninety-two per cent of trains now run on time. This is very important to those who are using trains to travel to work. One ticket now takes a passenger on all forms of transport and fare increases have been less than increases in the consumer price index.

Related to transport is the question of road funding, an issue which has been substantially fudged by the Opposition both here and in Victoria. The facts are that the level of road funding in Victoria has increased by 16.5 per cent in real terms since 1983 and allocations for urban arterial roads, which carry the bulk of the traffic in Victoria, have increased in real terms by 14.5 per cent. All this has been done in a period when the transport share of Budget outlays has fallen from 9.8 per cent to 7.1 per cent. The public transport deficit has declined in real terms, whereas it grew under the previous Liberal Government.

I now come to education, which will lead, if I have time, to some of the quality of life issues I referred to earlier. The Cain Labor Government introduced in last year's Budget an education expense allowance, providing $60 for children aged 5 to 15 years. In the 1988 Budget this was raised to $100 per child and extended to cover children up to 16 years of age. In Victoria there is also a long-standing benefit, which has been greatly extended from that provided under previous governments of a maintenance allowance which is available as a separate allowance to those who are eligible for the family allowance supplement. This has been increased by 22.1 per cent since 1982. The allowance has been extended to cover all students under the age of eligibility for Austudy. Under the previous Government the allowance covered only secondary students. A very good indicator of what has happened in education in Victoria is the increased retention rate for all post-primary schools, which will reach around 72 per cent by 1991. It is worth noting that, unlike other States, in Victoria the retention rate in government schools is close to that in non-government schools. I think this is an indicator of the very high standard of government schools in Victoria. Again, I have personal knowledge of that as a parent and as a teacher. Most people now recognise the importance of preschool education. By the end of 1988, 97 per cent of children in Victoria will be in preschool education.

Finally, in my last minute I would like to mention something which is of very great concern to women in particular, that is, the matter of domestic violence. This is a community concern which is becoming evident in the whole Australian community. The Victorian Government has an excellent record in legislation and other action in this area. For example, it is now possible to get intervention orders to impose a wide range of restrictions on perpetrators, including prohibition of access to the victims' home or workplace. Since 1 December last year 1,600 of those orders have been issued. Police are now empowered to seize firearms belonging to a perpetrator of family violence. The Victorian Government is funding an extensive education program on this.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable senator's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lewis Sen A.W.R

TALK.START.PARA: —The basic responsibility of State governments is to manage effectively State public finances. Today the Senate is debating the following matter of public importance:

SPEECH.PARA: The serious burden to the national economy imposed by the extraordinarily high levels of public debt in Victoria, the onerous burden of Victorian State taxes and charges and the gross mismanagement of the Victorian economy as exemplified by the $2.1 billion unfunded liabilities of Workcare, the horrendous losses approaching $1 billion per annum of the State transport system and the hundreds of millions of dollars put at risk by the bungled investment policies of the Victorian Economic Development Corporation.

As a Victorian it appals me to see what seven years of government by the Cain Labor Party has done to our State finances. It has, in effect, bankrupted our State while concealing the real situation by clever media manipulation. That is one thing that that Government is clever at-media manipulation. In the meantime, it has ignored the basics-the management of State public finances. It has ignored the problems on the roads and the problems with supply of water and power. They are the basic matters that State governments should apply their minds to. I have no doubt that the people sitting in their cars, clogged on our roads in Victoria at present, will agree that this Government has not been applying its mind to that basic matter.

What has happened under the Cain Government? After seven Labor Budgets we have had expenditure at an increased annual average rate of 3 per cent per annum every year in real terms. I ask the people of Victoria: Do you feel any better off as a result of that after seven Labor Budgets? Victorian per capita expenditure has increased from $1,508 in 1981-82 to $2,832 in 1988-89-an increase of 14 per cent in real terms. Do Victorians feel any better off because of the increased expenditure? I doubt it. And why? It is because this money has been spent on increasing State public employment; it has not been spent for the benefit of the people. The Government is employing more people; not spending the money on the roads, the water, the power and other things that people want it spent on.

There has been an explosion in State public employment under the Cain Labor Government in Victoria and there has been a rapid and substantial increase in State debt. For example, this year, the Victorian Government has budgeted for a deficit of over $1,000m, which is equal to 8.7 per cent of total State outlays. Around 65 per cent of State Budget outlays are in labour costs or labour related costs: 65 per cent of the Budget goes in that direction. Victorian State public employment has grown at treble the rate of other Australian governments. Between March 1984 and March of this year the increase in Victoria was 10.5 per cent; the Commonwealth increase in public employment was 2.5 per cent.

We now have a debt servicing crisis in Victoria. The proportion of revenue from State sources needed to meet interest commitments has increased from 15.4 per cent when the Cain Government came to office to 21.6 per cent this year, despite huge increases in State revenue. The Government is now borrowing to pay interest on previous borrowings and we now have record taxes and charges in Victoria. State taxation has more than doubled in the seven years that Cain Labor has been in office. State taxation has in fact increased by 41.4 per cent in real terms. Victorians now pay more in State taxes per head of population than the residents of any other State. In Victoria this year-1987-88-the figure is $1,081 actual and $1,162 has been budgeted for next year.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The time for discussion of the matter of public importance has now expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Alston Sen R.K.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-In the adjournment debate last evening, Senator Cook referred to me in terms which suggested that he intended to refer to my colleague and friend Senator Grant Chapman. I do not know whether Senator Cook has had an opportunity to peruse the Hansard, but it seems clear that that is what he had in mind. He talked in terms of having expected to hear from Senator Chapman. He then went on to speculate about people distancing themselves from my actions. I do not for one moment shrink from being associated with Senator Chapman, and indeed I am more than happy to support him. I think what Senator Cook had in mind was somehow to be critical of me-but it was on an incorrect basis. So, I certainly wish to clarify that matter.

SPEECH.PARA: More importantly, Senator Cook in this place and, indeed, the honourable member for McMillan, Mr Cunningham, in another place, impugned my motives in suggesting that my remarks in relation to the Morwell Migrant Resource Centre were not motivated by a desire to ascertain the truth in relation to the accounting irregularities and improper practices which have characterised the recent operations of the board of management of that centre. The fact is that I was at pains to point out that the board of management was engaging in a series of highly dubious practices, such as the payment of large amounts of cash under the guise of travel expenses, the ghosting of payments to cleaners in fictitious names, and many other matters which have been the subject of a confidential report by a Commonwealth auditor.

I want to make it clear that I was attempting to do no more than present the facts as they emanate from that report. I do not accept the remarks about my motivation. Despite the Minister's fulminations and the desperate efforts of the honourable member for McMillan to cover up the matter, my statements have today been corroborated in the most telling way. The Austrian, German and Greek communities in the Morwell area have all dissociated their organisations from the centre, and their representatives have resigned from the board of management. I regard this as a vindication of the courageous and correct stand taken by the Liberal candidate for Morwell, Mr Norm Olsen, and I am very pleased that I have had this opportunity to clarify the position and to endorse what Mr Olsen has been saying-namely, that there is an urgent need for a public inquiry and for the release of that auditor's report so that it can be well understood that in fact a number of gross irregularities need to be cleaned up and that it is simply not good enough for local members of parliament to pretend that there is nothing wrong with the situation.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I am indebted to Senator Alston for pointing out that in the dying hours of the adjournment debate last night, I apparently-and I accept his word for it-inadvertently referred to him instead of Senator Grant Chapman. I stand corrected; I accept the correction, and I hope that the record will be corrected to show that what I was referring to was the business venture of Senator Chapman, in seeking registration as an agent for the business migration scheme and to the fact that I believe that this is an inappropriate thing for a senator to do. I believe that that is the judgment that the community will make. I was surprised that none of the honourable senator's colleagues had taken the opportunity in the adjournment debate to stand and distance themselves from the actions of Senator Chapman. But now Senator Alston associates himself with Senator Chapman, which, I guess, is a confirmation of the conflict of interest in which Senator Chapman is obviously engaged in seeking such a registration.
—You are being misleading again now.

—In my view, it is an obvious conflict of interest. I accept the correction-I was referring to Senator Chapman. As to the second matter that Senator Alston has raised concerning Mr Barry Cunningham, MHR, I do not accept that one is entitled to impugn his integrity in relation to this or any other matter. I know him to be a man of considerable integrity. I said last night that I thought that normally a courtesy extended in this Parliament is to advise a member of the other place or of this chamber if he is going to be referred to in a debate in the way in which the honourable member for McMillan was referred to last night. Despite what Senator Alston has said, it is still not clear whether that courtesy was observed in the case of Barry Cunningham.

DEBATE.TITLE: THE ROYAL AUSTRALIAN AIR FORCE WELFARE TRUST FUND

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Newman Sen J.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move-

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the paper.

This report of the Royal Australian Air Force (RAAF) Welfare Trust Fund and the annual report of the Australian Military Forces Relief Trust Fund-which was listed yesterday in the daily Order of Business in the Senate, but not reached-make very telling reading for anyone who is concerned about the problems faced by our defence personnel and their families. I want to take a little time of the Senate to ensure that honourable senators understand what the purposes of these trust funds are. The Royal Australian Air Force Trust Fund report states that they are:
. . . to assist and alleviate need amongst serving members and their families, through grants and interest-free loans.

The RAAF trustees have reported that they have found a continuing problem of making the loans viable in their purchasing power, due to inflationary trends. What is quite worrying is that the total for loans approved was $1,672,548 in 1987 compared to $1,091,738 in 1986. That represents a growth of 65 per cent in relation to need in the Royal Australian Air Force. Is it any wonder that this is the case when we have the pressures facing our defence families, who need wage justice and who need care and leadership from the Government of this country? We have servicemen posted to the other side of Australia. In many cases their families are neglected, to the extent that when family emergencies occur they are thousands of miles away, and they are given no assistance in relation to getting together to cope with situations that have arisen.

I am reminded of Navy wives who have said to me that their husbands can get back to a funeral for, say, their father because the Navy will help, but that the Navy, or perhaps it is the Government, does not care if the father of a Navy wife dies in Melbourne and that wife cannot afford the $780 to go to his funeral. Should people who are sent to serve this country, to defend this country, be put into these situations where they cannot afford to go to the funeral of a family member because of having been sent to do their duty on the other side of the country?

Even here in Canberra service personnel are being encouraged to move out of rental accommodation and to buy their own homes. That is a good idea where those people can afford it, but we have young soldiers trying to do just that, stretching themselves to the limit, although when it comes to the crunch of removal they find that the Government will not give them a penny to help them with removal costs across the suburbs of Canberra, and they can be up for another $1,500 to pay for that removal. This helps the Government through its not having to provide the temporary rental accommodation assistance or a married quarter for those personnel.

The Government announced with a flourish that it would give assistance with the education tuition allowance. However, in August it was announced that the paperwork was still not through and that the claims were still being thwarted. New Zealand is addressing the problem of pay for service people, with a review of the armed forces pay, to produce a system which is more able to cope with market trends and to respond quickly to the needs of the servicemen. Our Defence Remuneration Tribunal needs more resources. The Government has failed to give it sufficient resources. I believe that the priorities in the Department of Defence need to be changed so that, first of all, a pay review, which is already a year overdue, can proceed more speedily. This is well overdue and is desperately needed by the servicemen. The service allowance, which came up last year and which did not give servicemen their fair deserts, should be reviewed quickly. The Defence Department is dragging its feet on that. Help should also be given to enable the 3 per cent increase awarded by the Australian Conciliation and Arbitration Commission to go through the Defence Force Remuneration Tribunal quickly.

Nearly 200 determinations are awaiting attention in the Department of Industrial Relations. Some of these determinations have been waiting for nearly two years. The Government has the power to unstick immediately this bureaucratic jungle that these things are stuck in. The departments of Defence and Industrial Relations should be given their marching orders and told to get on with the job quickly. We should be ashamed to learn that so many servicemen need to go to trust funds for assistance because they are in such desperate financial difficulties due to the Government's neglect.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

DEBATE.TITLE: 103RD SESSION OF THE NATIONAL HEALTH AND MEDICAL RESEARCH COUNCIL

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the paper.
I refer particularly to the following statement on page 5 of the report of the 103rd session of the National Health and Medical Research Council:
. . . at the request of the Minister for Health, the MREC had prepared comments on the ethical issues contained in the majority and minority reports of the above Senate Select Committee.

At page 41 there is a reference to the report of the working group to consider the establishment of a national body on guidelines and research on in-vitro fertilisation. Honourable senators will recall that the Senate established the Senate Select Committee on the Human Embryo Experimentation Bill 1985 under the chairmanship of the now Minister for Justice, Senator Tate. That Committee met over a considerable period and heard evidence from persons, scientists, ethicists, doctors and others, as well as patients. It came to the conclusion that there should be a legislative protection for a human embryo to prevent any destructive non-therapeutic experimentation on a human embryo such as would frustrate the development of that human embryo from fertilisation onwards.

In the course of that inquiry the Committee considered and rejected the National Health and Medical Research Council's property model-that is to say, the attitude of the National Health and Medical Research Council that the human embryo could be regarded as property and could be experimented on or disposed of in any way up until the fourteenth day after fertilisation. Indeed, the Family Law Council of Australia had considered and rejected the National Health and Medical Research Council's guidelines. So, two significant bodies have considered the National Health and Medical Research Council's guidelines and rejected them as being ethically invalid, as lacking scientific and ethical validity. I say `scientific validity' because the National Health and Medical Research Council said that the sheet anchor of its guidelines was the time at which implantation would normally occur. In its submission to us the Council said that that would be between nine and 13 days after fertilisation. Yet, when we asked the Council whether it had not heard of the research which proved that this took place or commenced to take place at the fifth or sixth day, it had to admit that it had not heard of the research that was contained in the Hertig and Rock publication. We then asked the National Health and Medical Research Council, `Is it not a fact that the sheet anchor on which your guidelines are established are now on shifting sands?' So it was.

Yet, here we have the Minister for Community Services and Health (Dr Blewett) going to the body whose evidence had been rejected by two major inquiries and asking it to comment on the report of the Senate Select Committee. The Government's policy has been developed on the basis of that report. I think that is an absolute disgrace. It is an insult to the Senate. It shows how the National Health and Medical Research Council's Medical Research Ethics Committee (MREC) is entrenched. In fact, if the Minister had read properly not only the report of the Senate Select Committee but also of the Asche Committee, he would have restructured the Medical Research Ethics Committee because its guidelines are not only permissive but also scientifically and ethically invalid.

We need to raise this matter again because this operation by the MREC may mean that the report of the Senate Select Committee will gather dust. I will at some future date reveal some further information as to the political operation that is being undertaken by certain members of the MREC against the Senate Select Committee's report and, indeed, against the Chairman of that Committee.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable senator's time has expired.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: National Health and Medical Research Council Report

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Coulter Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the paper.

The Senate is considering a report of some of the research work which was carried out in Australia under the Medical Research Endowment Act during 1987. I would like to draw the Senate's attention to two pieces of research. The first is reported on page 41 of the report-namely the importance of hormones that excrete salt. I raise this matter because of the continuing and unfinished debate in this place on the removal of pharmaceutical benefits scheme drugs from the general to the authority only list. That debate is continuing in this place. Prominent among those drugs are the so-called ACE inhibitors. This paper refers to work which is going on in Australia on salt intake and the relation between salt intake and hypertension. The report states:
When this research was started a new hormone, atrial natriuretic peptide, had just been identified. It has subsequently sequenced and synthesised.
The report goes on to explain the action of this peptide. The report states:

The studies undertaken have demonstrated that this hormone has potent effects. Its secretion is stimulated by excess sodium intake or retention by the body. When administered to animals in low doses it increases the excretion of salt. This effect occurs with a lower concentration in animals that are not salt loaded. Atrial peptide also has a direct effect on blood pressure, and when given by low dose infusion, causes a sustained fall in blood pressure. A significant part of this fall in blood pressure is due to interference with the action of angiotensin (another hormone that alters salt balance) on the blood vessels. One component of its effect on salt excretion is due to the inhibition of angiotensin's action on sodium reabsorption by the proximal tubule.

The significance is that the ACE inhibitors are the angiotensin inhibiting substances. Here we see the identification of the role of salt in the same mechanism, clearly indicating that the effect which can be achieved by the ACE inhibitors can also be achieved much more simply and in a preventative mode by altering the salt intake in the diet. I think that bears very much on the debate which is going on in this place. Earlier today I indicated that in very many instances considerably cheaper treatments, particularly preventative treatments, could be put in place.

The second aspect to which I refer appears at page 72 under the heading `The Causes of Tooth Decay'. It says, inter alia, that tooth decay is probably the most common infection in humans, while its incidence has decreased as a result of fluoridation, et cetera. I draw the Senate's attention to an article which appeared in the Canberra Times on 13 September this year in which the former principal dental officer with the New Zealand Department of Health in Auckland, Dr John Colquhoun, was reported as saying that he had conducted comparative studies of children's tooth decay in New Zealand in the 1980s in which he found that fewer fillings were required in unfluoridated areas than in fluoridated areas. He explained:
My bosses in Wellington did not believe the comparison figures; said they were not typical.

Dr Colquhoun said that he got out the statistics for all New Zealand school children aged 12 and 13 years from every health district in the country and the percentages were the same. His studies showed that the marked decline in dental caries attributed to fluoride had begun in the 1930s, long before the introduction of fluoride. I simply signal to the Senate that I believe that enough evidence is accumulating, which evidently is not known to people in this research work, to indicate that a thorough review of the role of fluoride in dental caries is long overdue.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —This morning I had a medical researcher in my office who had not been able to receive medical research grants from the National Health and Medical Research Council (NHMRC) for a specific project. That was a beneficial project for a number of Australians-northern Australians-and people in South East Asian areas concerning malaria. He was absolutely appalled that whilst the National Health and Medical Research Council could not give funds for that purpose it could turn around and give $450,000 for a project entitled bioethical issues in the use of human foetal tissue, embryos and gametes. The principal conductor of that program was none other than Professor Peter Singer of the Monash Centre for Human Bioethics whose often published views are that the human embryo, the human foetus and indeed the newborn child have no inherent right to exist and, specifically, that a human embryo is of no more inherent worth than a lettuce.

SPEECH.PARA: It is a disgrace that this sort of money could be spent on such a project. The Chairman of the NHMRC, Professor Lovell, has arranged with Professor Singer that institutional ethics committees' members throughout Australia should study at the Monash Bioethics Centre under this person. Furthermore, the NHMRC will not give a grant to other ethical bodies that have sought funding. This disgraceful situation needs exposing. Two months ago an event took place in Australia which will have grave implications, I believe, among the whole of mankind unless it is challenged and it will place Australia on the slippery slopes of eugenics. It has been done because of the NHMRC's permissive guidelines which were rejected by the Senate Select Committee on the Human Embryo Experimentation Bill 1985 and the Asche Family Law Council Sub-Committee on Reproductive Technology.

The only matter that I can deal with in the time available relates to the creation of human embryos specifically and solely for the purpose of being experimented on to their destruction; that is to say, they have been flattened to test for chromosomal abnormalities that may be caused by the microinjection technique. Honourable senators will recall the fuss that occurred in Victoria over this; yet it occurred in New South Wales. The medical doctor there indicated that he had already been undertaking these experiments in New South Wales and we discovered that the scientist in Victoria who was successful in pressurising the Victorian Government to change its legislation ended up as the scientific director of that project in New South Wales. We must take account of this matter. I remind the Senate that these guidelines have been subjected to the scrutiny of Judge Asche's Committee and the Senate Select Committee, which was chaired by Senator Tate, and they were rejected; they had no scientific or ethical validity.

It is of concern to scientists whose projects have been approved but for whom there is no money available in this fund to hear that $450,000 has gone to this project. It is an extraordinarily large grant, as those of us who know a bit about research grants are aware. Generally, they are about the $10,000 to $20,000 mark.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable senator's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —This is the latest attack of a number made by Senator Harradine on the National Health and Medical Research Council (NHMRC)-an attack directed at the means by which grants are allocated, with the clear implication that the decision made not to give grants to someone he mentioned and to give grants to other people is in some way unfair. It is an attack made in support of a view which Senator Harradine quite properly holds but it is not a universal view held within the Senate. To say that the NHMRC has some kind of perverted way of giving grants is unfair. It uses the most careful peer review methods. It is fair and careful in the way in which grants are made. This attack, one of a series, is thoroughly unfair. I want to put on record that not everyone in the Senate shares the view put forward by Senator Harradine. I know that some of my colleagues wish to speak on other papers. Therefore, I seek leave to continue my remarks later.

DEBATE.TITLE: HOUSING AGREEMENT BETWEEN THE COMMONWEALTH AND THE STATES AND THE NORTHERN TERRITORY

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Boswell Sen R.L.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the paper.

It is most timely that consideration be given to the supplemental housing agreement between the Commonwealth and the States and the Northern Territory. It is timely for three reasons. We should examine the poor performance of this Government in its housing policy. The current review of the Minister for Housing and Aged Care (Mr Staples) of the Government's housing initiatives has involved a host of problems and proposals, and pressure is starting to build up on housing interest rates. I can honestly say that this Government's housing performance has been second to none in the damage inflicted against those 90 per cent of Australians who work hard to own their own home and achieve the dream of most Australians.

Under this Government the cost of buying a home has nearly doubled. In 1983 the average monthly home loan repayment was $335. That was based on an average home loan of $33,000 over 25 years at an 11.5 per cent interest rate. Now, in 1988, the average home loan repayment is $620, based on a home loan of $55,000 over 25 years at an interest rate of 14.5 per cent. The Government has been able to achieve these disastrous results in only five years. Home ownership is less affordable today than it has been at any time over the last five years. The average annual disposable family income is currently $34,500, but an annual disposable income of $39,500 is needed to qualify for a loan to buy the average house. So even people on average incomes cannot afford to own an average house. That is a shocking indictment of this Government. Reductions in funding for the first home owners scheme have meant that the maximum deposit assistance for a couple with one child is now only $2,000. Under the present National-Liberal Party coalition policy this deposit gap would be eliminated for low income earners by the Commonwealth meeting the cost of mortgage insurance.

This Government's housing agreement has concentrated on funding public housing-welfare housing-and cut the proportion of funds going to home ownership assistance. In 1981-82, before this Government took office, Commonwealth funding was split 46 per cent purchase assistance and 54 per cent public housing. Last year, 1986-87, it was split 27 per cent purchase assistance and 73 per cent public housing-that is, welfare housing. So the person who wants to own his own home has been swept away. The first home owners scheme has had its funding cut from $306m in 1984-85 to $222m in 1987-88, with individual grants being cut last May by $1,000. That shows the commitment this Government has to young Australians who want to achieve the Australian dream of owning their own home. It could not care less about them. It is more concerned about welfare housing. I suppose that is what one can expect when one elects a socialist government.

It is no wonder, therefore, in the light of such a performance, that the Minister has called for a review of housing initiatives and has floated such proposals as a wealth tax on homes valued at over $300,000-that is disgraceful-a capital gains tax on family homes; and replacing the first home owners scheme with interest subsidies.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is absolute rubbish and you know it.

—The honourable senator knows that those ideas have been floated among the Australian public. The Minister has retracted them but Senator Tate knows that they were floated. They are there and they are in the back of the Government's mind. It is becoming increasingly apparent that the provision of initial home purchase assistance is a more cost effective way of helping low income families than forcing them to be lifetime tenants in expensive, totally taxpayer funded State Government housing-welfare housing. Not most Australians but all Australians would prefer to own their own homes. This Government has been most negligent in encouraging this. Net Commonwealth payments in housing and community amenities to the States have also dropped significantly.
—Order! The honourable senator's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Messner Sen The Hon A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to pick up the comments of my colleague Senator Boswell, who has made some very strong points about the failures of the Hawke-Keating Government's housing policies. Certainly, we have seen interest rates rising to make housing less affordable throughout the whole of Australia and particularly in Victoria. Senator Boswell made the point that there has been a greater emphasis on so-called welfare housing by the Federal Government in recent years, but even if we look at the figures in that area, we find that there has been a dramatic failure in the attempts of the Government to meet the demands not only in the whole of Australia but particularly in Victoria.

SPEECH.PARA: In Victoria the queue of people waiting for welfare housing at the time the Cain Government came to power in 1982 was 14,260. That number has now grown to over 35,000-a 250 per cent increase under the Cain Government. That compares with a total change for the whole of the Australian community of only about 170 per cent, which on its own is bad enough. It demonstrates that the Victorian Government is even worse than any other in terms of arranging welfare housing for the most needy in the community.

That is what the Cain Government has not done for Victorians and what the Keating Government has not done for Australian's generally. As Senator Boswell so ably pointed out, this Government has failed to meet even the dreams of ordinary, average Australians who are seeking to buy their own homes. They are simply being closed out of the opportunities because of rising interest rates which are now being encouraged by the Keating Government's misleading and misguided policies in fiscal affairs. I just want to repeat the main points. Whereas the Cain Government, which fortunately is going to its doom on Saturday in Melbourne--

TALK.START.PARA: —Do you want a bet?

—Yes, I do. Quite clearly, the opportunity is there for the Victorian people to judge that Government on the basis of its housing policy. The Cain Government has failed to deliver welfare housing to the most needy in the Victorian community.
