DEBATE.TITLE: STANDING COMMITTEE ON APPROPRIATIONS AND STAFFING

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 1 September, on motion by Senator Crichton-Browne:
That the report be adopted.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crichton-Browne Sen N.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to speak in respect of the eleventh report of the Standing Committee on Appropriations and Staffing, having moved the last time I spoke on this matter that the report be adopted. I remind the Senate of the content of the report and the purpose of the content. It flows first of all from a motion which was carried unanimously by the Senate, proposed by the Chairman of Senate Estimates Committee A, Senator Graham Richardson. The recommendation which was adopted by the Senate read:

SPEECH.PARA: (a) the provisions of the resolution of the Senate dated 25 March 1982, relating to the responsibilities of the Standing Committee on Appropriations and Staffing with respect to the Estimates for the Senate, are re-affirmed;
The reaffirmation is this:

(b) the estimates of expenditure for the Senate to be included in the Appropriation (Parliamentary Departments) Bill shall continue to be those determined by the Standing Committee on Appropriations and Staffing.

In other words, the Standing Committee on Appropriations and Staffing, on behalf of the Senate, is to make judgments as to what the amounts ought to be. That recommendation has been totally ignored by Senator Walsh. The resolution reads further:

(c) if before the introduction of the Bill the Minister for Finance should, for any reason, wish to vary the details of the estimates determined by the Committee he should consult with the President of the Senate with a view to obtaining the agreement of the Committee to any variation;

Senator Walsh did not consult the President of the Senate. As late as 1 August, in the first of his communications, he wrote to the President of the Senate, telling him unilaterally that the Estimates that had been arrived at pursuant to the resolution of the Senate were not satisfactory to him. It was on 1 August that we had the first indication that the estimates were not satisfactory to the Minister for Finance (Senator Walsh), notwithstanding the fact that previously, on 20 July 1988, the officers of the Senate had discussed the Estimates with officers of the Department of Finance and had been given to believe that there were no difficulties with the amounts. The resolution goes on to say:

(d) in the event of agreement not being reached between the President and the Minister, then the leader of the Government in the Senate, as a member of the Appropriations and Staffing Committee, be consulted.

I have to say that the estimates were arrived at and agreed upon unanimously by a committee of which the Leader of the Government in the Senate (Senator Button) is a member. But, of course, inasmuch as Senator Walsh, in his capricious, arrogant and insensitive way, disregarded the views of the Senate and first corresponded in writing on 1 August, it was hardly possible for there to be consultations with Senator Button. I remind honourable senators of resolution (e) which states:

(e) the Senate acknowledges that in considering any request from the Minister for Finance the Committee and the Senate would take into consideration the relevant expenditure and staffing policies of the Government of the day.

In my view the proposed estimates were very much in accordance with the general guidelines and principles laid down by the Government in respect of restraint and staff numbers. They are the minimum with which this Senate chamber can function and fulfil its obligations to the electors and the Australian people unlike, I might say, from my casual observation, the expenditures in respect of the Executive, of the Government of this Parliament. It is not without consequence to note that an amount of $5m is set aside to pay for the wages of 103 security guards to protect and preserve the Ministers of this Government. Yet Senator Walsh thought it appropriate to cut significantly the bare minimum outlays which the Senate had appropriated unto itself. I conclude by quoting resolution (f):

(f) in turn the Senate expects the Government of the day to take into consideration the role and responsibilities of the Senate which are not of the Executive Government and which may at times involve conflict with the Executive Government.

Whenever it is necessary, and yet there is no conflict of course that the Senate is not fulfilling its obligations and its commitments. The reason that resolution is there in that form is to ensure the independence of mind of the Senate, the capacity for independent audits, independent judgments and independent resolutions by the Senate in respect of the legislation that passes through this chamber. The great concern I have is not simply for dollars and cents. It is simply for the capacity of the Senate to fulfil its obligations. It is my view, with the Budget that has been set aside by Senator Walsh on behalf of the Government, that he is wilfully and knowingly denying the Senate an opportunity to fulfil its proper obligations and functions.

At a time when we have an ever pervasive, ever growing government, with ever increasing legislation being brought into this chamber, I would have thought there was an argument to be had for increasing the budget of the Senate and not decreasing it. Yet we found Senator Button, a member of the Committee and the Leader of the Government in the Senate, not raising a finger in support of the Senate. He sat as a member of the Committee and tacitly agreed to our budget. But he allowed Senator Walsh to write to the President telling the Committee that the estimates were unsatisfactory. As a member of the Cabinet and the Government he supports the reduction in expenditure available for the functioning of the Senate. In my view that imperils democracy in this country.

TALK.START.PARA: —Oh, come on!
—That is exactly typical of Labor opinions. Democracy? What's that?

—Senator Walters is quite right. It is not forgotten on our side of politics what has been said about the role of the Senate or the States which are represented in this place. Mr Hayden wanted to abolish the Senate and the States. What happened to Mr Hayden? Is he back in Australia or has he gone again? What did Mr Hawke say in his Boyer Lectures? He wanted to abolish the States. Of course, it is axiomatic that he would want to weaken the States House. It is with grave disappointment that I note the sort of language which was necessary in this report to unanimously record the objection that the Committee had to the cavalier way in which it was treated by Senator Walsh. In my eyes Senator Button to some extent redeems himself by being a member of the Committee and not dissenting with the report. At least he acknowledges that Senator Walsh's conduct was unacceptable to all members of the Committee and presumably in due course to the Senate. The fact of the matter is that he waited until a late date to tell us that he disagreed with our funding. He was uncompromising and insensitive to the necessities of the Senate. He chose not to consult with the Committee in the proper way as is required, nor with Senator Button or the President. We now find ourselves with a significantly reduced budget which in my view denies the Senate an opportunity to function in the way it was intended and to have a proper audit. It might suit Senator Button and the Government but I am sure it will not suit the people of Australia to have the Senate in a position where it is unable to properly audit the functions of government in the way in which it is intended we so do. It reflects very poorly on Senator Button and the Government. I hope that later on during the year when we come to Supplementary Appropriations he will use commonsense, decency and a touch of integrity to ensure that the original budget set by the Committee is reinstated to what it was previously.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —I only wish to speak very briefly on this matter because of the time limits. I wish to support the view that this is a very important matter because it goes to the heart of the separation of powers which are enshrined in the Constitution between the Executive Government, the Parliament and the judiciary. Clearly, if the functions of a parliament are to be so truncated as to prevent them from being exercised by the elected representatives of the people, by the imposition of cuts in funding proposed by the Executive Government, then that is a serious interference in the constitutional authority of this place, or of the House of Representatives for that matter.

SPEECH.PARA: I am a member of the Senate Standing Committee on Appropriations and Staffing. I believe that the Presiding Officers have exercised extraordinary restraint. After all, it was the Presiding Officers who, together with the Committee, looked at the proposed expenditure and made severe cuts in it. Rigorous examination took place by the President of the Senate and the Appropriations Committee. We had determined what was the lowest appropriation necessary to meet the non-discretionary requirements of the Senate. We had imposed severe restraint. That restraint is now currently being felt by officers of the Senate. It is not necessarily being felt by me or by any other senator just yet but it will come our way because the services that we demand in the performance of our functions as elected representatives of the people from our State will suffer. It is clear that we will have to come back when Supplementary Estimates are considered. I am sure that the Minister at the table, the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce (Senator Button), understands this matter because he has integrity and understands the Senate and its workings. I have no doubt that he will have regard to the needs of the Senate.
One of the major problems was that the Minister for Finance, Senator Walsh, imposed the cuts unilaterally. That was about two months after his department had received the Estimates.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 20 July his departmental officers were saying that there were no problems with the totals.

—That is correct, as Senator Crichton-Browne said. On 20 July, the Minister's Department stated that it had no problems with the then severely pruned estimates. It was then in the middle of August that the Minister wrote making these dramatic cuts and said that they would be in the Budget Papers. Honourable senators will realise that this has very grave implications. I feel that this really ought to be considered by the Government. The Government should consider whether this is a policy decision appropriate for it to adopt. If it considers that it is, we should have a major debate here as to the implications of the decision.
—I think that the Government should come clean and say what it is on about.

—Oh, no; I think the proof of the pudding will be when consideration is given to the Supplementary Estimates. I think that I shall leave the matter at that because there will be an opportunity after the Government's attitude to those Additional Estimates is known. We will know what the Government's view is. We will know whether it is the view only of Senator Walsh or, indeed, whether it is the view of the Government as a whole and thus a throwing down of the gauntlet to the Senate. We will know whether it is, indeed, an interference in a major constitutional principle of the separation of power between the Executive Government, the Parliament and the judiciary-that separation being so important to the future of our democratic nation.

SPEECH.PARA: Question resolved in the affirmative.

That the Senate take note of the paper.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 31 August, on motion by Senator Giles:
That the Senate take note of the report.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Knowles Sen S.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to express my support for Senator Durack's dissenting report to the eleventh report of the Committee of Privileges. Through the action of the Senate on 16 March the Committee was given an academic brief that avoided direct mention of what the coalition saw as the key question of privilege. That is the thing that disturbs me most of all. It disturbs me that the threat of possible legal action caused the suppression of a petition and thus constituted contempt of the Parliament. That was our main area of concern, the Government sought to water that down dramatically. As a result, the Committee did not address the problem that was originally raised. Moreover, the decision of members of the Committee along party lines to refuse to hear evidence from the petitioner concerned further reduced the effectiveness of the Committee's report. In my view, this really showed a lack of interest in any problems faced by private citizens compiling petitions. I think that to have muscles flexed in such a manner whereby petitioners can be threatened by citizens just because they are raising a matter of concern is an issue which really the Senate should be addressing.

SPEECH.PARA: It is a matter of record, acknowledged in paragraph 5 of the report, that Senator Collins's successful amendment on 16 March was to the effect that the removal of what he described as `personal references' in the original motion did not preclude the Committee, on its own motion, interviewing people concerned with the original case. Therefore, I think it is quite disturbing that the Committee-to be precise, its Australian Labor Party and Australian Democrats members in particular-voted to refuse to invite Mr Strickland to appear before it. I think that it was important that Mr Strickland should have been heard in evidence before the Committee. This can be described only as a determined political move to prevent the airing of a very real grievance-that of a citizen whose right to petition the Senate may have been improperly infringed. In regard to this whole question we have been continually confronted with a proposition floated by the Government that the petition cited by Senator Durack in his dissenting report is somehow grossly defamatory-from which it follows that Mr Burke had every right to institute legal proceedings.

Quite frankly, in reading the petition, it is revealed that the petition merely asks that Mr Burke be available to answer questions in regard to charges against Mr Brush and Mr Martin. The petition accused him of no active wrong doing. It makes no aspersion as to his fitness to act as ambassador to Ireland, once matters have been answered to the satisfaction of both Houses of the Parliament of Western Australia. Therefore, there was nothing defamatory at all in that petition. However, both Mr Burke and the Federal Government were extremely sensitive about the petition. Of course, Mr Burke was so sensitive about it that he threatened to sue Mr Strickland. I therefore stress the point made by Senator Durack-that there are no grounds for the Senate to assume that this petition was defamatory in any way, and that the Clerk of the Senate had specifically cautioned against such an assumption.

The Committee by its action has ignored the important question of whether the threat of legal action on spurious grounds can be used to deter a petitioner from circulating a petition dealing with legitimate matters of public concern. I think my main area of concern is that pressure can be put on citizens to prevent them from actually ensuring that this Parliament knows their concerns. None of us can pretend that a private citizen, acting as such and not fronting for a larger organisation, would not have every reason to avoid litigation. Of course, this was the case with Mr Strickland. Naturally enough, Mr Strickland was very concerned when Mr Burke threatened his action. Of course, Mr Strickland ceased circulating his petition. A case for defamation might have the flimsiest chance of success in the courts but the plaintiff could rely on the fact that a defendant could not afford legal advice, time away from work in the courts and the stress that invariably is produced by legal proceedings and that is experienced particularly by those unused to such proceedings. The precedent therefore exists in Gee's case of 1696, whereby the bringing of a libel action against people petitioning the House of Commons was found to be a contempt of the House. I am not, of course, alleging that Mr Burke was necessarily in contempt of the Senate through the threat of defamation proceedings, and I do not wish to be interpreted in that way. But what I do regret is the fact that this possibility has in no way been canvassed by the Committee that was set up really to look at the whole issue.

It ought to concern the Senate that this inaction may have set a very negative precedent whereby petitions, in any way questioning the actions of public figures, circulated by private citizens may be quashed merely by the threat of legal action. I do not think that is a desirable position. It really does defy logic to maintain that any protection that might be afforded to a petition of the nature of the one quoted in the dissenting report would thereby provide carte blanche for petitions that made specific and harmful allegations against individuals.

I think the point is made in the Committee report that petitions in general relate to public policy rather than the redress of personal grievances. It is therefore unlikely that allegations against individuals in particular, who legitimately would seek legal redress, would arise through their circulation. It must be remembered that the original petition in contention was concerned with public policy and did not accuse any citizen at all of any wrong doing. It would appear paradoxically enough, I suppose, that a person could submit a defamatory petition against an individual to the Senate and avoid libel if it were not actually circulated to anybody else. This is suggested in paragraph 21 (iii) of the report. The Senate could refuse to receive the petition, but its originator would still have enjoyed the protection denied the mover of a bona fide petition.

I very strongly endorse the conclusion reached by Senator Durack that the intention of presentation to the Senate should not excuse the publication of defamatory material, but that grounds exist for some legal immunity for limited and private publication. Therefore I think it is a very reasonable proposition advanced by Senator Durack that the Committee should have recommended an amendment to the Parliamentary Privileges Act 1987 to protect individuals from the threat of legal proceedings that can deter them from raising with the Senate matters of legitimate concern.

Clearly there is a need to establish ground rules that on the one hand would maintain the right of the citizen to protect himself or herself from harmful, libellous statements circulated as a petition, but on the other hand would protect the citizen from the abrogation of the right to petition the Senate on matters of public policy through the threat of legal proceedings. The Committee report does nothing to assist in the establishment of any such procedure, given the Committee's refusal to hear evidence from the person whose case gave rise to the original reference.

The point was well made on 16 March by Senator Chaney that the body of law of parliamentary privilege has been built up through the examination of particular cases. It is regrettable to me that this tradition has been neglected, producing a report of what can be assessed only as of very slight value. The Senate at least can be grateful for a dissenting report that does have the courage to address the real issue as to whether powerful and influential figures can in effect suppress any petition that questions their actions or urges that they give account of them. I think that would be a very sad day. The Opposition does believe that the Senate has a responsibility to the public for the rights of Australians to circulate petitions on matters of genuine public concern, as this petition was, but observing of course the proper decorum in form and content.

How sad it is that other parties appear not to share this concern and actively seek to ignore the question of whether legitimate petitions can be suppressed by this threat not of conviction for libel but of embarrassing and costly legal proceedings that many people simply cannot afford. As I said, I think it is a very sad day when we get to a position where people are obviously not going to be able to circulate petitions of public concern. As there are not other speakers, I seek leave to continue my remarks later.
Leave granted; debate adjourned.

DEBATE.TITLE: JOINT SELECT COMMITTEE ON VIDEO MATERIAL

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 31 August, on motion by Senator Chaney:
That the Senate take note of the report.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Senate will recall that after a three-year inquiry the Joint Select Committee on Video Material came up with its report in late April of this year. The majority of the Committee, comprising members from both the Senate and the House of Representatives, recommended a ban on X-rated videos and their R-rated equivalents. It made certain other recommendations which are included in its report. Those recommendations deal with the issue of video violence. The majority of the Committee made some specific recommendations relating to violence which were not taken up and included in the minority recommendations.

SPEECH.PARA: There have been some rather ludicrous suggestions that the majority of the Joint Select Committee was weak on violence and strong on sex. I point out to honourable senators that our Committee made specific recommendations; firstly, relating to the need for material that is contained in the lower classifications relating to violence to be upped or outed; and, secondly, that the whole area of relish for violence be banned.

On 29 June 1988 all State governments in Australia recommended to the Federal Government that it place a ban on X-rated material. I do not have sufficient time in the seven minutes that are available to me to go extensively into the other recommendations that we made. Those relate to the sale and hire of material, under what circumstances and what conditions. I hope that they are fairly well known amongst both legislators and the community. All of the State governments recommended that the Federal Government place a ban on X-rated videos.

It is important to know what this material is, and it is important to know that we are talking, in the X category, of physically non-violent material but material that portrays women as eager for sexual experiences of any kind and ever-ready for any opportunity for sexual activity. This is frequently manifested in the group sex scenes depicting diverse sexual activities which are a feature of much of the material. It is important to note that according to the evidence that we received, which was cited by the Committee, such material engenders in the viewer a sexually callous and manipulative orientation towards women. It mediates in the minds of the habitual viewer women in general as being highly promiscuous and available.

It is interesting to note that at least four of the researchers saw the non-violent pornographic videos as being more harmful in this regard than even the more violent video material. I refer to Professor Check, Professor Zillman, Professor Bryant and Professor Weaver. That is an important thing for honourable senators to remember. As has been observed in the report, the Film Censorship Board has already banned material which links explicit sex with explicit violence. Some of the producers try to get around that, but at least the Film Censorship Board has done that. As we observed in the report, this ban was placed on this material on the basis of behavioural science evidence that the Film Censorship Board had at that time. Since the Board did that in 1984 a considerable amount of research material has become available and it was made available to the Committee. As I indicated, this material showed, so far as at least four of the researchers were concerned, that the type of material that is contained in X-rated videos is more harmful in this regard than even the violent pornography.

I come then to the issues. Once what the material contains is explained and its harmful effect is explained, a reasonable person would consider the matter to be of such importance as to require legislation. Indeed, one recommendation of the Committee was that this matter be dealt with not by regulation but by legislation. The response to that is that this would be a form of censorship. We are not talking about censorship. That is precisely not the issue. We already have censorship. We already have a ban on explicit or unjustifiable depictions of sexual violence against non-consenting persons. Child pornography and bestiality are already prohibited imports. I know there is an argument abroad that there should be no censorship even of that material, but I do not think it holds sway amongst many people.

Then we hear the often repeated statement that adults should be free to see, hear and read what they choose. Even that is not the issue. Of course adults are free to consume poison too, if it is produced. But in fact the Federal Government and the Film Censorship Board have thus far seen this as not in the nature of a principle to be applied universally and uniformly but rather as a slogan to be used selectively and arbitrarily in a manner that lacks credibility. In the case of video pornography the Government has thus far resorted to the use of that slogan, rather than admit to giving priority to the exploiting pornographers' claim to right of freedom of expression over all other individual and societal rights.

This argument should not be confused with the debates of the late 1960s, which were characterised as debates between the literati and the philistines. This, in fact, is the reverse. This is material that has been produced by the philistines to make a quick buck, claiming that their right of freedom of expression is impeded. I think it is important to understand that the State governments want this material banned and for the Federal Government to ensure that it is.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable senator's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walters Sen M.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —Following Senator Harradine in this debate, I wish to deal with one other section, and that is the section on violence. The Joint Select Committee on Video Material reported in April 1988. I think the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce (Senator Button), who is at the table, would agree that there is a requirement for the Government to respond to a committee report within three months. The Minister is yawning and pretending he is very bored about the question I am asking him, but I do ask him: Does the Government intend to respond to this report? It is of great interest to the community. I hope it is not the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade (Senator Gareth Evans) who is now in charge of this matter. I could not stand it. I ask Senator Button not to leave the chamber. I ask him to remain and take the rest of this debate. Obviously I have to put up with Senator Evans. I know only too well his views on video material because he was the original instigator of the proposition that the barriers to pornography be lifted. It was he as the Attorney-General at the time who said, `Open slather'. It was only after deals had been done with all of us that he eventually was forced to withdraw and restrict the violence and sexual violence that he was so keen to allow to be shown on video screens in the home. It was he as Attorney-General who decided that that sort of rubbish could not be shown to the public in cinemas-it was too bad-but it was all right for home entertainment. It was he who was very anxious to allow it to be shown there. However, we have waited patiently-some of us impatiently-for the Government to respond to this particular Senate Committee report, but we have not had the courtesy of that response.
—Not only ours, but also the State governments.

—The State Attorneys-General met, as Senator Harradine indicated earlier, and they came to a decision. I believe at the time the Commonwealth also agreed with the action to be taken, but we have not heard any further.

SPEECH.PARA: I will deal with the area of violence. In our Committee report we noted that a fair amount of research by the South Australian Council for Children's Films decided that the children it had surveyed were seeing films that were not appropriate for them. Those children were between the age of six and 12 years. The majority by far were seeing films that were not suitable for their age group. One per cent were seeing X-rated classified films; 16 per cent were seeing R-classified films; 33 per cent were seeing M-classified films, and only 26 and 23 per cent were seeing the remaining two categories. We must bear in mind that, according to classification, the M-rated videos are suitable only for children over 15 years. Yet the majority of the groups were seeing quite freely those M-rated videos.

The Committee came down with several recommendations which I believe were of paramount importance. I will read to the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade some of those recommendations because I am sure he has not bothered to look at them. It was unanimously recognised by the Committee as a whole that violence ought to be curtailed, that there ought to be an ability for parents to walk into a video shop and pick up a video for their children knowing exactly what was in that video or, if it were the case, why it was not suitable for their young children to view. We recommended that non-G markings be displayed on the front cover of the video slip as part of the prescribed markings. We said why reasons should be given if the films were to be rated PG, M, X or R.

We said that there was great difficulty in finding the classification symbol on many video containers at the moment. We recommended that it be not only on the video cassette but also on the outside cover. We said that the agencies must display very clearly what the various markings meant, and we went into a great deal of detail. We also made an attempt-I think a very good one-to reduce violence generally in video films. We recommended that the current guidelines for R-rated violence be altered. An R-rating is the peak of the violent videos: it is the top grade.

The Committee decided that the violence in some of those R-rated videos was too extreme. To try to clarify the guidelines the Film Censorship Board should take into account, we said those guidelines should be altered. Previously they said that explicit depictions of violence but not detailed or gratuitous depictions of acts of considerable violence or cruelty were ruled out. We added a simple word but it made a great difference. We said that the guidelines should now refer to `explicit depictions of violence but not detail relished or gratuitous depictions of acts of considerable violence or cruelty'. We added the word `relished'. While that may appear to be small it is very important. It cut out of all those extremely violent videos any depiction of someone enjoying committing the violence, enjoying the suffering of his or her victim. That will cut out a considerable number of the extremely violent R-rated videos.

That was a unanimous report, yet the Government has continued to ignore the Committee's recommendations. I do not understand why. There is considerable concern in the community on a number of these classifications. When all the States want the Commonwealth to take some action, I do not understand why it refused to do so. I do not understand when Government members recommend certain action-it seems very sensible and reasonable action and it is a unanimous decision of the Committee-why the Government still refuses to take that action. I can only presume that the Attorney-General (Mr Lionel Bowen) is finding it very difficult to get it past the party room and is not game to bring it into the Senate. I hope that the Attorney-General very quickly brings forward this legislation, as required by our recommendations. I ask the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade, who is at the table, to give that message to the Hon. Lionel Bowen.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Second Report of the Sixty-third Session

PROCTEXT.PARA: Consideration resumed from 31 August, on motion by Senator Cook:

That the following Sessional Order, contained in the Report, be adopted: That, notwithstanding anything contained in the Standing Orders, in a debate on a motion for the suspension of any Standing or Sessional Order a Senator shall not speak for more than 5 minutes, and if the debate is not concluded at the expiration of 30 minutes after the moving of the motion the question on the motion shall then be put-
Debate (on motion by Senator Tambling) adjourned.
Debate resumed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —When this matter was being discussed before I made several points in relation to the motion for disallowance. First, cost containment is a reasonable goal for government and, if that is the goal of government, we do not object to government pursuing that goal. But the Government has made claims without offering evidence for the course it wishes to take. The claims that the Government has made and which I outlined before are that too many expensive drugs are being prescribed; secondly, that the Government wishes to save money; thirdly, that the Government believes that the new arrangements-that is, certain drugs being available only on authority-will save money; and, fourthly, that the Government believes this can occur without detriment to patients. The Opposition opposes the Government's propositions because they do not stand up.

SPEECH.PARA: I have already challenged the Government to show any evidence that present prescribing is idiosyncratic, that it is inappropriate, or that other cheaper drugs available are equally effective. It is for the Government to support with evidence the case it wants to make because it is proposing a particular course of action. We think that there is ample evidence to the contrary for many of the 53 drugs on the list which are now available only on authority there is simply no alternative available. If that is the case, why have those drugs gone on an authority only list? The most obvious examples of this are the anti-cancer drugs, and I mentioned these before. They are awful agents that are used to treat only those malignancies unsuitable for other therapy. In some conditions they are used to cure those malignancies, but they are awful drugs. No person will submit themselves to treatment with these agents willingly or unnecessarily. Is the Minister for Resources (Senator Cook) suggesting that these anti-cancer drugs are given to people because of caprice or fashion, for reasons of fad or idiosyncrasy? If he is, will the Minister and the Government please produce some evidence? If not, if there is no evidence that drugs are being used in this way, why are they on the list requiring authority only prescription? We should disallow the regulations and tell the Government to try again. Has the Minister for Finance (Senator Walsh) any expert evidence to back up the very convenient statements he made in his speech in Geelong when he said that doctors were prescribing more expensive drugs when less expensive ones would do?

Let us now challenge the Minister on another matter; that is, that the drugs which have gone onto this list actually represent real advances in therapeutics. Of the 53 drugs, we should tell honourable senators that 75 per cent-three out of four of the prescriptions which are written-involve just six of the drugs. All of these drugs are used for various forms of heart disease-cardiovascular disease. Honourable senators have already referred to the ACE inhibitor drugs-the angiotensin converting enzyme inhibitor agents-a new class of drugs. These drugs represent a real advance in therapy. In a very important editorial in the Medical Journal of Australia of 15 August, Professor John Shaw said that the list of 53 drugs is a poorly disguised attempt to camouflage a new restriction on these angiotensin converting enzyme inhibitor agents and to forestall any further blow-out in costs as new cholesterol lowering agents become available.

I have to say to the Government that if the drugs work, if more people in society require treatment for, say, elevated cholesterol levels, or for high blood pressure or heart disease, why not encourage use of the drugs, as long as they are used properly. We have evidence that they are better drugs. Certain people taking part in the community debate have told us again and again that we do not have to use these new agents for high blood pressure, that we can use treatment based on certain diuretics, on the old thiazide diuretics, that they are alternatives to the new drugs in various combinations and that they are much cheaper.

The people who say that are wrong. The new drugs are different. They are better. Thiazide diuretics, which I used extensively in my practice, did for many years form the basis of treatment for high blood pressure and certain conditions, but in the United Kingdom they have been found, when used by males, to be associated with a high incidence of impotence. Any doctor who has been in practice would know that one of the problems in treating high blood pressure was to convince male patients that it was worth having the treatment, if one of the side effects, as it not infrequently was, was impotence. The thiazide diuretics have that as a side effect. How do we now explain to patients that because of government cost saving priorities they should accept an unnecessary and higher incidence of impotence with the cheaper treatment for their blood pressure?

TALK.START.PARA: —Unreasonable.

—It is unreasonable. However, that is the kind of alternative and the Government is saying that we should go for the cheaper drug-for example, the thiazide diuretics. The fact is that the new drugs do not happen to have those side effects. Further, we know that it has been demonstrated that the treatment with thiazides for hypertension in the elderly in Australia is associated with a higher incidence of sudden death and mortality from myocardial infarction-heart attacks. If I had mild hypertension, high blood pressure, I would want the best treatment available.
—We are all at risk from that.

—I suppose we are, working here. I have a letter here from Professor Trefor Morgan, Professor of Physiology in the University of Melbourne-a graduate from the golden year of medicine, I should say. Professor Morgan actually says that for his patients the initial treatment of choice for high blood pressure, for reasons which he sets out in his letter, in fact is this new group of drugs, the angiotensin converting enzyme inhibitor agents-the ACE inhibitors, as they are called. If I had mild hypertension, my treatment of first choice would be a converting enzyme inhibitor. Professor Morgan says that if that did not work, the second treatment of choice would be a slow channel calcium blocking drug. Both Professor Morgan's first line choice of treatment and his second line choice of treatment involve drugs that happen to be on the list of 53 drugs for which prescribing will now be more difficult.

SPEECH.PARA: Honourable senators should understand that it is not just a question of saying that too many drugs are being prescribed. We should look at the scope for treating high blood pressure in Australia. The National Heart Foundation has produced information and has published data which indicates that 30 per cent of women and almost 50 per cent of men who have elevated blood pressure in Australia were not receiving any treatment at the time of a risk factor prevalence survey. If we merely treated all the people who have elevated blood pressure in Australia, that would certainly improve health outcomes-and it would involve the use of more drugs. Merely to provide some treatment for the 50 per cent of men and 30 per cent of women with elevated blood pressure who are presently receiving no treatment should lead to the use of more-not fewer-of these agents. The newer cardiovascular drugs have no equivalents therapeutically. They have fewer side effects; they are used less in Australia than in comparable countries; and they are not being over-prescribed.

Let us now consider the foolish way that the Government has approached the whole exercise. In a speech that he made on 7 July in Geelong, Senator Walsh quoted internal figures, and said that there had been major increases from $1 billion for drugs, projected to go to $1.9 billion by 1990-91. Senator Walsh was using rubbery figures, because that projection is valid only if one assumes that a one-year rise in cost was carried on year by year, unchanged, through to 1991-only if that one year rate of increase was maintained over each year-and, of course, it will not be.

The Australian Medical Association understands that the list was selected simply by a process of the Government inviting the Pharmaceutical Benefits Advisory Committee to provide information on which drugs within the pharmaceutical benefits scheme cost more than $30 for a course of treatment. The drugs were chosen solely on the basis of cost and not on the question of effectiveness, whether they represented a real advance, whether they were needed, whether there was a large group of people untreated, or on whether it would involve efficiency. A blanket approach has been taken to extend the authority system to most of the drugs identified by the Pharmaceutical Benefits Advisory Committee. The result is that there have been what the Government calls some unintended consequences. The major anti-cancer drugs have been caught up in the net, and other drugs have been caught up for which there is simply no practical cheaper alternatives. They have been included in this new special authority list.

The Government's proposals will require doctors to certify that less expensive therapy is not `appropriate' for a patient. Whenever I fill in an authority form, I fill it in using the exact words required by the Government, so that the clerk who is processing it knows that he has to approve it. The only net effect of that might be three million extra authority forms-with little or no saving in the cost of drugs prescribed for Australians. Very foolishly, these decisions were taken without any consultation with the organised medical profession.

Now we can assess whether or not the Government has reached the wrong conclusions. I believe that it has. Whatever were the aims of the Government, the present arrangements will not achieve any good or desirable outcomes. If the goal is cost saving, the Government will probably not even achieve that, if one takes into account the extra administrative costs that the scheme will involve. The Government will restrict the prescribing of the most expensive drugs simply because they are expensive. A chemist in Mount Druitt Village-located in one of the working class areas of Sydney-a concerned citizen, put the matter to me this way:

One could sympathise with the Government in attempting to curtail the costs of health and pharmaceutical benefits; however, surely a simpler system would be to place appropriate conditions in the handbook supplied to doctors, with an instruction to doctors that the issue of an ordinary prescription for these items will only be valid if the conditions are complied with.

Senator Crowley would know that that is the SP kind of drug arrangement. Surely, that would have done the job. We already know that the Western Australian Labor Minister for Health, Keith Wilson, has been reported as urging a review of the changes, because he believes that patients in Western Australia are in a position where their health has been put in jeopardy.

The Government's decision rests on the presupposition that much of the present prescribing is inappropriate and that the new restrictions will reduce this inappropriate activity. However, an authority scheme does not really save money. I draw to the attention of honourable senators the fact that two drugs, cimetidine and ranitidine, two drugs used for treatment of peptic ulcer, are available only on authority; but because they are necessary and because they fulfil a real need, the costs of prescribing them have actually increased. If the Government wants to save money it will have no alternative but to refuse some of the requests for authority.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is the stated aim.

—But is the Government going to refuse the authority requests? Let us approach this motion for disallowance with some sympathy for the desires of this or any government to save money, to avoid waste and to ensure the appropriate use of subsidies which are made from the public purse. The Opposition actually has sympathy with those goals, if they are carried out properly. But on this matter the Government has made wrong assumptions about the problem and has put into place quite inappropriate and foolish decisions. I have never minded filling out authority requests for drugs, and I have done it day after day for sick people; but the present scheme is foolish. It is not based on any facts or evidence which have been made available to us. It is a scheme which will save money only if it disadvantages the ill.

SPEECH.PARA: The purpose of the Government is clearly to see less of the expensive, modern, better, more effective drugs used for the ill. If I had high blood pressure or cardiovascular disease, I would want an ACE inhibitor or a slow channel calcium inhibitor drug used for me, if that were necessary. It is an unworthy objective for the Government simply to want to save money at the expense of Australia's sick. The regulations on which that objective is based should really be disallowed so that the Government can pursue its cost containment objective in a fairer and more appropriate way.

Whatever the fate of this disallowance motion, I hope that the Government, in re-examining and reviewing this matter-as it is doing in the face of very considerable public concern and pressure-will bring in new arrangements and regulations that will achieve significant cost savings, if that is what it seeks, that will not harm the people of Australia who are in need of treatment.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Reid Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —We are discussing the Government's proposal to take off the list of pharmaceutical drugs available in Australia some 53 items which are important in the treatment of high blood pressure, high cholesterol, cancer and epilepsy. We find, of course, that the Australian Democrats, the people who are always espousing causes and pretending, one might almost say, that they care about people in Australia, will vote with the Government on this matter. That disappoints me somewhat because I would have thought that this was one matter where the Democrats really would have seen that there was some benefit and some point in ensuring that the sick people in Australia are able to get the treatment they need.

SPEECH.PARA: The Government is shifting 53 items onto the authority only list. This is a total misuse of the authority only list which, as Senator Peter Baume has pointed out, has been used for some considerable time. A doctor is required to obtain specific approval from the Department of Community Services and Health to prescribe drugs on that list. That has been the case for good reason. Under this arrangement addictive drugs and new drugs are able to be monitored, and no-one has complained about that. This concept has been supported. But what we are seeing now is a total misuse of the authority only list. Australians are being denied access to drugs which are expensive or new merely because the Government wants to try to rein in the exorbitant cost of its misguided Medicare health system. It is merely a cost cutting measure, with no regard whatever being shown for the people who would benefit from the types of drugs that are now available in Australia and in countries similar to our own.

The Minister for Community Services and Health (Dr Blewett) claims that this arrangement will make doctors think about cheaper but equally effective methods of treatment. It is worth looking back at what the Government promised in 1983 and 1984. None of us has forgotten the rhetoric of the 1983 election about what Medicare would do, or the rhetoric of 1984, when Medicare was to come into operation. In an article in the Canberra Times on 29 January 1984 Neal Blewett said:
On February 1, all the costs, the complications, the inconvenience and the headaches that crippled the health-insurance system over the past few years will end.

Well, anyone who has not been sick since February 1984 may think that that has happened. Anyone who has been sick or has had a member of his family sick will know that that in fact is not the case. The Minister said:
Two out of three families will be paying less.
That is a joke for most people in Australia. He went on:
If you go to a public hospital, Medicare will provide free accommodation and treatment by hospital doctors-whether you are an in-patient or an out-patient.

People should just try getting into a hospital these days if they are sick. I could spend the rest of the night telling the Senate of incidents in Canberra that have occurred since 1984, when Medicare was thrust upon us. I could tell the Senate of people in Canberra who have waited 3 1/2, 4 1/2, five hours at Canberra hospitals.

TALK.START.PARA: —Not the Minister when his family was sick in Canberra.

—Not the Minister when someone in his family was sick. I am talking about people who do not have a private doctor to whom they could go but had to depend on the public hospital system, people who have been sent home in the middle of the night, having sat in the outpatients department. I am talking about elderly people over 90 years of age. Only today I heard of a man whose doctor said that he should be in hospital. But the doctor said to the family, `Don't just take him there because if you do he will spend four or five hours sitting in casualty'. The family cannot get him admitted. The hospitals have rejected him. So the Minister's message on 29 January 1984 has not proved to be the case. We did not expect it to be, and we have said so frequently.

SPEECH.PARA: A press release put out at the same time as the Minister's article waxed lyrical over four pages. The press release stated:
`The introduction of Medicare is the biggest step ever taken by an Australian Government to ensure that every Australian has the best and cheapest medical and hospital care', Dr Blewett said.
Well, it is turning out to be the cheapest; it is not turning out to be the best. I could read more of that press release, but I have other things to say on this topic.

The Government proposes to chop Australians out of health care by removing 53 drugs from the list. There is no doubt that this is an indication of the failure of Medicare. The Government is effectively saying that patients in Australia are not entitled to the benefits of research and development for many quite common conditions because it is not prepared to run a health scheme which will enable these things to be paid for. The Federal Government is condemning many people with the complaints that I have referred to-cancer, high blood pressure, high cholesterol and epilepsy-to what can be regarded as second rate treatment. Roughly 28,000 people a year die from cancer. An Australian Bureau of Statistics health survey reveals that 55,400 Australians would have experienced an episode of epilepsy in any given period of two weeks. The survey, which was taken when Australia's population was less than 16 million, showed that one person in 275 had suffered an epileptic attack in a two-week period. We are talking about keeping from people drugs which would enable them to lead more normal lives and get on with their jobs and social arrangements.

The Australian Medical Association (AMA) has identified some of the effects. Senator Peter Baume has spoken about them. The cheaper alternative drugs the Government wants doctors to prescribe for high blood pressure, heart disease and strokes can have the side effect of impotence. Cuts to Medicare and to what is available under the system are not new. As I said, think back to the rhetoric of 1983 and 1984. Ever since then the sick have been facing cuts to available health services.

Let us look at what is happening in Canberra. I am not being parochial when I say that; I am looking at a health system which is run entirely by the Federal Government. The Government cannot hide behind State government decisions or other decisions. The Australian Capital Territory (ACT) situation is an example of Medicare as it happens. There have been cuts to what is available right through. Universal health services have not provided care to those who need it. The benefits have been chipped away ever since the scheme began. The levy has been increased from 1 per cent to 1.25 per cent of income. So people are paying more and getting less. The people I am concerned about are those who cannot afford, in addition to paying the levy, to have private health cover. They are the people who are suffering-the ones who need to rely on the government health system.

According to the Canberra Times of 21 September, the number of items on the Medicare pathology benefits table has been almost halved in a major rationalisation of the schedule. Is not the Labor Government keen on the word `rationalisation'? We know what it means: people are getting less than they thought they were or less than they are entitled to. The article says that this has been undertaken to promote more efficient pathology services and reduce the confusion caused by the large number of items. We are not fooled by those sorts of words: we know what they mean. Medicare has failed. There are hospital waiting lists like I have never seen before in this country. There is a lack of funds for vital medical equipment. Cancer patients in the ACT have had to travel to Sydney or Melbourne for treatment because the unit at the Woden Valley Hospital no longer has equipment that can be relied upon. The computer which operates part of the equipment breaks down. The system is so old that parts cannot be obtained, or they have to come from old equipment overseas to try to keep it going. That is what is happening to our health service in the ACT.

The neglect of the cardiology unit at the Royal Canberra Hospital is such that it has driven the head of that unit-an expert in this area whose reputation is beyond dispute-to take extended leave and to comment publicly on what is not now available in the cardiology unit at the Royal Canberra Hospital. Patients in that unit are sitting in corridors because the Department has not adequate office space. The need for the upgrading of the Royal Canberra Hospital is beyond dispute. The former Minister for the Arts and Territories, Mr Punch, commented on it only a short time after a report as to the necessity for upgrading the Royal Canberra Hospital was produced. An amount of $160m is needed over a period of years. How much did we get towards that in this year's Budget? Nothing. The Royal Canberra Hospital stays in the same condition as it has been in. Anybody who had a patient there last summer will remember the conditions when the air-conditioning was not working. Patients were sent home as they were unable to cope with those conditions in the heat of summer.

It is little wonder that the morale of the health care workers in this Territory is so low. There has been industrial disputation in the health area since Labor was elected, with nurses, the Hospital Employees Federation, the Royal Australian Nursing Federation, transport workers employed in the area, private doctors, physiotherapy professionals and the like involved. The salaried doctors in the Canberra hospitals resigned en masse last Friday, giving a week's notice. The most recent report that I have heard on it, which I think was today, asked whether the deadlock had been broken. The doctors had still not withdrawn their resignations and until that happened the dispute would be considered serious. Can one imagine it being anything other than serious if the doctors employed in the hospitals are resigning en masse because of the conditions? I suggest that this problem, personified in Canberra where the Federal Government is totally responsible for health care, reflects the conditions in other hospitals in this country. It is useful to look at what goes on here.

When this Government tells us that we in this country can no longer afford the benefits and advances in the medical and pharmaceutical area for common conditions such as those to which I have referred, it really is committing us to the status to which the Treasurer (Mr Keating) referred a couple of years ago-a banana republic. He is now strutting around the world purporting to tell other countries how to run their economies. Before doing that, he ought to come home and find out what it is like to try to get health care in this country.

The problem lies with the failure of Medicare to provide. It is costly. We are not talking about spending more money: we are talking about spending the money that is available more wisely. An editorial in the Canberra Times as recently as 24 September, headed `The ACT no place to get sick'-is that not the truth?-outlines the situation. If one has a broken bone in the ACT one is likely to have to go to Wagga Wagga in New South Wales for orthopaedic treatment.

TALK.START.PARA: —In the capital of Australia. It is an absolute disgrace.

—That is the case in the national capital. We had a health system in the ACT which provided for the region of New South Wales. People came here for treatment. We were proud of our hospital system. We are very disappointed that it has been brought to what it is now. The Government talks about setting up an inquiry. If it is genuine about that, I hope that it will get to the bottom of the problem-that is, the failure of Medicare. I hope that the Government is not setting up an inquiry merely to hide behind it while it goes on, rather than doing something to solve the problem of those in Canberra who need the health system. The editorial stated:

SPEECH.PARA: It would almost be comforting if the mass resignations were a rare disruption to a smooth and efficient ACT public health system, but the system has long been plagued by industrial action by nurses, hospital employees and doctors, services have been reduced, old equipment has not been replaced and an urgent refurbishing of the Royal Canberra Hospital has been deferred till self-government is achieved.
That is the state of health care in the ACT. Another article, entitled ` ``No room at the inn'' in ACT hospitals', quoted the ACT President of the AMA as follows:
It is ironic that if Mary and Joseph arrived at Royal Canberra Hospital at Christmas time, they would find the ante-natal ward closed and `no room at the inn'.

He was referring to the closure of 268 hospital beds in Canberra during the Christmas-New Year break which, he said, seemed to be based on the premise that patients were an impediment to the efficient running of hospitals. It is a story that no government should be proud of. The Government should be ashamed. Setting up an inquiry is not enough. We want solutions. We want to know that those who must rely on the public health system are able to get the services they need. The Opposition's motion to disallow the Government's chopping out of another 53 items of medication and the impediment which is being placed upon it under the guise of this authority list has been moved because we believe that the people of this country are entitled to a better health system than they are getting at present.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walters Sen M.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —We ought to be fully aware of what the Government is on about. Its sole aim is to cut costs. That is what it has stated. Indeed, I have a copy of a letter from the Minister to Professor Lewis of the University of Tasmania, and that is his priority-cutting costs. It does not matter about the second rate health care that creates; it does not matter about the health of the patient; and it does not matter what type of drugs are involved, so long as the Government can cut costs. We are assured that the Government's decision has been taken on the basis of bureaucrats deciding which drugs should come off the list. Naturally, the most expensive will come off. We have been told that there are cheaper drugs: they may well have side effects; nevertheless, there are cheaper drugs that can take their place. That is typical of what the Government has done in the past.

SPEECH.PARA: I will mention two other occasions on which the Government has used ridiculous decisions to attempt to cut costs. Recently we debated the nursing homes legislation in which the Government made an effort to regulate staff numbers. We all remember that debate. Nursing homes were given a patient score. If they had a certain number of patients with a high score they were entitled to more staff. The score system was quite ridiculous. It obviously had nothing at all to do with nursing care. When I asked the Minister who was involved in recommending this score sheet to him, I was told that the person involved was qualified in statistics and research. The person was qualified not in nursing but in statistics and research. There was not proper consultation. That is typical of this Government. Then on another occastion it said, `Get the bureaucrats to decide on the number of visits a patient with a certain illness can make to a specialist without the specialist's schedule fee being downgraded'. It did not matter to the Government that some of the illnesses were so serious that a patient could not possibly have been treated adequately with the number of visits the bureaucrats decided.

This was a cost saving exercise. The Government would not have to pay out so much. In the Estimates committee hearings-I am sure Senator Crowley will remember this-Senator Peter Baume spent quite a long time going through a series of serious illnesses and the number of visits permitted to a specialist, asking Dr De Souza whether he believed that was adequate treatment. Dr De Souza, as we all know, is one of the main Government advisers. On each occasion that Senator Baume asked the same question, Dr De Souza said no, he did not believe that was adequate treatment for a patient.

But the Government did not care whether it was adequate treatment so long as it cut costs, so long as Medicare, because of its particular ideology, was able to survive. It did not matter that Medicare was downgraded, that it provided second and third rate health care. The bureaucrats said, `It does not matter how sick a patient is. The illness can be treated satisfactorily by a specialist on the number of visits that we determine'. Yet, as we know only too well from the Estimates hearings, that was not so, so the Government was forced to review that arrangement.

What does the Government do with the nursing home patients? It gets research officers and statisticians to work out a score that will help cut Government costs. That is what it has again done in this instance. We have 53 drugs taken off the pharmaceutical benefits list and put on an authority only list. A doctor has to seek special permission to give vital medication to very ill patients. We have received a tremendous number of letters from very concerned groups. The Epilepsy Association says that it believes that any delay in giving the drug that is necessary for epilepsy patients can be life threatening. It also says that at the very best the patient can end up in hospital. Where is the Government going to save costs by allowing that to happen?

The Government has said that it will save $40m. I make a little suggestion to the Government. It has just spent nearly $47m on a ridiculous referendum campaign that it lost overwhelmingly. If it had not spent that sort of money on the referendum, it could very easily have provided that $40m over three years. It will save only $40m by cutting out 53 drugs from the pharmaceutical benefits scheme over three years, yet it squandered $46m on a referendum that the people threw out because they did not trust the mob on the other side. That is why in Tasmania 75 per cent of the people said, `We just don't trust you'. The Government spent that $46m because it was so out of touch that it had no idea that it was so far down in the dregs as far as the people out there are concerned.

Let us look at what this declaration says. It is not only about the 53 drugs to be removed from the pharmaceutical benefits list. Let me outline what the Government has decided to do with the cheaper drugs. At the moment under the pharmaceutical benefits scheme, a doctor usually prescribes a month's supply of drugs and provides repeat prescriptions to save a patient coming back to see him so that, at the most, a patient would get three months supply of a drug. But from 1 August the patient will not have in her handbag or his pocket a month's supply of drugs. From 1 August the supply will be doubled for a range of inexpensive drugs. Patients will be able to have a lot of the cheap drugs, and to have them all at once. The Government is going to double the supply. One very experienced chemist said to me that pharmacists consider that the issue of increased drug quantities will be unsafe and contrary to the Government's national drug strategy. They say that it will cause an increase in drug abuse and accidental poisoning and that the decision is against the interests of public health. They are not prepared to be party to an increase in drug abuse.

But the Government could not care less so long as the system is cheaper. It spends so much money on its national drug strategy, on a public relations exercise in which it says to the people, `Look, we are doing something'. It does not reach street level-it never did-it is just a public relations exercise. Then the Government says to the chemist, `You are allowed to hand out to these elderly people, to pensioners, twice the amount of drugs that you have been able to hand out in the past; but only the cheap ones, mind you-the ones that can have disastrous side effects'. Patients will be able to have twice as many drugs in their handbags, which the Government had always considered was not appropriate. To save a few lousy dollars that it has squandered on the referendum, it has decided to double the amount of drugs that can be supplied to a patient.

Let us look at what some of the chemists have been saying about the restriction being placed on the 53 drugs to which I have referred and the requirement for doctors to apply to prescribe them. It is inevitable that delays will occur. How can a doctor treating an epilepsy patient-someone immediately in need of a drug-say, `I'm sorry; I cannot prescribe you that. I cannot send someone down to the chemist to get it for you; I have to write to the Minister. I have to seek permission from the Secretary.'?

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam Acting Deputy President, I raise a point of order. I have practised considerable tolerance in listening to Senator Walters explain about costs in nursing homes and matters of great irrelevance, but I draw your attention to the total misrepresentation of the facts in this matter and I ask you to ask the honourable senator at least to speak the truth.
—There is no point of order.

—Thank you, Madam Acting Deputy President. There is no point of order, because I am speaking the total truth. As the matter stands now, following this decision by the Government, a doctor will have to write away seeking approval to prescribe a drug for an urgent case. He will have to seek approval. He will not be able to prescribe and supply the drug immediately.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Victorian Economic Development Corporation-Stock Market Crash-Urban Environment-Tobacco Advertising-Fuel Rebates: Off-road Users-Deployment of Service Personnel to Darwin-WorkCare-Building Industry, Victoria-Debbie Flintoff-King

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! It being 7.30 p.m., the debate is interrupted. Under sessional order I put the question:

INTERJECT.PARA: That the Senate do now adjourn.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cooney Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —Today during the matter of public importance debate reference was made to the Hon. Robert Fordham, Minister in the Victorian Government, about his role and activities with the Victorian Economic Development Corporation, the VEDC. He is concerned that the allegations made against him be answered and answered as soon as possible. I do so, subject to permission given, by tabling a statement which I have in front of me dated 26 August 1988. At the bottom of the statement is printed the name Robert Fordham, MP, Minister for Industry, Technology and Resources. There are three appendices with that statement which further elucidate the propositions which Mr Fordham so forcefully puts in this statement. I seek leave of the Senate to table the statement.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have three matters that I wish to raise tonight. I notice that there are a number of senators on the adjournment debate list and I would like to truncate it a little. The first two matters concern two papers which have come to my attention and which would be of interest to honourable senators. Like many honourable senators I was interested in the recent stock market crash and have a paper which was prepared on financial implications of the crash. It is a paper which is factual in nature.

SPEECH.PARA: The second matter I wanted to raise was a matter raised by my colleague, the Hon. Tim Moore, in the New South Wales Parliament. It was written before the Liberal Party won the election. It is called `Saving our cities-future directions for the urban environment'. It is also a straightforward and non-controversial paper. In view of the number of people on the adjournment I seek leave to table those two papers for the information of honourable senators.
Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Senate. The third matter concerned some censorship of recent matters about tobacco. Tobacco policy has always brought into conflict health perspectives and interests on the one hand and mercantile perspectives and interests on the other. Many other groups in society find themselves brought in. For example, sporting bodies find that their funding becomes dependent upon the patronage of tobacco companies and tobacco sponsorship. Cultural bodies find they cannot continue to function without the money that comes to them from tobacco retailers, the pushers of legal drugs. Tobacco retailers are also knowing agents of avoidable death and suffering. Even the press becomes involved. The papers value the advertising revenues that come from cigarette and nicotine industries. Of course honourable senators realise that the print media enjoy all the acknowledged press advertising by the tobacco industry. The electronic media has to satisfy itself with what it can squeeze out through the improper use of corporate sponsorship. The press does not want to take any action that would jeopardise that industry or the money it gets from revenue. It does not want to take any action that would threaten its own revenues. Rev- enue is an approach based on self-interest ahead of public interest.

SPEECH.PARA: A recent event illustrates this lack of public responsibility by the newspapers clearly and dramatically. That event occurred, as honourable senators would be aware, against the background that two States-Victoria and South Australia-have passed legislation restricting sponsorship activities and advertising by tobacco companies. This action was taken in those two States quite simply because cigarette promotion is a form of recruitment of our young into a dangerous and addictive form of drug use. In the last week in June legislation went through the Parliament of Canada totally banning all cigarette advertising in that country. The legislation in Canada provided for penalties of up to $Can300,000 for breaches of the new law. My friend Dick Smith, that outstanding Australian explorer, anti-cigarette campaigner, publisher of the Australian Geographic, conservationist, and concerned citizen, was aware of the Canadian legislation. He was interested in how it would be received in Australia. In fact, Dick Smith wrote a letter to the editor of the Sydney Morning Herald, Mr Max Frisk, on 8 July. It states:
Dear Max

Last week legislation went through the Canadian Parliament totally banning all cigarette advertising with the heaviest penalty ever set in that country's legislation of a whopping $300,000. This ban includes newspapers, magazines, billboards and other outdoor advertising as well as sports sponsorship. I understand this is the first English speaking country that has done this. Even though this quite far-reaching announcement was on the world wire-services, the anti-smoking movement took a bet with me that it would not be mentioned in the Sydney Morning Herald. They were right.
Surely it is important that Australians know of this quite drastic legislation for if news is suppressed there is no way a democracy can work. I am sure you agree.
Yours sincerely
Dick Smith

Sadly for the Australian public and for the reputation of our Australian press Dick Smith was absolutely right in the prediction he made as he has been right on so many other occasions and issues. Only one Australian newspaper carried any report of the legislation enacted in Canada which, if it were enacted here, would assist in a major reduction of death and disability, would improve the public health, and-we note this-reduce the revenue of the print media in Australia. All newspapers ignored the story, except the Australian Financial Review which, on 1 July, ran a small story under the headline `Canada gets tough with smoke bans'. It was a good and adequate story.

What is worth reporting here to the Senate and what was contained in Dick Smith's letter to the Sydney Morning Herald is that the anti-smoking movement was able to take a bet with him that the story of new legislation in Canada would be suppressed by the newspapers even though it came in on all the wire-services. Was it suppressed because it was not important? No, of course not. Was it suppressed because it was not interesting? No, of course it was not. It was suppressed because it represented a conflict with the vested interests of the papers. That is the tragedy of the episode. Of course, it could be that there is some other simple and honourable explanation for the press non-coverage of this story. If so, it would help us all to know it but right now there does not appear to be a simple explanation. One would have to worry about the information that might be made available, or might not be made available, should a similar measure be proposed for us here.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Panizza Sen J.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —My concern relates to the actions of the Department of Customs and Excise when it checks and rebates tax-free fuel. In years gone by off-road fuel that was mainly used by agricultural and mining industries could be obtained by getting a certificate and one did not have to pay up front. In the mid-1970s under a Liberal Government that idea was changed and one had to pay it all first up or charge it to one's account and then apply for a refund later. That system one way or the other has not worked too badly up to the present where one expects to get one's rebate back for off-road fuel within the pay period of 30 days. But since mid-May this year things down at Customs and Excise seem to have gone haywire. There has been a heap of applications for the fuel rebate by agriculturalists around Australia after having planted their crops. The payment of that rebate has been tardy. Generally during seeding farmers do nothing else; they do not even open their mail, for that matter. They do not bother putting in an application for their fuel rebate. They make a lump application towards the end of June and hope to have the rebate by the end of July to pay the 30 June accounts. As I have said already, this year things have gone haywire. The rebates are just not coming back. I will give honourable senators just a couple of examples of what has happened.

SPEECH.PARA: Example No. 1 involved an application received by the Department on 14 July for $9,560. When the person concerned found that his rebate was not in the bank when it should have been, he was told on inquiry that his application lacked one signature. This person was in a partnership and had been signing for that partnership for the 10 years since its inception. All of sudden the Department decided that it had to have the signatures of both partners and, therefore, it sent the application back out. Of course, it took about 32 days for the Department to work out that another signature was needed. The application was sent back out on 16 August. The application was returned to the Department. When the fellow inquired again of the Department, he was told that there was a questionnaire to go out. Obviously the Department sends questionnaires out every now and then no doubt to ensure that the exemption still applies. However, the Department sent out the questionnaire without sending the cheque. It took until 19 September to send that questionnaire out. This fellow was getting desperate by then and returned the questionnaire fairly quickly. He then made another inquiry to the Department asking where the money was now. He was told that the cheque would go out in a few days-that was 19 September-after a few minor queries had been sorted out. Of course, as I told honourable senators, that matter has been going on since the present certificate system has been in action. As of today, he still had not got his money. My quick calculation of the overdraft rate or the money forgone in interest adds up to about $500 and rising.

Example No. 2 involved an application for $1,895. This application was received by the Department on 29 July this year. It took the Department until 30 August-in other words, one full month and one day-to have the application verified. Of course, the Department then found some good reason not to pay it until 8 September. I have not even bothered to work out what the interest lost on that money would have amounted to.

Of course, in regard to all these matters I have rung the Department and asked the reason for the trouble. The only excuse I have got is that the Department has been working to rule. I do not know whether working to rule in the Department happens at this time of the year or when the Government is short of money. When we total these two minor sorts of accounts-there are a lot bigger accounts than these around the place; accounts which would put those two to shame-it must amount to a loss of millions and millions of dollars around Australia.
