These people I am talking about are either paying interest on money borrowed or are forgoing interest because it is going into the Government's coffers.

On the other side of the coin, of course, if one is one day late in paying a tax bill one incurs quite a penalty. The Australian Taxation Office does not want any excuses such as the money having been delayed in the mail or that one's office is working to rule. The Taxation Office just does not listen to that sort of thing. If one just happens to mail off a cheque and leave off the interest, one will certainly find that that interest is added to one's tax bill next year.

I am raising this subject because I think it is a serious matter throughout Australia. I consider that the Government could be using the delay in payments as a means of retaining interest free money in its coffers at the expense of somebody else.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Newman Sen J.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —At Question Time today Senator Collins asked Senator Robert Ray a question about the move of what he called the 16th Cavalry Regiment to Darwin. In fact, it appeared that Senator Collins really was asking about the move of the 2 Cavalry Regiment, which is the regiment referred to in the answer Senator Ray gave him. Presumably as the question was a dorothy dixer, one would have assumed that they would have had agreement between them as to what unit it was that was being moved to Darwin. My reason for rising to speak briefly tonight is to set the record straight, because Senator Ray claimed that the Opposition was opposed to the move of 2 Cavalry Regiment to Darwin and that the Opposition defence spokesman, Mr Peter White, had said so last week on his visit to Darwin. That is completely untrue. I would like to quote very briefly from a Northern Territory newspaper, which stated:

SPEECH.PARA: Mr White said during a visit to Darwin last week that the millions of dollars the deployment would cost-
the deployment of the brigade-
should be directed toward more urgent priorities.
While he believed the relocation of the Second Cavalry Regiment to Darwin was proper, the movement of a full brigade was ill-conceived.
The situation is quite clear and unequivocal: we support the move of 2 Cavalry Regiment to Darwin. We have very good and justifiable reasons for being concerned about the movement of the brigade.

This Government has been studying the possibility of moving that brigade to Darwin for some considerable time now. It was to be a two-year study. That study is now well down the track. I simply cannot believe, in light of the fact that the Government is having so much trouble producing the funds which Mr Dibb, in the White Paper, regarded as being important for the maintenance of an effective defence force, that it could possibly find the millions and millions of dollars that would be necessary to effect such a major move. If the Government has such funds, there are other much more urgent priorities within the defence area for spending the money on. Of course, the defence forces currently are announcing that they have got to cut back operations because of changes to the defence budget resulting from a lack of funds, because of an increase in training costs and because of an increase in the number of recruits to replace people who are leaving. As I say, when we have cut-backs in operations and we need money desperately to staunch the haemorrhaging of service personnel from our service ranks, that is where the money should be spent if there is any spare money to go around. It should not be spent in this rather fanciful scheme to move a brigade to Darwin. There are quite good strategic reasons for why that would not be a good proposition. It is not my purpose tonight to go into that in great detail, but I want to make it quite plain that the Opposition is very much in favour of 2 Cavalry Regiment going to Darwin. The Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs, Senator Ray, and Senator Collins today tried unsuccessfully to paint a completely dishonest picture of our view on the matter.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Short Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to raise two matters this evening. However, before doing so I would like to respond briefly to the statement made by Senator Cooney earlier in debate today and to comment on the document that he tabled, as I understand it, on behalf of the Deputy Premier of Victoria, Mr Fordham, in relation to statements made about Mr Fordham's role with the Victorian Economic Development Corporation (VEDC). In fact, I did not make the comments about Mr Fordham; my colleague Senator Alston did. However, I would subscribe completely to the statements made by Senator Alston. Expressions of concern have been reiterated throughout Victoria over many weeks now about the operations of the VEDC and the role of Mr Fordham in relation to the loan that was made to Wallace International Ltd.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Cooney has tabled on behalf of Mr Fordham a statement on the VEDC. In the two minutes I have had that statement, I have not, obviously, had the time to study it carefully. But on a very quick flip through it, it would appear that there is nothing new in this document. It is just a rehash of what we have been told over the past weeks. In my view, it in no way could cause us to resile from the statements that have been made about the role of Mr Fordham in the Wallace International case. We believe-and the Premier of Victoria has not in any way sought to refute this belief-that one of the basic reasons for the calling of the Victorian election next Saturday, 1 October-the elections was called at great haste before the Victorian Government had even let the ink dry on its Budget, let alone get it passed-in unseemly and unexplained haste, was to protect the Deputy Premier of Victoria from scrutiny in the Victorian Parliament over his role in the Wallace International loan by the Victorian Economic Development Corporation. Nothing that Senator Cooney has tabled tonight and nothing that has been said in this place today would in any way cause the Opposition to change its view of that.

I want to raise two matters. I first wish to pursue a little further the question of the Victorian WorkCare scheme, about which I commented in the Senate today when we were debating the state of the Victorian economy. In that debate I spoke about the financial disaster that WorkCare has proved to be in the three years since its establishment by the Cain Government. Time prevented me from mentioning several other points I had intended to raise, and I do so now. I am advised that if the Cain Government is re-elected on Saturday all WorkCare agencies will be sacked immediately and the Accident Compensation Commission will take on the primary responsibility of being the agent. This, of course, is nationalisation in its most extreme form. It would totally nationalise the workers compensation system in Victoria, which is already so far down that track, but it would take it there in entirety by removing completely from the WorkCare scheme any role of private insurance companies in the agency arrangements for WorkCare. It obviously would lead to a great cost escalation and an enormous further expansion of the number of bureaucrats on top of the trebling of the staff of WorkCare that has already occurred during 1987-88.

There are many examples of the complete shambles existing in the administration and operation of WorkCare. I will mention only four but they are just the tip of the iceberg. I mentioned the first one in my speech this afternoon, but it bears repeating. I have in my possession a copy of a cheque dated 29 August 1988 paid by WorkCare to a doctor for services rendered. Fortunately he is an honest doctor and so he returned the cheque. I say `fortunately' because the cheque was written out for $290,788. How on earth could such a mistake occur? The point I make is that it could not occur if even the most basic financial procedures were being followed by WorkCare.

The second example I have concerns a copy of a letter, which is also in my possession, from a company which, again on 29 August 1988-it must have been quite a day for WorkCare-received from WorkCare a cheque for $41,129.20, which in fact should have been for approximately $4,000. Again, it was thanks only to the honesty of the company that the mistake was detected and corrected. The honesty of that company saved the taxpayers of Victoria $37,000. Those mistakes are merely indicative of the chaos which exists within WorkCare.

I also have in my possession a copy of a very recent letter to WorkCare from the operator of a McDonalds restaurant complaining about a 50 per cent increase in his WorkCare levy payments. The increase was not notified to him until mid-August 1988, yet it applied from 1 July. He received no explanation whatsoever of the increase in his levy rate from 1.6 per cent to 2.4 per cent. That is a 50 per cent increase in his costs. Savage cost increases such as this are having a crippling effect on business, particularly small business, in my home State of Victoria. These cost increases are part of a deliberate pattern by the Cain Labor Government of increases in taxes and charges to fund the avaricious spending demands of the most doctrinaire socialist Government in Australia and to pay for its monumental financial mismanagement and incompetence.

For my final example I seek leave to incorporate in Hansard a copy of a letter to WorkCare dated 22 September 1988 from the Melbourne company A. V. Syntec Pty Ltd, which details how, in October 1987, it received a letter from WorkCare advising that the company's levy rate would be reduced by 62.5 per cent from 1 July 1988 when in reality the levy was in fact increased by a massive 90 per cent.
Leave granted.
The letter read as follows-
Incorporating:
A.V. Adheelves
Syntec Chemicals
AVEE Chemicals
A.V. Syntec Pty Ltd
Bridge Road,
Keysborough, Vic. 3173
Australia
P.O. Box 310,
Springvale, Vic. 3171
Telex: AVSYN AA34848
(Incorporated in Queensland)
22nd September 1988
Workcare,
G.P.O. Box 262c,
Melbourne, Vic. 3001
Dear Sirs,
Re-Employer No. 1466229
We wish to bring to your attention a situation which is not only confusing but contradictory to public statements made by the Premier during the past seven days.

When Work Care came to being we wrote to your Department advising you that a dramatic increase in premiums over the private rates that were paid prior to Work Care, your ref: 1466229-19.9.85, and asked you to review. This was duly attended to and our rate of 1.4% has been in place ever since.

We received further correspondence from you dated 9.10.87 advising that new procedures and levys will be introduced on 1.7.88 which indicated that Chemical wholesalers rates would reduce to 0.570% a decrease of 62.50%. Surprise, the 1.7.88 arrives and we are informed that our Levy rate will not fall by 62.50% so widely touted in the press expounding the success of Work Care but in fact INCREASED by a massive 90%. Now fair go. If you publish a Chemical Wholesaler as 0.570% (proposed) and voice publicly that rates have or will fall for a large percentage of categories you should be prepared to go public and let everyone voting in our State elections know that what is published and expounded as good value i.e. `Gee we are doing a great job'' is not so. In fact, I am sure that if a leaflet is printed clearly state that, ``Industries with DECREASED Levy Rates'' there seems a possible case of misrepresentation on your behalf does exist. We do not accept your telephone reply to our letter dated 16.8.88 when your representative stated that we were on a special levy of 1.4% (your normal rate listed as 1.52%) is withdrawn and we are now being asked to pay 2.66%. This does not relate to any Industry remotely close to ours.
We will continue to pay the 1.4% levy until we are satisfied we are getting a ``fair go'' at which time we will seek and expect a refund.

TALK.START.PARA: —The other matter I wanted to raise briefly tonight is I believe a chilling and disturbing story for anyone with even an elementary sense of justice. I do so in a preliminary manner as I intend to pursue the matter much more fully in the Senate in the weeks ahead. My purpose in raising it at all at this stage is because I believe it is vitally important that all Australians know just what is going on in Victoria in respect of union muscle in the building industry, and the complete failure by the Cain Government to do anything whatsoever to support or protect the rights of independent subcontractors in the building industry. Only if there is a public, and a media, awareness of just what is going on will there be any prospect of pressure being brought on the building industry unions to change their intimidatory practices towards subcontractors; or any prospect of reinforcing the rights of the individual and the self-employed in our society.

SPEECH.PARA: In Victoria there is a small company called Troubleshooters Available. Troubleshooters is a labour agency which supplies unionised bona fide self-employed subcontractors to the building industry. Troubleshooters has been repeatedly intimidated, harassed and tormented by building trade unions, Victorian Trades Hall Council officials, and various government departments heavily influenced by the unions. The reason for this intimidation is that the unions want Troubleshooters to alter the status of the independent, self-employed subcontractors who Troubleshooters, as a labour agency, help place on building sites where and when they are needed. The unions want this so that they can increase their control over the subcontractors, even though every one of the subcontractors is a member of a union. Toubleshooters has refused to do this, for two reasons. First, it is not in its power to do so. Second, it would not be in the interest of the self-employed contractors. The dispute between Troubleshooters and the unions has been going on or a considerable period of time. It has been fought in the courts, and on building sites.

I want tonight to draw particular attention to the latest episode in the intimidation and harassment by the unions, and particularly by the Building Workers Industrial Union. Posters and stickers are being put up around building sites in Melbourne by union officials asking that they not be named or they would be in trouble. These posters and stickers are slanderous of Troubleshooters. Troubleshooters has approached the Cain and Hawke governments for protection. They have not even been granted the courtesy of a meeting. Nor have the Cain or Hawke governments made any public denouncement of the slanderous material being distributed.

It is deplorable that neither government is prepared to take any measures whatsoever against this destructive trade union power, which is deliberately obstructing the introduction of the most efficient and productive work practices in the building industry. Troubleshooters, and in particular its two principles, Peter Bosa and Brian Groves, are to be congratulated on their determined and courageous efforts to supply the Victorian building industry with its labour requirements on an efficient and productive basis. I call on the Cain and Hawke governments to instigate an inquiry into the matters I have raised tonight; and to state publicly their support for the rights of independent subcontractors in the building industry.

This is not merely an industrial relations issue. This is human rights under attack. It is about the right of the independent contractor to remain independent. It is an issue that is of national importance because of its obvious ramifications. Freedom of choice is a democratic right. We cannot stand still and allow intimidation and thuggery to rob us of our rights. The future that we leave our children is up to us to determine today. In 1985 I was the first member of this place to bring to public notice the industrial intimidation at the Dollar Sweets Co. Pty Ltd. The Dollar Sweets case became a landmark in Australian industrial history. It was about the rights of the individual in the workplace.

The Dollar Sweets case was followed by the equally famous Mudginberri case. Both these cases dealt a major blow at excessive trade union power at the expense of the individual trade unionist. I believe the Troubleshooters case will finish up alongside Dollars Sweets and Mudginberri as cases which will change for the better the industrial relations landscape and the human rights landscape of Australia. I can assure the Senate that these brief remarks are but the first I will be making on this matter, which I think the Senate will agree is of very great importance to us all.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McGauran Sen J.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —As the Senate would be aware, today Debbie Flintoff-King was victorious in achieving a great hope and dream, not only for her family but for all Australians, when she won a gold medal at the XXIV Olympiad at Seoul, Korea, in the 400 metres hurdles. On such occasions `congratulations' often seems a very simple word, but it is very sincere and joyous congratulations that the Senate extends to Debbie and her family. Debbie Flintoff-King has highlighted the great spirit of achievement that the people of Australia are capable of. She epitomises the spirit of an Australian that the world has come to know and admire. As all Australians would be aware, her victory has been achieved through a great deal of sacrifice and personal tragedy, but she has striven and not yielded. Her gold is truly a gold for this country.

SPEECH.PARA: As the National Party senator for Victoria, I extend my heartfelt congratulations to Les Flintoff, the father of Debbie. Les and I were on the Victorian National Party ticket in the July 1987 election. Anyone who met Les during that election campaign would certainly have realised from where Debbie received her motivation to reach such champion status as she has today. Les really is a champion in everything he tackles. He constantly lifted the spirits of the campaign team and his sound advice made him a very important factor in my own election to the Senate. Politics needs men like Les Flintoff. I know that since the 1987 election he has put his time and energy into supporting Debbie's quest for gold at the Olympics. His reward has been to witness a great race which will be remembered for the Flintoff will and finish at its best. Today he must be very honoured and today Australia is very honoured.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Department of the Prime Minister and Cabinet: Unattached Officers

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Archer Sen B.R.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Prime Minister, upon notice, on 10 May 1988:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Since 11 July 1987, how many Senior Executive Service (SES) officers have become unattached within the Minister's area of portfolio responsibility, including statutory authorities, and of these: (a) how many were placed in sustantive positions at their own level; (b) how many were placed in substantive positions below their sustantive level; (c) how many were offered early retirement packages; (d) what was the mean value of the packages; (e) what was the age structure of these officers.

(2) Since July 1987 how many administrative support, other scientific and technical officers became unattached, and of these: (a) how many were placed in substantive positions at their own level; (b) how many were placed in substantive positions below their substantive level; (c) how many were offered early retirement packages; (d) what was the mean value of the packages; and (e) what was the age structure of these officers.
(3) What programs of retraining and redeployment are in place to usefully employ those permanent officers still on the unattached, supernumerary and redundancy list.
(4) What has been the net saving in SES and other positions in each portfolio/statutory authority since 11 July 1987.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Prime Minister has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: Taking all parts of the question to refer to the Machinery of Government changes which took effect on 24 July 1987, the answer to the question for my Department and portfolio agencies under my control, with the exception of the Public Service Commission, is as follows:-
In respect of the Public Service Commission, the answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

The Machinery of Government changes on 24 July 1987 transferred some Public Service Board offices and staff to other departments. Remaining offices and staff continued to exist as part of the Public Service Board.

On 18 September the Administrative Arrangements Act 1987 repealed provisions relating to the constitution of the Public Service Board and replaced them with provisions relating to the Public Service Commission, thereby creating the Public Service Commission.

The Act also provided that anyone who held an office in the Public Service Board prior to its legislative abolition retained an office in the Public Service Commission. Therefore, technically, no officer was unattached as a result of the Machinery of Government changes.

Following the Machinery of Government changes the Public Service Board and Commission varied the establishment structure for the Public Service Commission and, as a result, some staff were identified as being potentially surplus to the Commission's eventual staffing requirements.
Staff in this category were assisted in gaining permanent transfer at their substantive levels to other Departments. This included both central and regional office staff.
(1) 43 Senior Executive Service positions existed in the Public Service Board against which 35 Senior Executive Service officers occupied positions (a number of positions were vacant).

6 were transferred to the Public Service Commission, 1 was tranferred with function to the Department of Finance, 12 with function to the Department of Industrial Relations, and 11 have been placed at their substantive level in other Departments; that is, a total 30 SES staff were placed at their substantive level.
2 officers have retired, and 3 are still surplus, (2 of whom are temporarily placed in departments and 1 is on leave without pay).
(2) The total Public Service Board Administrative Service Officer staff in July 1987 was approximately 745, including approximately 60 unpaid inoperatives.
The 685 paid staff equated to approximately 665 ASL (full-time equivalents).

Approximately 42 transferred with function to the Department of Finance; approximately 158 with function to the Department of Industrial Relations; and approximately 134 staff transferred with residual functions to the Public Service Commission, giving a balance of approximately 411 staff.

(a) All i.e. 745 Administrative Service Officers (with the exception of approximately 10 unpaid inoperative staff who have not yet returned to duty as at 8 June 1988) were either placed at their substantive level or resigned or retired.

(3) All officers excess to the requirements of the Public Service Commission are either occupying positions on a temporary basis in the Commission or other Departments or are engaged on duties appropriate to their level.
Development options are under review for all excess staff including attendance at courses offered by the Commission's Staff Development Branch.

(4) The former Public Service Board had an approved SES structure comprising 43 positions. The Public Service Commission has an approved SES structure comprising 7 positions, so the net saving to the portfolio from the abolition of the Board was 36 SES positions.

The anticipated Average Staffing Level (ASL) for the Public Service Board for 1987-88 was in the order of 690. The Public Service Commission's approved ongoing ASL for 1987-88 was 124. A further 12 ASL were provided to the Department of the Prime Minister and Cabinet to provide corporate services to the Commission and the Merit Protection and Review Agency (which previously had similar services provided by the Public Service Board), so the total net saving to the portfolio is 554 ASL, comprising 36 ASL for SES positions and 518 ASL for other positions.

Approximate figures only can be provided in response to this question as accurate records of staffing arrangements at 11 July are not available and a complete record of officers transferring to other positions was not maintained. Information provided has been drawn from a number of sources and is as accurate as can be reasonably achieved.

ANSWER.PARA: (2) The Liquidator's terms and conditions are set out in Part II of the Phosphate Mining Corporation of Christmas Island (Winding Up) Ordinance 1987. The remuneration payable to the Liquidator are those fees from time to time recommended by the Insolvency Practitioners Association of Australia for a Principal Appointee Liquidator of a Company with similar allowances to those payable from time to time to the Secretary of a Department of the Commonwealth of Australia.

(3) In accepting advice from the Directors of the Phosphate Mining Company of Christmas Island that the Company was not financially viable and should be wound down by the end of 1986, the Government decided on 11 September 1985 that issues concerning the future of the Island should be examined by a Working Party. That Working Party was chaired by the (then) Department of Territories and included representatives from Commonwealth agencies with an interest in the Island, the Australian Council of Trade Unions (ACTU), the Phosphate Mining Company of Christmas Island, the Union of Christmas Island Workers (UCIW), the Christmas Island Services Corporation (CISC), the Minister's Office and Parliamentarians. The Working Party reported in December 1985 on a range of issues requiring immediate attention and foreshadowed proposals to be developed about the future. In respect of mining, it generally concluded that a viable successor mining operation was an option in the short-term provided there was acceptance that it would have a limited life and that it would have to operate on an economic basis.

Against this background, the Phosphate Mining Corporation of Christmas Island (PMCCI) was established in late 1985. PMCCI found itself in financial difficulties during 1987, and the Government subsequently appointed a Liquidator to the Corporation on 11 November 1987. The Liquidator announced that PMCCI would close with effect from 31 December 1987. Following that, the UCIW commissioned consultants, Arthur Andersen and Company to examine the feasibility of phosphate mining continuing on the Island. That study concluded that future phosphate mining may be viable within certain parameters.

In a media statement on 11 February 1988, Mr Punch rejected the findings of the Arthur Andersen report. He went on to say, however, that the Government would examine genuine proposals for mining if any were forthcoming. He also outlined the Government's conditions for any future mining on the Island.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 18 February 1988 (Hansard, page 225), Senator Chaney asked me, as Minister representing the Minister for Industrial Relations, a question without notice regarding threatened industrial action by the Transport Workers Union (TWU) over the decision by Caltex Australia Ltd to contract out the distribution of its products to the Linfox organisation. Senator Chaney asked what steps the Government had taken to ensure that the TWU did not proceed with the action threatened. In my reply, I undertook to refer the matter to the Minister for Industrial Relations. The Minister has provided the following response:

ANSWER.PARA: Clearly, the announced sale by Caltex of its road tanker fleet and the contracting out of its product distribution function to the Linfox organisation was a matter of concern to the TWU. It was unfortunate, however, that, in addressing these concerns TWU members took industrial action which resulted in disruption to petrol supplies at different times particularly in New South Wales and Victoria. Further, the New South Wales Government considered it necessary in the circumstances to utilise the emergency powers provided for in State legislation to ensure a return to a normal supply situation.

The matters in dispute were, of course, the subject of proceedings in the Australian Conciliation and Arbitration Commission. Indeed, the dispute, insofar as it related to the siutation in Victoria, South Australia and Western Australia, was the subject of proceedings before Leary C on 22 February during which arrangements were developed between the parties which led to a decision by TWU members on 24 February to cease industrial action in those States.

As far as the industrial action in New South Wales was concerned, the matter was heard in compulsory conference by Boulton J on Sunday, 28 February 1988. His Honour's recommendation at the conclusion of those proceedings called for, inter alia, cessation of industrial action in New South Wales and negotiations between the parties on particular issues in dispute. Further, following the return to work by TWU members on 29 February in compliance with the directions issued by the State Government, His Honour held a further hearing on 1 March 1988 at which he issued an order:
directing that the status quo be maintained for 30 days (ie no industrial action and no further implementation of the Caltex/Linfox arrangements); and
directing that negotiations involving the TWU, ACTU, Caltex and Linfox take place over various issues in dispute and that these negotiations be chaired by a member of the Commission.

These negotiations commenced on 2 March 1988 and a series of private conferences chaired by Boulton J ensued during March. On 25 March TWU members employed by Caltex met and rejected a redundancy package offered by the company. Immediate strike action over the issue was taken by the company's Victorian drivers. Boulton J heard the matter on 28 March and on the following day directed, inter alia, that the Caltex offer be extended until 30 March. The company indicated the offer would then be withdrawn. On 30 March Caltex drivers met and voted to accept the redundancy package leading to a cessation of the industrial action in Victoria.

The Government monitored developments in the dispute at the time and was supportive of the role played by the Australian Conciliation and Arbitration Commission. The Government's view is that the Commission is the proper forum in which the parties should seek to resolve industrial issues upon which they cannot reach agreement. Recourse to the established industrial relations machinery is of course preferable to direct action of the type which required the New South Wales Government to take the action it did.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 1 June 1988 (Hansard, page 3340), Senator Harradine asked me in my capacity as the Minister representing the Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Public Service Matters a question without notice concerning the level of youth employment in the Australian Public Service and what steps the Goverment is taking to ensure that youth get their fair share of Public Service Jobs. I undertook to obtain the figures and provide Senator Harradine with an answer. The Prime Minister has provided me with the following answer to the honourable senator's questions, based on information provided by the Public Service Commission:

ANSWER.PARA: In relation to the first question:

the proportion of youth in the Service is declining-in December 1987 young people aged 20 or under constituted 3.8% of officers (a table setting out the age distribution of permanent staff is attached)

the number of young people applying for appointment to the Service is also declining. In 1979 the proportion of young applicants for Clerical Assistant positions was 64% and for Clerical Administrative Class 1 positions 46.7%. This declined to 45.5% and 37.2% respectively by 1985
the proportion of young people being appointed to the Service is declining-in 1980 young people aged under 20 constituted 26.1% of appointments. In 1984 this declined to 22.4% and in 1986 to 18.6%
this trend is not the result of any deliberate policy of discrimination against youth in the processes for entry to the Service
entry to the Service is based on an assessment of the relative ability of applicants to perform the work required
factors which can be identified as contributing to the decline in the level of youth in the Service are:
- retention rates for the final year of secondary schooling have risen from 28% in 1966 to 53% in 1987; in the ACT, a large recruiting centre, the retention rate is 79%
- the number of students enrolled in full-time higher education courses increased by 18% between 1976 and 1986. In the same period, the number of youth in the general population increased by only 8%

- increased school retention and higher education participation rates have decreased the number of young applicants for positions in the Service, particularly in the younger age groups, and increased the average age of young people entering the Service

- the bar on married women remaining in the Service was removed in 1966. Upper age limits for appointments to base grade clerical and keyboard positions were removed in 1973, while upper limits on the number of graduates appointed were abolished in 1978
- all of these measures have tended to reduce the appointment opportunities for youth
(iv) Greater competition in the labour market
- generally buoyant labour market conditions until the early 1970s meant that young people seeking to enter the Service did not face strong competition
- since the mid 1970s a generally tighter labour market has meant that young people have been required to compete more strenuously with older applicants
(v) Constraints on the growth of the Service and a decline in separation rates
- constraints on the growth of the Service since the mid 1970s have resulted in a reduction of appointment opportunities
- overall separation rates for officers of the Service have declined from 10.4% in 1966 to 7.5% in 1984
- combined, these trends have further limited appointment opportunities available for young people

the decline of youth in the Public Service is not limited to Australia. For example, the Public Service Commission of Canada in its 1987 annual report noted that the proportion of youth (those under 25) in the Canadian Public Service had dropped from 14.1% in 1977 to 3.3% in 1987.
In relation to the second question:

The Public Service Commission is concerned at the decline in the number of young people in the Service and supports a recent recommendation of Joint Council that the Commonwealth Employment Service (which now has the responsibility for operational aspects of clerical recruitment to the Service) should investigate the prospects for maximising the numbers of young people applying for Service positions through:
the timing of selection tests at the end of the school year so as to maximise the numbers of young people

the continued expansion of youth traineeships in the Service. There was an initial intake of 610 trainees in early 1986, with a further 162 taken on later that year. Some 855 trainees were employed in 1987.

The Government has announced that young people aged 16 to 18 without Year 12 seeking to enter the Service in areas where traineeships exist, should do so via traineeships. It is anticipated that this will provide some 1500 traineeship opportunities this year.

While these measures will be helpful in increasing the proportion of young people in the Service, it is unlikely that there will be a significant turnaround, and certainly not to the high levels experienced in the 1960s.
A.P.S. PERMANENT STAFF; AGE AND SEX DECEMBER 1987

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Newman Sen J.M.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Industrial Relations and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Public Service Matters, upon notice, on 18 February 1988:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) How many officers and from which departments, are reimbursed for all fees, under the provisions of paragraph 2.28 of the Public Service Board Personnel Management Manual: Volume 7-Guidelines on Studies Assistance (October 1986).
(2) What is the total amount payable by each department in respect of these fees and of the amount, how much relates to the $263 tertiary fee.

(3) If no $263 tertiary fees are being paid, when was the decision taken that they not be paid, by whom, and on what grounds are they not being paid when the guidelines provide for the reimbursement of all fees.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1 to 3) The current `Guidelines on Studies Assistance' do not provide for the reimbursement of all fees. The guidelines provide for reimbursement of compulsory `tuition' or `examination' fees (the $263 higher education administration charge is not a `tuition' or `examination' fee).
The higher education administration charge may be reimbursed to a small minority of students:
where the student was given approval to study prior to 1 January 1981;
where the student was employed under cadetship or traineeship conditions of service; or
where under full-time study arrangements the Secretary of the Department approves payment of fees and charges under section 90 (3) of the Public Service Act.

The Public Service Commission does not keep statistics on studies assistance. QUESTION.SPEAKER: Sanders Sen N.K.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories, upon notice, on 25 March 1988:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Has the Minister received correspondence and photos from Mrs E. Mayer of Lane Cove, New South Wales, detailing the effects of dredging in the Heron Island Harbour, the island and adjacent parts of the Great Barrier Reef.
(2) What is the purpose of the dredging operations.
(3) Are those operations damaging the Great Barrier Reef.
(4) What power does the Federal Government have to prevent further damage.
(5) What action has the Federal Government taken to prevent further damage.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Yes. My office responded to Mrs Mayer's letter on my behalf on 22 January 1988.

(2) Dredging was undertaken for the maintenance of the existing entrance channel and harbour, to allow some expansion of the harbour basin to facilitate manoeuvring of a new catamaran ferry, for the repair of existing bund walls, and for the construction of a jetty. Siltation of the harbour over the years since it was last dredged had been substantial and there had been significant damage to the bund wall which had been designed to minimise such siltation. This could not be allowed to continue.

(3) The Great Barrier Reef Marine Park Authority, in conjunction with the Queensland National Parks and Wildlife Service and the Heron Island Management Board, carefully considered this proposal before the Authority issued a permit for the work to commence. The immediate impact of the dredging work did give cause for concern and I am advised that the sediment plume and spoil heaps were unattractive during the course of the project. I am now advised that the water clarity adjacent to the dredge site has returned to pre-dredging condition.

Very little coral damage, attributable to the dredging operation, has been observed at Heron Island. Two outcrops of brain coral on the reef slope, each about 1.5 metres high and 3 metres in diameter, have suffered greater than 50 percent mortality. The complete colonies have not died at this stage and may recover over a period of years. Several very small coral heads on the reef flat appear to have died as a result of silt damage. Several small areas of branching corals on the reef slope have been affected. The total coral area affected is some 30 square metres. The total area of Heron Island Reef is about 37.5 million square metres.
(4) The waters up to low water mark adjacent to Heron Island are part of the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park and as such are subject to the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park Act 1975.

In addition any proposed activity which involves a decision by the Marine Park Authority (or by any other arm of the Commonwealth Government) and which may have a significant environmental effect, would be subject to the Environment Protection (Impact of Proposals) Act 1974.

The Environment Protection (Sea Dumping) Act 1981, which refers to the dumping of wastes or other matter from ships, aircraft or platforms into Australian waters, confers wide powers to control such activities and to require monitoring and other environment protection oriented actions.

(5) The Great Barrier Reef Marine Park Authority in close consultation with Queensland National Parks and Wildlife Service, the University of Queensland and P & O (the owners of the Heron Island Resort) have formulated a monitoring program with a considerably expanded scope over that which was conducted during the course of the dredging operation.

The monitoring program will emphasise consideration of the reef slope, the beach rock and the chronic stress resulting from persistent silt resuspension. Geological and geomechanical components will include consideration of beach profile, sediment distribution and the washout of silt/mud fractions.

Experts and consultants outside the Marine Park Authority and Queensland National Parks and Wildlife Service will also be used for some aspects of the program to ensure the cross-section of opinion available in assessing findings is maximised.

I have been assured that the monitoring program which has been established will result in the development of more comprehensive guidelines for the assessment of dredging operations than has been available in the past, and that this will go a long way in eliminating the concerns which have arisen at Heron Island.

The Great Barrier Reef Marine Park Authority has advised me that the amount of turbidity and sediment transport caused by the operation exceeded the expectations of the design engineers, the Authority and the Queensland National Parks and Wildlife Service. The damage caused by the operation is temporary, but any future dredging operations in the Marine Park will be subject to more stringent restrictions as a result of this experience.

ANSWER.PARA: On a broader level, the Minister and senior Australian Defence officials have raised this matter on a number of occasions. In a speech to major US defence contractors and senior US officials in October 1987, Mr Woods referred to the damage to Australia's balance of trade resulting from US trade policy, and the logical consequence of its being more difficult for Australia to afford to buy US Defence equipment.

Similar sentiments have been expressed to groups of contractors on various occasions, by the Head of the Australian Defence Staff in Washington and by other Australian Defence officials. For example, in early September 1986 the then Head of the Australian Defence Staff, Major General H. J. Coates wrote to the heads of the following principal US companies with which Australia has had defence dealings:
Major General Coates made follow-up visits to:
Rockwell and Lockhead, Los Angeles-10 September 1986
The then Air Attache, Air Commodore A. Reed made similar visits to:
In almost all occasions, access was achieved to the highest executives of the Coporation ie. President, Vice President or Chairman of the Board.

The Minister and his official have had many other meetings since 1983 with defence contractors on a range of issues relating to the large number of procurements being undertaken by the Defence Department. Generally the meetings have not been called specifically for the purpose stated in the question although the opportunity has been taken on appropriate occasions to make that point.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Archer Sen B.R.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories, upon notice, on 18 May 1988:

QUESTION.PARA: What is being done to help replenish the ozone layer in terms of-
(a) steps taken to prevent further depletion; and
(b) artificial means.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (a) The Government attaches great importance to protection of the layer of ozone gas in the upper atmosphere which screens out harmful ultraviolet radiation.

It is a global problem which requires action by all countries, but especially developed countries, to control ozone depleting chemicals. Australia is a party to the Vienna Convention on Protection of the Ozone Layer. We are also a signatory to the Montreal Protocol to this Convention which specifies controls on chemicals known to deplete ozone levels. The Government intends to ratify this Protocol as soon as implementing legislation has been enacted.

The Government is proceeding with drafting of legislation to control ozone depleting substances. This is a high priority and it is intended that the legislation be introduced into the Parliament this Sittings.

The proposed legislation will place Australia at the forefront of action internationally to address this problem. The proposed legislation will include provisions to give effect to the Montreal Protocol, principally through quotas applied to the manufacturers and importers of the chlorofluorocarbons (CFCs) and halons which are of concern.

Importantly, the proposed legislation will also provide for introduction of comprehensive measures to limit emissions from the various applications of these substances. CFCs are used mainly in refrigeration and air conditioning systems, in production of some plastic foams, in some aerosol sprays and as solvents. Halons are used for some fire protection purposes. The goal will be to achieve the maximum practicable reductions in the emission of these substances.

Through a joint Government/Industry working group, industry has developed initial proposals for reduction of emissions in each of the key industry sectors. Those proposals show that by utilising available alternative substances and technologies, reductions in emissions to the order of 50% can be achieved by 1992. For example, the elimination of CFC propellants in aerosol sprays, in all except limited essential uses, will alone result in reduction of the national consumption of CFCs by about 30% by the end of 1989. However, it is important to note that the initial industry plans also identify potential for substantial further reductions to be achieved as new alternative substances and technologies, some of which are already in an advanced stage of development, become available. Under the proposed legislation, new initiatives for reducing emissions will be able to be adopted as they are developed.

Further important scientific findings have been made in the year since the Montreal Protocol was concluded, for example concerning the role of CFCs in the increasing losses of ozone over Antarctica-the so-called ozone hole. The CSIRO and the Bureau of Meteorology have provided recently an assessment of the current state of the science on depletion of the ozone layer. Australia will take an active part in the review of the provisions of the Montreal Protocol which is to be completed by 1990. In light of the latest scientific findings, there is a strong likelihood that the Protocol provisions will be made more stringent as a result of that review.

(b) Replenishment of the ozone layer by artificial means is apparently not a feasible solution to the problem. The effectiveness of the ozone layer is dependent on naturally occurring chemical reactions in the upper atmosphere which result in the continual production and destruction of ozone at rates which maintain a dynamic balance. The present international scientific view is that the reduction of emissions of ozone depleting substances which have been identified as interfering with these natural processes is the most appropriate way of ensuring that the dynamic balance is restored over time.

It is important to recognise that in the lower atmosphere ozone acts as a pollutant, particularly in relation to its exacerbation of respiratory problems and its toxic effects on plant life, even at concentrations slightly above normal. Atmospheric ozone also contributes to the ``greenhouse effect''. Artificial production of ozone is therefore likely to cause other potentially severe imbalances in the atmosphere.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: MacGibbon Sen D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce, upon notice, on 20 May 1988:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Have any grants been made to the Inventors' Association of Australia; if so, how much was granted and in what years.
(2) Was the grant made to the Association for administrative expenses, or was it intended that it be given to support the work done by individual inventors.
(3) Was it intended that this grant be used for the purchase of office equipment.
(4) Was any part of the grant, over any of the years it was given, used to employ any consultants; if so, was the purpose covered under the intention of the grant.
(5) Has there been any follow up on how the grant was expended; if not, why not.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Grants totalling $250,000 have been made by this Department and its predecessor, the Department of Science and Technology, to the Inventors' Association of Australia (IAA).

In an agreement dated 7 June 1984, the then Department of Science and Technology, recognising the potential of the IAA to assist the Government's objective of encouraging innovation and invention, committed $25,000 to restructure the Association to achieve a more professional and effective national organisation. The final payments under this agreement were made by the Department of Industry, Technology and Commerce in 1985.

On 14 June 1985, my Department signed a further agreement with the IAA providing funds totalling $225,000 over three years at the rate of $75,000 per year, payable in advance. However, the IAA was faced with cash flow difficulties in March 1986 and the instalments were paid as follows:

(2) The grants were intended to assist the IAA to provide inventors and entrepreneurs with an infrastructure to facilitate access to information, expertise, services, facilities and other resources. To achieve this the Association needed to project a high profile, gain the confidence of individuals and organisations involved in the innovation process and conduct all its operations with a high degree of professionalism and efficiency.

A Corporate Development Strategy, forming part of the later agreement, includes a statement of the IAA's proposed expenditure for the years covered by the agreement. Less than 30% of the proposed total expenditure per year was for administrative expenses, such as the lease of a photocopier, printing, stationery, rent, telephone and other necessary expenses.
The Association does not provide financial support for individual inventors and it was not intended that the grants be used for this purpose.

(3) The Corporate Development Strategy outlined the intention to lease a photocopier and purchase a computer. To achieve the goals of greater efficiency and professionalism, this and any similar expenditure on office equipment falls within the intention of the grants.

(4) Use by the IAA of part of its funds, (of which my Department contributed only about one third), to employ consultants was not contrary to the intent of the funding arrangements outlined in the agreement.
(5) My Department has been provided with information on the IAA's activities and expenditure. Financial statements for the years ending 30 June 1986 and 1987 have been received.

The IAA is currently preparing a financial statement and a report outlining the activities undertaken by the Association for the 87/88 financial year. The IAA's achievements in terms of fulfilling the agreement will be assessed when this final report is received.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Crichton-Browne Sen N.A.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Community Services and Health, upon notice, on 1 June 1988:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Is the Minister aware of the heavy burden placed on pharmacists-particularly those in small pharmacies in rural and remote areas-to maintain an accurate and up to date file system for the purposes of the Pharmaceutical Benefit Scheme.

(2) Is the Minister aware of the great distress that can occur when pharmacists are forced to refuse to fill out prescriptions in circumstances where pensioners forget or lose their Pharmaceutical Benefits Card.

(3) Does the Pharmaceutical Benefit Scheme impose too great an impost on these pharmacists when, in addition to their normal pharmacy work, they are required to act as agents for the Commonwealth in maintaining these records of Pharmaceutical Benefits numbers; if not, why not.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Housing and Aged Care has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Yes. However, it is important for pharmacists and the Government to be able to account for almost $1 billion of taxpayers' funds.

(2) As in other areas where pensioners are granted concessions, they must establish eligibility for concessional treatment. While the Government recognises that this may cause inconvenience in some cases, this statutory requirement is necessary to ensure that proper control is exercised over the expenditure of taxpayers' funds.
In the event of the loss of a pensioner's entitlement card, an interim card will be issued immediately by the local Social Security office on application by the pensioner.

(3) No. When determining pharmacists' remuneration, the Pharmaceutical Benefits Remuneration Tribunal takes into account the workload associated with dispensing a pharmaceutical benefit, including keeping records required under the Scheme. In fact, the Tribunal has recently undertaken a survey of pharmacies to ascertain the cost of dispensing pharmaceutical benefits.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: McLean Sen P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Community Services and Health, upon notice, on 1 June 1988:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What proportion of the total yearly budget of the Department of Community Services and Health is spent on medical research.
(2) What proportion of the Gross Domestic Product is spent on medical research.
(3) How do these figures compare with the member country of the OECD which spends most on medical research, and the member country of the OECD which spends least on medical research.
(4) Have there been any significant changes in the proportion of funds spent on medical research in Australia in the last ten years.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Community Services and Health has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) In 1986-87, the Department spent $75.4 million on health related research. This represented 0.93 per cent of total departmental outlays. Projected expenditure for 1987-88 is $84.0 million (0.95 per cent of departmental outlays).

(2) In 1986-87, research and development expenditure in Australia directed towards the socio-economic objective of health represented 0.11 per cent of the Gross Domestic Product (GDP). An alternative classification of research and development expenditure is by field of science. Using this classification, research and development expenditure in the medical sciences amounted to 0.082 per cent of GDP in 1986-87.

(3) Data for total research and development expenditure on either health or medical sciences for the OECD nations are unavailable. However, data are available on the level of government-funded health research and development. In 1986, the USA Government-funded research and development on the socio-economic objective of health was 0.16 per cent of GDP. As a percentage of GDP, this was the highest of all the OECD nations. The lowest rate of government-funded health research funding for OECD nations (for which data are available) was Spain, where Government-funded health research and development amounted to 0.016 per cent of GDP. The median for all OECD countries (excluding Australia) was 0.067 per cent of GDP. Government-funded health research in Australia amounted to 0.085 per cent of GDP in 1984-85 (later figures are not yet available).
(4) Over the period 1976-77 to 1986-87, research and development expenditure in Australia on the socio-economic objective of health has increased by 167 per cent in real terms.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Tambling Sen G.E.J.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for the Arts and Territories, upon notice, on 1 June 1988:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Can the Minister provide proof that all groups who submitted proposals for a successor mining operation on Christmas Island were given until the end of April to provide submissions to him; if so, when and how was each group advised of this.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for the Arts and Territories has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) A report by Arthur Andersen and Company, consultants commissioned by the Union of Christmas Island Workers, concluded that future phosphate mining on Christmas Island may be viable within certain parameters. In a media statement on 11 February 1988 Mr Punch rejected the findings of that report. He went on to say, however, that the Government would examine genuine proposals for mining if any were forthcoming, but these would necessarily need to be made quickly because the Liquidator's work was well advanced. He also outlined the Government's conditions for any future mining on the Island.
A number of expressions of interest and three firm proposals to recommence phosphate operations on the Island were subsequently received during March 1988.

Given the need to move quickly to finalise assessment of proposals, and following the cyclonic storm on 27 March 1988 which damaged some mining infrastructure, Departmental Officers telephoned all proponents on 5 April 1988 advising them that the Department would recommend to the Minister that all proposals, including any variations necessitated by the storm damage, should be submitted by the end of April 1988 and that they should work on that basis.

Throughout this process, several of the proponents had urged Mr Punch to have the assessment of proposals undertaken by an independent party. In giving effect to that concern and recognising the need for the process to be consistent with Commonwealth assets disposal policy, Mr Punch, on 12 May 1988, announced that the assessment of proposals would be undertaken by the Official Liquidator of the Phosphate Mining Corporation of Christmas Island.

The final date of 31 May 1988 for submissions to be received was set by the Liquidator through advertisements in national newspapers. This date was subsequently extended by the Liquidator to 10 June 1988. The Liquidator had written on 25 May 1988 to those groups who had previously provided submissions to the Minister concerning future mining, informing them of his assessment and that it was not necessary for them to submit a fresh proposal.
The issue of fresh proposals was, of course, a matter for the individual judgement of proponents, and several submitted amended proposals or additional information.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Reid Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Social Security, upon notice, on 22 August 1988:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Are recipients of Invalid Pension, once assessed as eligible to receive an Invalid Pension, reassessed after they have been in receipt of the Invalid Pension for any length of time; if so, how frequently are reviews conducted, and what form does the reassessment take; if not, why not.

(2) Where a recipient of a Social Security Pension or Benefit appeals against a decision of the Department to the Administrative Appeal Tribunal and the Tribunal finds the recipient's case to be without merit, is the recipient required to pay any costs associated with the appeals; if so, what costs is the recipient required to pay; if not, why not.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Bolkus Sen The Hon N.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Social Security has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) All pensioners, excepting those who are permanently blind, are subject to a periodical review by mail of their circumstances to ensure that their eligibility is continuing and that the correct rate of pension is being paid. The period between reviews can vary between one to three years depending on individual circumstances.
Invalid pensioners may also be subject to the following types of reviews.

(a) A sample of invalid pensioners is interviewed in person 12 months after grant of pension. The interview is usually conducted in the pensioner's home and is part of a full entitlement review of matters which may affect pension eligibility such as financial circumstances. This review does not include an assessment of medical eligibility.

(b) Review of medical eligibility are conducted where it is considered that the pensioner's condition may improve or where other information comes to hand indicating that a medical review is warranted, such as the pensioner commencing work. The medical review consists of assessment of a report from the pensioner's treating medical practitioner and, if necessary, an examination by a Commonwealth Medical Officer. A further medical review may be scheduled if it appears that future improvement in the pensioner's condition is likely. The scheduling of these reviews depends on the individual circumstances of each pensioner. If their condition is deteriorating or is otherwise unlikely to improve, a medical review is not conducted.

(2) When the Administrative Appeals Tribunal was established it was intended to provide a cheap and accessible forum as an alternative to litigation in the courts. Accordingly, the Administrative Appeals Tribunal Act 1975 does not empower the Tribunal to award costs to either party in the Social Security jurisdiction whatever the result of the application for review.
If appellants do not appear in person, they are faced with the payment of their own legal costs (unless provided under the legal aid system which would not fund a case without merit).
The tribunal has very rarely described an appeal to be ``without merit''.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Lewis Sen A.W.R

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 2 June 1988:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What individual obligations under the defence component of the offsets program have been incurred by overseas participants since 30 June 1980.
(2) For each obligation incurred, has the obligation been discharged; if so, by what means.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Defence has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The Commonwealth considers that details of individual obligations incurred by companies to be Commercial-in-Confidence and has undertaken not to disclose such details. This consideration was fully supported by a recommendation made in 1984 by the Inglis Committee of Review on Offsets. Therefore, the information at the level of detail requested by Senator Lewis cannot be made public knowledge.
(2) In order to respond to Senator Lewis, without compromising the Commonwealth's undertaking the following information is provided on the defence component of the offsets program since 30 June 1980:

- thirty individual obligations have been fully discharged by twenty-five companies representing $100 million worth of offsets. The total obligation placed on the companies was $70 million. A list of companies involved is provided in the attached Table 1.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Crichton-Browne Sen N.A.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Attorney-General, upon notice, on 23 August 1988:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What cities and towns has the Constitutional Commission or any of its sub-committees visited for the purpose of taking public submissions since the Commission was established.
(2) What amount of time was spent by each body in each of the towns and cities mentioned in part (1).
(3) How many people appeared before the bodies on each of the occasions mentioned in part (1).

(4) How many written submissions had the Commission or its sub-committees received from people in towns and cities mentioned in part (1) in advance of the Commission or its sub-committees making the visits mentioned in part (1).
(5) What has been the cost of the visits mentioned in part (1).

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Attorney-General has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) to (5) The Constitutional Commission has provided the following information:

The Constitutional Commission and its five Advisory Committees received submissions at meetings, most of them public, on 92 days in 27 cities and towns in all States and mainland Territories and on Norfolk Island.

The full cost of visiting a city in which a public hearing was held is given in the tables below. On numerous occasions, however, the Commission's Advisory Committees also undertook other tasks and engagements while in the city, e.g. conducting or participating in seminars, and holding meetings which were not public hearings.

In the tables the costs of conducting those public hearings include all transport costs, sitting fees, travelling allowance, salary costs of staff while travelling and attending the public hearings, and venue hire. Advertising costs are not included in the calculations. Approximately $97,000 of expenditure is attributable to advertising public hearings. It is not possible to be more precise because most of the Commission's advertising was multi-purpose.

In computing the costs shown in the tables below, it has been necessary notionally to subdivide various lump sum figures. At all times the Commission tried to organise its public hearing programs in such a way that airfares were minimised, by covering a number of public hearings on a single journey. In those cases the total airfare for the journey has been notionally subdivided between the various venues covered by the journey.

For ease of presentation the information sought is set out in tabular form. The caveat should be added that the approach of each of the Advisory Committees was different, and that this difference in approach was reflected in the numbers and format of the public meetings held by each Committee. The different approaches were dictated very much by the different subject matters which the five Advisory Committees were reviewing.

Statistics on how many written submissions the Commission or its Advisory Committees had received from people in the various towns and cities visited, in advance of the Commission or a Committee conducting public hearings, are not readily available. The Constitutional Commission and its Committees received over 4,000 written and oral submissions. The first submission was received in February 1986. One hundred had been received by early June 1986; 300 by late September 1986; 500 by mid November 1986; 800 by early January 1987; 1000 by late February 1987 and 2000 by the end of April 1987. The public hearings commenced early in July 1986 and concluded in mid March 1987. Most of the hearings were held between August and December 1986.

Records of the people attending the public hearings were not collected, or thought appropriate to be collected. The attendance figures which follow are therefore approximate only and are based on the recollections of those who attended the respective hearings. The total attendance at the public hearings, including the people who made the 677 oral submissions received at them, was approximately two and a half thousand.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Jones Sen G.N.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Industrial Relations, upon notice, on 24 August 1988:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Will the Minister provide State by State figures for average weekly male and female earnings to cover the financial year 1986-87.
(2) If there are considerable disparities between the States, could the Minister outline what action is being taken or is contemplated to redress imbalances.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Industrial Relations has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The table below provides data on the dollar level of average weekly earnings (AWE) for males and females in each of the six States in 1985-86 and 1986-87 and also the rate of growth of those earnings.
TABLE: AVERAGE WEEKLY EARNINGS BY SEX AND STATE

(2) There are considerable disparities between States in both the level and growth of AWE. Two major reasons for differences in earnings across the States are differences in the industrial and occupational mix. A State with a higher proportion of relatively lower paid industries or occupations will have, on average, a lower level of AWE. Differences in the level and rate of growth of AWE between States may also arise if significant differences in the proportions of part-time, junior, or temporary workers exist. These differences in industrial and labour force composition between States represent valid reasons for any perceived `imbalances'. Accordingly, such differences are not directly addressed by Commonwealth Government policy.
Other factors accounting for earnings differences between States include differences in the incidence of overtime worked and overaward payments reflecting varying labour market conditions.

It should be noted that since the beginning of the current centralised wage-fixing system in 1983, the State industrial tribunals and courts have followed closely the principles and decisions of the Australian Conciliation and Arbitration Commission. Indeed, for equity reasons, the Government has supported a consistent approach across Federal and State jurisdictions. Thus all Australian wage earners regardless of their State of residence have had increases in their award rates of pay determined under an essentially common set of wage fixing guidelines.
